story:
WHO ARE WE?

My name is April Singley.  Inspired by the real-life figure of "Oldcraghan Man", a bog body found in Manchester, England in the 1980s, I set about to learn more about the mummified remains of a great ruler who elected to be subjected  to great torture in order to bring prosperity to his people.  The brutal destruction of the flesh as necessary, so the ancient Celts believed, upon the feast of Beltane, when spirits would be released and the gods appeased.  I considered the myths and the mystery behind the Celts. What began as curiosity, prompted me to ponder the nature of sacrifice in all its forms. 

 In 2012 I wrote a play entirely in iambic pentameter, centered around "Lovernos" ( the latinized name for man referred to as Oldcroghan man).  Iobair is a Celtic word for sacrifice. Sacrifice is the main artery of the play.

The play was done for the Portfringe Festival in Portland, Maine in 2012 as a staged reading and received many accolades.  

Now, my friend and colleague, Christopher Davis, and I will be mounting this script as a full staged production in April at Massachusetts College of Art (Kennedy Building 402)  We are excited to bring life to these forgotten shadows of our past and the spirit of Beltane.  The play will be performed April 10th, 11th, and 12th. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to mount this production, we will need your support. The financial costs of renting the theater, mounting staging, and paying for the production of the play. 

Even the donation of a dollar adds up to many when many have pulled together.  Your donation from $1 to $500 (or more ;) can help us bring this play to reality.

* Once you have donated to our campaign $25 or more I will email you to confirm the date of your choice to claim your free ticket(s).

For donations of $25  you get a free ticket

For donations of $50  you ca get two free tickets.

For donations of $100 or more you will get three free tickets and a signed poster by the cast and crew.


Once you have donated, I will email you to secure your tickets to be held at the door in your name on a night of your choosing. PLEASE be sure to leave your name and email address. THANK YOU!

Why is this so important?

Theater is a alive and has the unique ability to create a direct invitation with the audience to partake in it's dialogue.  By supporting the theater, we enable actors and artists alike to share their vision and open the audience up to new ways of thinking and reflecting on the past, and how we may have stayed the same. Has the nature of sacrifice changed? 

We NEED your support

By donating, we ensure that so many artists are able to share their vision. From the actors, the directors, the playwright, to those who would be sitting in the seats experiencing the play with you. Without your help, the arts cannot happen. 

Please join us in mounting a script that has been highly acclaimed, with tremendous artists.

story:
Little Tree Theatre

Hi, we are David and Annalisa, co-founders of Little Tree Theatre. 

Little Tree grew out of talks we had while producing a collaborative piece titled MisShapen, first at the Long Beach Playhouse, and then again when the show was remounted at the Hollywood Fringe Festival.  We both believe that art and storytelling are essential to what defines us as human beings.  Catharsis through story makes us stronger, wiser and more empathetic.  We become curious and imaginative, we become more human.

We realized there are so many incredible designers, performers, directors, writers and producers in our community that are capable of amazing work, but just need the opportunity and support to hone their craft and share it with the world.

Our Mission: Little Tree Theatre strives to create and share art with its community by creating opportunities for emerging artists to explore new work.  Together we grow.

We are now presenting in collaboration with ClownMa dell'Arte our world premiere production The Moon, The Sun & The Empty Space on the Long Beach Playhouse's Studio Stage in March 2015

How You Can Help

See and support our first production The Moon, The Sun & The Empty Space  at the Long Beach Playhouse!  It Performs March 6th-7th at 8pm and March 8th at 2pm.

Tickets are available here!

Donate to our Indiegogo!
Your donation will go towards:

  • Costumes
  • Set Pieces
  • Props
  • Lighting Instruments
  • Makeup Supplies
  • Stage Manager Expenses
  • Marketing and Publicity
  • Rehearsal Materials
  • Programs
  • Postcards
  • Venue Rental
  • Company Operating Expenses
  • Rainy Day Fund

What You Will Receive

By donating to this company you are actively contributing to the creative process, you are making it possible to create and share art with our community, and that is invaluable.  And because we appreciate your support so much, we are offering gifts of gratitude ranging from a social media shout-out, a ticket to the show, or a photo-shoot and even custom made art!

The Impact

We need a strong start to help our company reach its full potential.  We have created this fundraiser in tandem with our production at the Long Beach Playhouse's Collaborative season to give the company the strongest start possible and to share with our audience the type of work that Little Tree has in store for the future.  If we reach our goal we'll be able to establish the company and have a seed fund that we can use to produce future projects!  We want this company to be something that fellow artists in our community can come to with a passionate vision that Little Tree can help them realize.  A place where audiences know they can trust in seeing new and exciting work that speaks to their experiences and senses, and sometimes challenges them with the unfamiliar.
Your belief and support in this dream means the world to us and we plan on paying back that kindness ten-fold by giving our all and creating something we can all be proud of!

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps, but if you are not able to contribute financially don't be discouraged! - You can still offer amazing support! We would be so grateful if you could share our cause with your friends and family through this link: http://igg.me/at/LittleTree

Most important come see our show!  You can find tickets on the Long Beach Playhouse's website here: http://www.lbplayhouse.org/show/moon-sun-empty-space-studio-collaborative-season/

Like and Share posts from our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/LittleTreeTheatre

Follow and Retweet us on Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/Littletreethtr

Tell all your friends about our company and the show, and help spread the word!  If you want to get involved in other ways send us an email at littletreetheatre@gmail.com we look forward to hearing from you!

Thank you for your support!!

story:
Create an Original Cast Album

The creative team of Matt Insley, Jessica Tidd, and Michael Streeter have created a powerful piece of art with a capital "A" in the best sense of that term.  The compelling music, the passionate performance, and Shakespeare's poem need to be captured in this unique creation.  You can trust that your contribution will chronicle a work for posterity.  A broad audience of music, theater, poetry and Shakespeare fans will be indebted to you for preserving this moment for future generations.  Matt Katz will be the critical studio recording artist in the creation of this album.

  • Jessica Tidd is a critically acclaimed actress and singer in Portland, Oregon.  She is a company member at the award winning Post5 Theater.
  • Matt Insley is critically acclaimed as a composer and musician, also based in Portland, and also a Post5 Theater member.
  • Michael Streeter is a Shakespearean actor and teacher with decades of experience.  He is the Artistic Director Emeritus of Portland Actors Ensemble an organization that produces Shakespeare in the Parks in Portland.  He received his MFA in Acting from the University of Southern California.
  • Matt Katz has a BFA in Studio Composition from SUNY Purchase.  He is an award-winning pianist and instructor.  He toured nationally for nearly a decade and has been producing records for eight years.
  • This work of art should not be limited to the temporal brief run it had in the theaters.  Even with a tour, this beautiful piece will not be preserved.
  • A cast album will provide future audiences with an opportunity to appreciate this worthy project.

Are you ready to make a contribution?

We need $2800 to produce this album.

$9000 would be ideal.

There are many production costs in creating an album:

  • Studio rental is a large expense.  The hiring of musicians, an audio technician, engineer, and a production assistant are costs.  Services and fees such as editing, mixing, plate reverbs, I-tune fees, and CD fabrication are all costs associated with this project.
  • With a $20 contribution or more, you will receive an electronic version of the album.
  • With a $40 contribution or more, you will receive a CD.
  • With a $100 contribution or more, you will receive an autographed copy of the CD and autographed photos of the creative team.
  • A $500 contribution or more receives the above plus an autographed poster and program from the original production.
  • A $750 contribution or more will receive the above plus an autographed score of the music.
  • With a $1000 contribution or more, you will receive a personal live performance of the show in the Portland metropolitan area!
  • A contributor that fully funds the $9,000.00 of the project will receive a personal live command performance anywhere in the US!
  • If we don't reach the minimum goal of $2800, the money will go towards the tour of the show.

The Impact

  • Your contribution will make a difference in whether or not audiences will have an opportunity to encounter this unique piece of art.  The world should not be denied the moving experience of listening to this performance.
  • Your contribution will make a difference in the quality and depth of the recording.  The quality of the studio, the instruments, the presence of an isolation booth, and additional musicians all may hinge on your contribution.

Risks & Challenges

A challenge we face in creating this piece is scheduling.  All of these talented artists are in great demand and finding a time when all are available to work together is burdensome.

  • We are determined to make this happen.  It may take some time, patience, and persistence, but we are committed.
  • The plan is to record in February.  If we are not able to make that work, we will continue to circle around until we are all available.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Share on social media!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
On March 14, the sprinkler system in one of our company studios unexpectedly malfunctioned and ran for 40 minutes. Fire trucks rushed to the Hubbard Street Dance Center in response to the alarm, and our building — which houses the company, administrative offices, the Lou Conte Dance Studio, our costume shop, storage and archives — was completely evacuated. While fortunately there was no fire, thousands of gallons of water flooded into a large area of our second floor, damaging Studios B, C, and D. More than 50 classes had to be canceled during the following week, while temporary flooring for Studios B and C was secured and installed. We have been working hard to expedite renovations to get the Hubbard Street Dance Center fully up and running again, but the damage is extensive and significant. However, this could be an opportunity to improve multiple aspects of our facility, beyond repairing those affected by the flood — and that’s where you come in!


Many people are asking...


How Can I Help?

To help get us back to serving thousands of students, artists, and audiences each week, we are asking for your help to rebuild the Hubbard Street Dance Center. Our campaign goal is $25,000, which will cover repairs going beyond what was immediately affected by the flood. Donations in any amount are critical in helping us rebuild the Hubbard Street Dance Center, so we may continue fulfilling our mission to change lives through dance.


Don't You Have Insurance?

Yes! We have been working with our insurance agent to fast-track the process. We are thankful that our insurance will cover some of the immediate damage from the flood, but there are several areas that insurance will not cover. This includes repairing ceiling insulation, replacing carpets and repairing damaged electricity.


Where Will the Money Go?

The money raised by this campaign will not only bring our studios back to full functionality, but also better the facilities that are used by hundreds of students, professionals, and teaching artists each day. With your money we will be able to repair ceiling insulation in two studios, add outlets in three studios, upgrade sound systems in all studios, repair our hydraulic lift, upgrade our faculty lounge, replace carpeting and more!  Take a closer look:


Why Is This Important?

Hubbard Street Dance Chicago has served the Chicago community as a non-profit organization for over 38 years. Your donation to Help Rebuild the Hubbard Street Dance Center will allow us to continue reaching thousands of people across Chicago and beyond. Hubbard Street offers more than 70 public classes each week at the Lou Conte Dance Studio, reaches nearly 100,000 people each year with our performances and programs, gives more than 75 performances each year, collaborates with diverse partner institutions in Chicago and beyond, brings our field-leading Education Programs into more than 30 Chicago Public Schools, offers professional development opportunities to teachers, and serves young dancers with autism and people with Parkinson’s disease through Adaptive Dance Programs.

Your donation will improve the space we use to enrich and transform the lives of hundreds of thousands of people through dance.


I've Donated! Now What?

  1. Outstanding! Your support is greatly appreciated. You will receive an email at the conclusion of the campaign with information on how to claim your perk. 
  2. Share this message with your friends using the hashtag #HubbardStreetFloodRelief or by using the IndieGoGo share tools at the top of this page!


Other Questions?

If you have any questions, please contact Melissa at 312-850-9744 ext. 172 or via email at mplatt@hubbardstreetdance.com. 

You can also support the Studio Repair Fund by mailing a check to: Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Attention: Development, 1147 W. Jackson Blvd. Chicago, IL 60603.


Thank You!

We are excited to make these much-needed repairs and upgrades to the Hubbard Street Dance Center a reality, and we are grateful for your generosity.

story:
THE DRAMATIC'S EXPERIENCE:

“A FIGHT TO THE TOP”

Directed by Dan Martin

Written by Greg L. Glass

Produced by Do Good Dog Productions, LLC

    In the late 1950's and 60's, a sound quietly blew throughout Detroit,Michigan. It was a sound full of BODY and SOUL. The sound seemed to hover over the city. It worked it's way into the very SOUL of the people. Magically, some of the people began to produce SONGS and DANCES from this SOUND. There were well known groups that emerged from the Motor City, with names like The Temptations, The Contours, The Four Tops, The Velvelettes and The Originals.

    What was truly amazing was how quickly young and old became captivated by this soulful music. In a matter of a few months a competition was built which centered around which groups were most soulful, had the better voices, rhythms and songs. The groups became more creative and their talent was on full display. The competition was fierce and almost unrealistic, but like anything else, GOD took over and put his power and spirit in the very group everyone counted out.

    This group, led by their youngest member was called The Dramatics. They were just infants in the business when they experienced their first hit record. Nevertheless, their youth did not stop their fight to the top. They mastered the challenges of surviving in the difficult and tempting music business, and through it all, Ron Banks and The Dramatics triumphed for over three decades. They overcame every trial and tribulation the business could produce, all the while keeping the fans satisfied.

    During the lows of Show Business, one can't always see the upside or benefits of the pursuit. However the benefits can be huge, and they are not just financial. The Dramatic's Experience is a true story of their fight to the top in the tumultuous music business. Their story has been captured in a 3 Act stage play that will detail their their lives, their struggles, highs and lows, all while laced with The Dramatic's great music.

    We are seeking the support of friends, loved ones, fans, and anyone who loves theater, The Dramatics, or just the sound of great soul music. This play is designed to be an epic view of their lives and times. Your pledges will be appreciated, and will go directly towards the production of the play.

    Thank you to the beautiful Miss Ella Joyce for her support and for so eloquently describing our mission to bring this story to life. The writer Greg L. Glass and the Director Dan Martin have teamed up to present this colorful and exciting play, and we would like to thank you in advance for your pledges and contributions.

Please make checks payable to:

Do Good Dog Productions

C/O Trinichia Jordan, Treasurer

PO Box 7643

Long Beach, CA 90807


Willie Ford's Thank You Video                                          https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAcwOcxPmeY      


SAMPLE OF THE PLAY VIDEO

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvOZqGSKTAc    




The Best and Last Interview of The Dramatics      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGL1Ty3BeQU      



"PLEASE GET THE NEW CD BY LJ REYNOLDS" - "GET TO THIS"

http://www.motorcityhits.com/

the challenges of surviving in the difficult and tempting music business, and through
it all, Ron Banks and The Dramatics triumphed for over three decades. They
overcame every trial and tribulation the business could produce, all the while
keeping the fans satisfied.
    During
the lows of Show Business, one can't always see the upside or benefits of the
pursuit. However the benefits can be huge, and they are not just financial. The
Dramatic's Experience is a true story of their fight to the top in the
tumultuous music business. Their story has been captured in a 3 Act stage play
that will detail their their lives, their struggles, highs and lows, all while
laced with The Dramatic's great music.
    We
are seeking the support of friends, loved ones, fans, and anyone who loves
theater, The Dramatics, or just the sound of great soul music. This play is
designed to be an epic view of their lives and times. Your pledges will be
appreciated, and will go directly towards the production of the play.
    Thank
you to the beautiful Miss Ella Joyce for her support and for so eloquently
describing our mission to bring this story to life. The writer Greg
L. Glass and the Director Dan Martin have teamed up to present this
colorful and exciting play, and we would like to thank you in advance for your
pledges and contributions.Please make checks payable to:Do Good Dog ProductionsC/O Trinichia Jordan, TreasurerPO Box 7643
Long Beach, CA 90807Willie Ford's Thank You Video                                          https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAcwOcxPmeY      SAMPLE OF THE PLAY VIDEOhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvOZqGSKTAc    The Best and Last Interview of The Dramatics      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGL1Ty3BeQU      "PLEASE GET THE NEW CD BY LJ REYNOLDS" - "GET TO THIS"http://www.motorcityhits.com/

story:
Short Summary

I'm Victor Richards, actor, poet and published author of 'Poetry Trilogy'.  I cover African and Caribbean History especially about the Windrush stories of our parents arrivals and the first generation born here in the UK through my one man plays and spoken word.



Trip to Barbados

I have been invited to attend the 5th edition of the Caribbean Fine Art Fair (CaFA) -Barbados will be staged in Bridgetown, Barbados from March 11-15, 2015. This exposition will feature over 35 exhibitors showcasing works by artists of Caribbean ancestry. They have created a format with 4 full days of exhibition which will include theatrical performances, spoken word and film screenings on each day of the Fair. I am taking part to present my spoken word with reggae music at the event. 

CaFA website   http://www.cafafair.com/

Trip To Jamaica

Also I have been invited to perform at the International Safeguarding Children‟s Conference.,‘Cocktail Evening, Dance with Entertainment’. This will be held on Saturday 16th May 2015 and will take place at the University of the West Indies, The Mona Visitors‟ Lodge & Conference Centre, 2, Garden Lane, UWI, Mona, Kingston 7.

This will be the first time that One Step Forward Consultancy will be bringing together such an event and will be approaching sponsors. I am presently approaching sponsors to assist me to support this event.

I.S.C.C.   Every child matters in the Caribbean  15th May 2015

www.facebook.com/pages/One-Step-Forward-Consultancy/363488533663091

Asking Your Help and Support

These are two exciting opportunities for me to present my work internationally. 

My work is very important part of British and Caribbean History. My presence as an UK artist at these events in Barbados and Jamaica will be an great opportunity to share my unique work with people there and support the events to help local young artists and children to achieve their goals. 

Your contribution to my campaign will be a significant help for me to reach my dream faster. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need £2000 to cover travel cost and accommodation for both Barbados and Jamaica for 7 nights during the event taking place, also to cover marketing materials to promote my business there to make strong connection with Barbados, Jamaica and other Caribbean islands. 

If you can contribute for my campaign whether it's small or large, I will email you to express my appreciation and keep you informed my progress in the future. If you are big contributors, I will discuss with you what you want me to do for you or your business. 

e.g. your logo on my website, to distribute your business information in Barbados, free voiceover for your business advert/video,  free performance of my play or spoken word at your event ... etc

If you wish to discuss in advance, please contact me by email victor@vjaytheatre.net

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a monetary contribution, but you still want to help, you can.  

I want you to:

• Spread the word to your friends and family. 

• Offer me useful ideas or information for my trip to Barbados and Jamaica

I appreciate any support I can receive from you. Please contact me for more information.  Email: victor@vjaytheatre.net

story:
Hello,

 

My story?

I decided to make a theatre show called Marlene – The Competition
to speak about important issues. I applied to the Arts Council in England for support and was turned down, but I didn’t give up. I fought for a year and step by
step, with a little help from here and there I created and opened the show.  It ran for a week at Tristan Bates Theatre London, in Santa Barbara USA and in Budapest at the Katona Jozsef Theatre with great success.

You may have seen it or heard about it.

I applied again to Arts Council hoping that the work I have already put in will help to get some support from them.

Unfortunately, Arts Council turned me down again and that way my further plans.

I spent all my money on making the show and now has nothing left to invest for touring.

I’d like to bring it back to London for a proper 3 weeks run, because that’s the only way I can get press to review it. Without reviews, it's impossible to get industry attention. And the show will never be performed again.

Based on the positive feedback I had in London, California and Budapest, I’m here now, to ask your support, to be able keep playing my “Marlene” show. I feel it would be wrong to give up now.

 Whatever amount, I am fortunate to receive, will help me to go ahead artistically, introduce my work in UK and create future work.

If you would like to see examples of my work, and get to know me more as an artist visit my website, http://www.evamagyar.com/

 Thank you,

 

Eva Magyar

story:
Breve reseña

Mi nombre es Alejandro Palma y he empezado esta petición a modo de sugerencia por Facebook (La propuesta es que cada contacto de mi cuenta me donara un euro para poder mudarme a Londres) y al ver que varios amigos estaban dispuestos a ayudarme, decidí dar el paso y llevarlo a un gran soporte.

Estudié arte dramático en Tenerife y tengo pensado irme a vivir a Londres el 24 de Septiembre de 2014, con el fin de buscar un futuro prometedor tanto en mi sector como en mi vida personal.

Todo el dinero recaudado irá íntegramente a mi proyecto de empezar una vida en Londres juntos con dos amigos que viajan conmigo. Esto incluye la búsqueda de un piso donde poder vivir, los gastos que me supondrá dicha vivienda, los hostales en los que tendré que quedarme hasta que encuentre un lugar donde vivir, etc. Una vez asentado, podré empezar a buscar castings y demás proyectos artísticos en los que esté interesado y puedan favorecerme en mi territorio.

Lo que necesito y lo que obtienes

Detalles:

  • En principio solo pido un euro por persona, creo que sería más que suficiente para mí y para mi objetivo principal hasta que encuentre dinero. El dinero no se usará para caprichos, solo para costearme todos los gastos hasta que pueda establecerme en Londres.
  • Las recompensas con valores mayores a 3 euros deberán ir al apartado de "Recompensas" y ver qué recompensa tiene derecho a reclamar a cambio de la contribución que haya hecho.

El impacto

Tu contribución hará que mi búsqueda sea menos ardua y más fructífera, todos sabemos que Londres es caro, y no he podido ahorrar lo suficiente como para ir con un colchón económico estable, por lo que tu colaboración me dará estabilidad y además me favorecerá las oportunidades que tenga a la hora de encontrar piso o trabajo.

story:
Our Story

Hi! My name is Evan Crommett and my co producer is Aleah Black. We're a writing/directing/producing team. We're students in our junior year at Bard College in upstate New York. Bard is where we met, and where I major in creative writing, Aleah in theater.

The Play

This campaign aims to raise funds for the play we're writing, Hadeon. The play takes place within a fantastical world, influenced in equal parts by Greek mythology, Shakespearean plays, and the aesthetic of the 50s. This is a world where the gods once existed, but have long been done away with. Through the actions of King Argos, the cunning, immaculate leader of this world, a new god, Hadeon, is born.

Our Needs

In the case of any play, costuming, makeup, hair design, lighting, set construction, sound, technological aspects, and publicity, require a great deal of time, energy, kind, hard-working people, and of course, money. This is all the more the case, however, when the play in question has the aesthetic demands of Hadeon.  All of the people who have agreed to act in, tech, and design Hadeon have agreed to work for free. Because of this, all of the money from the campaign will go to creating the world of the play.

It may sound dramatic to say we're creating a new god and a new world, but that is, in fact, the task at hand. Our actors are already on their way to making our world, and the characters within it believable, but we require assistance in other ways to bring this project to life.

Our goal is to use a lot of found and ecofriendly materials to construct our show. That said, there are specifics that we will need to purchase to successfully capture our aesthetic. For example: sheets of recycled industrial grade plastic, an entire 1950s pastel wardrobe from thrift stores for thirteen people, props including throwing knives, stilts, and a trampoline, sheet metal to construct crowns, and chicken wire, wood, and spackle to create a giant egg from which a god is born.

The Importance

The project is very is important to us for a number of reasons; in addition to the themes of love, and power we've mentioned, the play explores themes too often deemed taboo, such as class, and sexual liberation. The play functions, in many ways, as a parody and investigation of an old cliché: the story of an ingénue striving to kindle a romance with a gallant, ever-elusive male. This play, we feel, is not just a story that can be told, but a story that needs to be told.

I’d also like to point out the astoundingly positive reception, and overall success of Aleah's previous theatrical endeavor, Wolf, a play she wrote, directed, and produced last fall. It was entirely funded through indiegogo.

Your Contribution

Thank you so much for supporting the two of us as student artists. The success of this project will be a step in establishing ourselves in this community. Furthermore, it will promote accessible, beautiful, and sustainable theater created by young artists.  Lastly, please share this page in any way you can! Posting it on Facebook, emailing it to friends, talking to people about the show, sending out carrier pigeons, firing arrows with rolled up scrolls through your friend's windows, whatever you can do to spread the word, please do it! 

Thank you for your contribution!

story:
Senior Showcase

2014 marks the first year that Utah State Theatre will be putting on a showcase of its graduating seniors. Performance dates are April 3rd in Logan and April 5th in Salt Lake City.

  • We are ten actors about to graduate from Utah State University and head into the world of graduate schools and professional theatre and film.
  • We are producing a showcase of scenes, monologues, and songs performed by us and directed by our professors Richie Call and Jason Spelbring.
  • If you help us to reach our goal you will be helping us to make a stellar and memorable impression on industry professionals such as Talent Agents, Casting Directors, and Artistic Directors.

What We Need

Our goal is $2,500, but any amount will help. We are hoping to raise enough money to pay for, or at least defer, the cost of the following necessities:

  • A headshot photographer and makeup artist for ten actors.
  • Printing of headshots.
  • Printing of programs and actors' contact info to be distributed to attendees.
  • Cost of renting a venue.
  • Cost of reception following the showcase.
  • Cost of travel to and from Salt Lake City.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that cash is tight for a lot of people, so if you can't contribute please spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, and other social media outlets.

story:
About the Play

"The Lives We Lead" is about two employees at a diner discussing their relationship during closing. When he expresses a need for change, she must make a choice about love.

The play was written by me, Jessica Lehman, in fall 2013 as part of a playwriting class. It was then performed in March 2014 as part of Quinnipiac University's New Play Festival at the Abingdon Theatre in NYC.

Now the play is part of Manhattan Repertory Theatre's Fall One Act Competition. It will receive four performances in a night with four other shows. Each night, the audience ranks the shows and the play with the most points at the end of the run advances to the finals.

Meet the Cast and Crew

Jessica Lehman (Writer/Director) is thrilled to have her play, "The Lives We Lead," appearing in Manhattan Repertory Theatre's Fall One Act Competition to kick off her new life in NYC. She is a recent graduate of Quinnipiac University with degrees in Theater and Film, Video, and Interactive Media. She had the pleasure of seeing this play performed in Quinnipiac University's New Play Festival at the Abingdon Theatre this past spring where she also directed Count. Jessica is also an actor and most recently spent the summer as an apprentice at the Williamstown Theatre Festival.

Holly Linneman (Woman) is thrilled to be performing in her first official NYC production! She met the awesome Jessica and Deane at Williamstown Theatre Festival, where she performed in Drunk (Jen) and the Williamstown Late-Night Cabaret. Other favorite roles include Babe in Crimes of the Heart (Princeton Summer Theater), Dot in Sunday in the Park With George (Princeton University), and Mrs. Squeamish in The Country Wife (LAMDA). Holly is a recent graduate of Princeton University, where she studied English and Theater.

Deane Sullivan (Man) is a recent graduate from the University of Southern California's School of Drama. A native Bostonian, he is very happy to be part of this production. He loves New York, but his loyalties will forever remain true with the Red Sox.

Why We Need You

Manhattan Repertory Theatre provides the performance space, lights, sound, and set pieces for the production. Everything else, we're on our own. As a recent college grad who just moved to NYC, funding this production is a large expense. Your donations will go toward:

  • Rehearsal Space: $800 -- Putting up a play requires a lot of rehearsal and those rehearsals require a space. In addition, the space needs to be large enough to fit or match the dimensions of the stage we will be performing on. This is our largest cost.
  • Programs: $300 -- We must provide all the copies of the program for our audiences at each performance.
  • Participation Fee: $150 -- In order to be part of the festival, we had to pay Manhattan Repertory Theatre a $150 participation fee that goes to putting on the shows.
  • Props and Costumes: $100 -- Most of the props and costumes will come from things we already have but some of the items will need to be bought. These items are important for helping to create the world of the play and improve your audience experience.
  • Indiegogo's Fees: $60-$135 -- Depending on whether or not we meet our goal, Indiegogo will take either 4% or 9% of what we raise, meaning we need to raise a little extra to make sure our productions costs are covered.
  • The rest of the money will go to things like shipping fees for the rewards and any other costs that pop up. If we advance to the finals, it will cover additional rehearsal space rentals. In the event that we raise more money than we need to cover our expenses, it will be evenly divided as stipends for the cast and crew so they can do what they love and get paid.
  • This is a competition we are part of so if we win in the finals, we will receive $1000. This is the only way we receive any money from Manhattan Repertory Theatre. In the event that we win, the money will first go to covering any remaining costs. Anything left over will be evenly divided as stipends for the cast and crew so they can do what they love and get paid.
We would greatly appreciate your support and, in return, we have some exciting rewards for you! You can see the full list to the right, but some highlights include:

  • Cast and Crew Provided Rewards -- a story from Jessica, a spicy song from Holly, and a picnic with Deane!
  • Everyone who donates $5 or more will receive a thank you from the cast and crew in a thank you video we will make just for our donors!
  • If you fund our full amount, not only do you get all the previous rewards, but we will treat you to some drinks after the show!
  • Check out the rest of the great rewards you can receive for supporting us in our theatrical endeavors!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are still other ways you can help and support us! Please share this link with your friends and encourage them to donate to our production.

If you're in the NYC area, come to the show September 17-20 @ 6:30pm! Tickets are $20. Reservations can be made ahead of time by emailing mrtreserve@gmail.com.

Thank you for your support!

Rehearsal Space: $800 -- Putting up a play requires a lot of rehearsal and those rehearsals require a space. In addition, the space needs to be large enough to fit or match the dimensions of the stage we will be performing on. This is our largest cost.
Programs: $300 -- We must provide all the copies of the program for our audiences at each performance.
Participation Fee: $150 -- In order to be part of the festival, we had to pay Manhattan Repertory Theatre a $150 participation fee that goes to putting on the shows.
Props and Costumes: $100 -- Most of the props and costumes will come from things we already have but some of the items will need to be bought. These items are important for helping to create the world of the play and improve your audience experience.
Indiegogo's Fees: $60-$135 -- Depending on whether or not we meet our goal, Indiegogo will take either 4% or 9% of what we raise, meaning we need to raise a little extra to make sure our productions costs are covered.
The rest of the money will go to things like shipping fees for the rewards and any other costs that pop up. If we advance to the finals, it will cover additional rehearsal space rentals. In the event that we raise more money than we need to cover our expenses, it will be evenly divided as stipends for the cast and crew so they can do what they love and get paid.
This is a competition we are part of so if we win in the finals, we will receive $1000. This is the only way we receive any money from Manhattan Repertory Theatre. In the event that we win, the money will first go to covering any remaining costs. Anything left over will be evenly divided as stipends for the cast and crew so they can do what they love and get paid.

We would greatly appreciate your support and, in return, we have some exciting rewards for you! You can see the full list to the right, but some highlights include:


Cast and Crew Provided Rewards -- a story from Jessica, a spicy song from Holly, and a picnic with Deane!
Everyone who donates $5 or more will receive a thank you from the cast and crew in a thank you video we will make just for our donors!
If you fund our full amount, not only do you get all the previous rewards, but we will treat you to some drinks after the show!
Check out the rest of the great rewards you can receive for supporting us in our theatrical endeavors!


Other Ways You Can Help
 If you can't donate, there are still other ways you can help and support us! Please share this link with your friends and encourage them to donate to our production.
If you're in the NYC area, come to the show September 17-20 @ 6:30pm! Tickets are $20. Reservations can be made ahead of time by emailing mrtreserve@gmail.com.
Thank you for your support!

story:
Creativity is Beautiful!

I am in love with creativity. We hear about so much negativity that we forget to enjoy the beauty around us. Everything around us has a story and I love bringing stories to life. In school, I was the child that was full of imagination. I went on to college and I studied journalism and television production. 

I have written and directed several stage play productions, with the most recent production, Meet the New First Lady, including the talented Willie Taylor of Day 26 and recording artst Jerome Wiggins of the Tia and Tamera Show.  I want to do more. I want to bring to Movies with a message, productions with a purpose. 

I started this campaign because no man is an island. I cannot do this alone but with your help I can bring my vision to life and make some actor's dream a reality. I would love to tour cities around the country and bring my productions to a city near you. I am asking for your help in making this possible. We need to cover travel expenses and production costs and your contribution can help us accomplish that. I know there are many out there that love the arts as much as I do, and I am asking that you help me bring the arts to cities beyond Los Angeles and New York. 

Please join me on this journey and let's bring quality back onto our television screens, our movies screens and our stages.Your contribution would be greatly appreciated.

To Get Started

To get started we need to raise $5000.00 to cover the following costs:

  • Venue
  • Travel expenses for a cast
  • Production costs for staging 

How You Can Help

  • With your contribution we would be able to reach areas that have been overlooked when it comes to performing arts. Some of the most talented individuals of our time and past time have come from small towns and it would be great if we could give these talented individuals the opportunities to share their great talents with the world.
  • To date, one of my most successful shows happened in a town near Dallas, called Garland. People want to come out and enjoy a stage play and they want it in their communities and I want to bring that to them. 
  • My parents are from small towns and I have family members living in towns that seek things to do on the weekend but they're limited because no one brings their shows to them. They deserve the enjoyment of seeing an entertaining show in their community. Everyone should be afforded that opportunity. The actors there should also have a chance to do what they love in the company of their family and friends and they should be given those same opportunities given to those in well known entertainment capitals.  

I have risked every dime I have and will continue to do so because I believe the performing arts can also uplift and inspire communities.


  • I was driving through Detroit and I was looking at the vacant buildings and my first thought was production companies should come shoot some movies here. A stage play would be great here to bring out the community and unite them as one. 
  • I have put every dime I had into my productions. With my last production for three months straight, I took every paycheck I received and put into the cost of producing that show. It was a sacrifice but it paid off. The actors took so much pride in their work, that the audience was amazed that this talent came from their own "backyard".
  • For future shows I would love to create a budget so that every expense is addressed from the start and ticket prices are kept at a comfortable rate for our attendees.  Ultimately I would love to go to some under privileged communities and do free shows. 

I Need Your Help

I know that some of you may not be able to contribute financially and that is okay. You can still help us by spreading the word, informing us of others that want to donate their time and service to our events, sharing our campaign on social media sights and having actors and talent contact us from your area that want an opportunity as well. 

We thank you in advance for whatever contribution you can make.

story:
The Chekhov Club

In 2014, the Barn Arts Collective started Chekhov Club - a community organization on Mount Desert Island in Maine that brings people together to read, discuss, and perform the work of Anton Chekhov.  Since then, Chekhov Club has met regularly and grown to include film projects, public events, and full productions of Chekhov's work.  This year, Barn Arts will launch the first ever Chekhov Festival.

 

The Chekhov Festival

The Barn Arts Chekhov Festival will be a celebration of the author's work that will share the spirit and camaraderie of Chekhov Club with the community through a major event this fall.  The lineup includes three full productions from artists based in Maine and New York, a festival of short films adapted from Chekhov short stories, and a public event at the Southwest Harbor Public Library inviting everyone to take part in Chekhov Club.

 

The Budget

Funds raised through this campaign will go towards the cost of travel and stipends for artists coming to perform in Maine.  Rehearsal and performance space, food, and housing have already been donated by local supporters and Chekhov Club needs to raise money to bring visiting artists to Mount Desert Island.

You can be a part of the success of the first ever Chekhov Festival by pledging your support for Chekhov Club as we celebrate Chekhov and bring people together at the end of the month.  Make a donation, help us spread the word, and come see a show - Chekhov Club is growing and we want you to be a part of it.

You can be a part of the success of the first ever Chekhov Festival by pledging your support for Chekhov Club as we celebrate Chekhov and bring people together at the end of the month.  Make a donation, help us spread the word, and come see a show - Chekhov Club is growing and we want you to be a part of it.

story:
Macbeth is Shakespeare's hellish, blood-soaked journey through the dark underworld of ambition, supernatural duplicity, and brutal carnage.

What happens when our institutions break down? Where do we turn when those we believed would protect us turn violent? How should we respond when our leaders are obviously unqualified to lead? What will break the destructive cycles we’re locked in? Will we even realize when we've passed the point of no return? Join our search for the answers.

In this not so distant future following a devastating social and economic collapse, those who have spent their whole lives in comfort and security must suddenly cope with war in the streets. Are our characters breaking free from the chains of the past? Or are they doomed to repeat it?

Opening Friday, October 13th, this raw production comes to vivid life, staged in the round at the Sound/Stage theatre on Western Avenue in Hollywood.

But now, we want to invite you to be a part of our team to realize this savage, primal, seductive story - just in time for Halloween.

So go ahead, click the pledge button and be an instrumental force in creating this production. 

Macbeth @ Studio/Stage
520 N. Western Ave.
Hollywood, CA

Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays:
Friday, October 13th – Saturday, November 4, 2017
8:00pm

Please note: Due to the strong sexual content in this production parental discretion is advised for those younger than 17; persons younger than 10 years of age will not be permitted.

 

Naturally, you want to know where this partnership is going to take us. We want you to know too. In combination with your support, this project is a labor of love and is being supported with additional as well as personal means: 

 

We believe every little bit helps. Please consider sharing our project with your friends, family, and school via all kinds of social media channels. You can find us on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram @hailmacbeth2017 or here: 

https://facebook.com/hailmacbeth2017
https://twitter.com/hailmacbeth2017
https://instagram.com/hailmacbeth2017

What's more amazing than our awesome Macbeth swag? Below you will find renderings for our backer rewards. All of these are limited in quantity and available only to you, our awesome backers!

First up, our awesome Macbeth printsigned with the 'bloody' handprints of our spectacular cast!

Next up are our custom shot glasses, which come full! When you arrive at our show, you'll be given your shot glass along with your choice of beverage (many of which will only be available to our 21+ backers).

      

 

 

 

 

 

 

Third up are these one-of-a-kind hand-painted custom sneakers made for you by designer Matt Hill.

*Artist renderings. Final art will vary.

First and foremost, thank you to everyone who has helped us to get this far! We reached 100% within 17 days, which is thrilling! Also thrilling is that we have a few stretch goals! Stretch goals are things we would like to do with the show, but cannot under our standard budget. However, if our fundraising manages to hit any benchmarks, we will unlock them. Unlocking a stretch goal means added elements in the show and added rewards for our backers!

STRETCH GOAL #1 - PROJECTIONS! If we raise an additional $1,500, we will add an integrated video element into the show. These will be designed by Ovation Award-winning video designer Matt Hill! These extra funds will cover rental cost of the equipment and software necessary.

Below are some sample of Matt's award-winning work on "Man Covets Bird" at 24th Street Theatre.

STRETCH GOAL #2 - HALLOWEEN PERFORMANCE! If we raise another $1000 we will be able to produce an exclusive Halloween midnight showing of Macbeth! We of course will have tricks and treats of all sorts. These extra funds will cover the cost of running this show and the extra treats and beverages.

 

STRETCH GOAL #3 - SPECIAL EFFECTS! If we raise another $750, for a total of $9,250 or more, we will be adding SPECIAL EFFECTS to the production. This means blood and smoke, people!

 

To create this one of a kind experience, we’ve brought together a team of top-notch theater artists from the Los Angeles area. Here’s a little bit about us!
 

CURTIS KRICK (Director) is a director/writer/producer for both both stage and screen. Most recent stage credits include the original one-man show Dramatis Personae at the Hollywood Fringe Festival; Paula Vogel's Desdemona, a Play About a Handkerchief for the Weird Sisters in Atlanta, GA; and Twelfth Night at the University of LaVerne. Last summer he presented a staged reading with his writing partner Sean Dillon of their new musical Fool's Gold, an adaptation of Playboy of the Western World set in the Klondike gold rush. For television Curtis was an Associate Producer on The Flash, Supergirl, and DC's Legends of Tomorrow. He has worked on the visual effects for several Bad Robot series including Fringe, Almost Human (Emmy nomination), and Believe.  Currently he's VFX Co-Supervisor on Syfy's The Magicians going into its third season. Curtis co-produced the creature feature The Craving, and co-directed the award-winning mockumentary Almost Blue.

 

DAWN ALDEN (Producer/Lady Macbeth) is a mover, a shaker and a maker. She holds an MFA in Acting, and has over 25 years experience in that, stage combat, and new play development. She eats Shakespeare with a spoon and a bib. She founded and ran an all-female theatre company in Chicago (Babes With Blades), and now acts and runs a film production company in LA (Vicarious Films). She is dedicated to creating work by and about women, for everyone. www.dawnalden.com www.vicariousfilms.com

 


MATTHEW G. HILL (Producer/Scenic Designer) is an award-winning, multi-media, multi-disciplinary artist. From stage to screen to the printed page, Matt is a storyteller by trade and by heart. He believes in the power of story and hopes to use it to inspire. As a theatre artist, Matt has won an Ovation Award, a StageRaw Award, and an LA Weekly Award. Matt has served as an Artist-in-Residence at the National Theatre of Croatia, the Getty Villa, and the Annenberg Beach House. He is currently the associate artistic director of the Rogue Artists Ensemble. Recent career highlights include: co-directing the feature film Burning at Both Ends, designing Maximus Musicus at the Walt Disney Concert Hall, production design for the feature film No Postage Necessary, directing Hamlet for Inner Circle Theatre, and co-designing puppets for Kayne West's Yeezus tour.

 

MONA LUTFI (Producer/Lady Macduff) is a theatre artist, world traveler and lover of language. Since completing her theatre degree from the University of La Verne, where she performed in Measure for Measure, Copenhagen, and The Dog’s Will, she has been exploring the world focusing on the power of language in performance and everyday life. As a theatre artist she has studied at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts and the Art of Acting Studio.

 

 

BO POWELL (Producer/Assistant Director) is a twenty-four-year-old Los Angeles based theatre director and producer. A member of Sacred Fools Theater Company for four years, he graduated from the University of La Verne with a BA in theatre with an emphasis in directing. He has produced and/or directed a play at the Hollywood Fringe Festival for the last three years and has been producing independent works since 2015. Most recently he directed and produced Orange Mango Cabaret for the Fringe Festival and was the associate producer for the 40th anniversary revival of The Sirens of Titan by Kurt Vonnegut adapted by Stuart Gordon at Sacred Fools. bojamespowell.com

 

ALEXIS NICOLE ROBLES (Stage Manager) is a freelance Stage Manager based out of the Los Angeles area. An alumni of the University of La Verne, Alexis has worked with companies such as Rogue Artists Ensemble, Segerstrom Center for the Performing Arts, Mainstreet Theatre Company, and McCoy Rigby Entertainment, and many others. Alexis is currently pursuing her California teaching credential to foster her love for education and History.

 

 

STEPHANIE WILLIS (Assistant Stage Manager/Prop Mistress) received a Bachelor of Arts in Film and Theater from Dartmouth College, then obtained a Master of Fine Arts from the School of Cinematic Arts at the University of Southern California. While at USC she won a prestigious Annenberg Fellowship which helped fund her award-winning short film, This Is Who We Are. Stephanie continues to write and direct and has also developed a burgeoning career as an assistant editor in television. Her credits include Golden Globe and Emmy nominated series such as Bloodline, Fringe, and Person of Interest.

 

SARA HADDADIN (Technical Director) is a recent theatre arts graduate of the University of La Verne. She has worked on productions such as Cloud 9 at Antaeus, and Hamlet at Inner Circle Theater. During the school year she is the technical director at the Archer School for Girls, and Mission Viejo High School, and in the summer the tour manager for Shakespeare by the Sea.

story:
Short Summary

Hello!

My name is Avinoam Silverman.  I am a former National Ballet of Canada soloist and presently a freelance choreographer and ballet teacher.    I'm very excited to tell you about two new dance creations on which we are working entitled Anvil 18 and Shedding Eve.  These works will compose  a full dance evening program that will take place in Summer 2017 at the Dancemakers Center for Creation in Toronto.    

Anvil 18 is a 30 minute piece for 8 dancers.  This work can be viewed as especially meaningful since it takes an intimate look at the ballet world's emotional impact on its dancers.  The dancers and I are exploring different layers that construct the ballet world: dogmaticism; discipline; rigour; competition; beauty; passion; comradery; and humor.    We are digging  deeper into the way dancers feel inside the ballet world and giving expression to the range of feelings they experience such as frustration, joy, anger, sadness, helplessness, despair and excitement.  As I myself am a former ballet dancer, the critical aspects of the way this work tackles this complex subject stems from the deep respect I hold for the artistry and creativity of this art form. 

We are using a wide range of movement vocabulary ranging from classical and neo classical to contemporary and more theatrical and thereby creating a unique world of exploration around our theme -  the inner world of dancers and the tension between the free expression of movement and dictated, restricted expressions of it.   We are striving to take ballet into uncharted territory and giving it a fresh twist which I think is very exciting. 

Shedding Eve is a ten minute  solo work danced by Amy Hampton which is loosely based on  the story of Adam and Eve. The work examines our relationship to traditions and how we choose to move forward with our own lives making our own decisions.    The work looks at different aspects of "Shedding".  Just as a snake sheds its skin we are shedding different aspects of ourselves such as old political, religious, social beliefs and, our ever-changing physical body.  We are constantly   asking questions,  growing, learning and finding our own way.  In this solo work we are expressing  these processes and struggles.    The movement is contemporary and theatrical and we are using pieces of music that are very different from one  another to create a sharp changing of mood as an expression of our changing ideas.    This work is in a sense a journey towards our truth and how we decide to live our life free of ideas that no longer resonate with us.      

With your support you will help us bring these new works on to the stage and ultimately share it with you and our audience. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution will go directly to:

Dancer fees -  $5000 

Outside Eye - $525

Studio Rental for rehearsals - $525

Theatre and Crew Rental -  $1264 (One Tech and 2 performances)

Stage Manager/Lighting Designer - $1000

Costumes and Set - $1000

Marketing - $436

Videographer - $250

We have some great perks for you! Including tickets for the show, sitting in for one of our rehearsals with a Q & A, a private ballet class and more... 

 

The Impact

In the spring of 2015 I  used Indigogo in order to fund my first dance film titled Diversion. Our campaign was successful thanks to the generosity of all our backers. We truly couldn't have done it without them.  All our hard work paid off and we were able to complete our project with all expenses covered.  Now the dance film exists and we can share it with everyone.  It also was accepted into several film festivals. Here is the link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poiiapWKc8E 

This time around we are preparing a live evening for the stage.   I wanted this evening to have a common thread connecting the two works though one is a solo and the other a group piece. Therefore both works are looking at our traditions and how we choose to relate to them.   I believe it is important to take an honest and critical look at our traditions.  These works offer an opportunity to look deeper into these questions in an artistic and creative way. It hopefully will lend a fresh perspective on how we can learn from the past without fear of venturing out to new paths.   Your help will bring to life an exciting evening of dance.

We would be most grateful for your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help us out monetarily,  your spreading the word about our campaign using the indigogo share tools will be much appreciated!

Thank You for visiting our campaign.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello!
My name is Avinoam Silverman.  I am a former National Ballet of Canada soloist and presently a freelance choreographer and ballet teacher.    I'm very excited to tell you about two new dance creations on which we are working entitled Anvil 18 and Shedding Eve.  These works will compose  a full dance evening program that will take place in Summer 2017 at the Dancemakers Center for Creation in Toronto.    
Anvil 18 is a 30 minute piece for 8 dancers.  This work can be viewed as especially meaningful since it takes an intimate look at the ballet world's emotional impact on its dancers.  The dancers and I are exploring different layers that construct the ballet world: dogmaticism; discipline; rigour; competition; beauty; passion; comradery; and humor.    We are digging  deeper into the way dancers feel inside the ballet world and giving expression to the range of feelings they experience such as frustration, joy, anger, sadness, helplessness, despair and excitement.  As I myself am a former ballet dancer, the critical aspects of the way this work tackles this complex subject stems from the deep respect I hold for the artistry and creativity of this art form. 
We are using a wide range of movement vocabulary ranging from classical and neo classical to contemporary and more theatrical and thereby creating a unique world of exploration around our theme -  the inner world of dancers and the tension between the free expression of movement and dictated, restricted expressions of it.   We are striving to take ballet into uncharted territory and giving it a fresh twist which I think is very exciting.

Thank You for visiting our campaign.

story:
With opening up a new studio come quite a few costs. So, to help us help YOU become the strongest and happiest aerialist you can be, we’re reaching out and humbly asking for your help to make this dream come true for ALL of us, you included!

We appreciate any support you can offer!

We’ve set up a few ideas here, or....name your price!!! Name an amount, and let us know what you’d like in return, or if there’s something specific you’d like to sponsor at the Lab. We’re open to bartering!

What We Need & What You Get

Right now, we have the basics we need to get The Lab functioning, but in order to fully open our classes, we need to expand the number of apparatus we have hanging. We want our students to excel at a rate that is determined by their own learning pace and not be limited by equipment numbers. 

This is where YOU can help us by sponsoring the purchase of some high-flying props :)

We are INCREDIBLY grateful to Camp Augusta for renting us their crash mats for the winter, and eventually we will need more of our own.  

Smaller donations will be pooled to assist us with the development costs of our first collaborative production with Del Corazon this winter! 

The Impact

There is a limited offering and exposure to a wide variety of the aerial arts in both Nevada County and the Sacramento region in general. For both children and adults, learning the aerial arts can be a valuable way to develop a new relationship with your body and mind - to learn agility, to gain strength, to explore flexibility, to poke at our fears, and to increase confidence in ourselves.

At The Aerial Lab, we focus attention on the science behind movement. We want our students and fellow collaborators to have access to tools that encourage safe play, artistic development and a thorough understanding of physics and how the body moves in spacial suspension.

This way of approaching Aerial and Circus is a new movement, and we have connected to many aerialists in our industry in order to collaborate on this new way of thinking in the aerial world. We want to share it with you!

Risks & Challenges

As  with all new businesses, we proceed with great optimism, grand designs, and a healthy dose of well-informed market research. We have been working in this industry for a cumulative total of 20 years, between us we hold two business degrees and believe we have a recipe for solid instruction, industry advancement and artistic development. We hope to construct the framework for a local community that loves to play in the air with us, and provide wondrous and professional performances, locally and further afield.

Bringing this skillful offering to a small-ish county will certainly be more of a challenge than starting this business in a large city. However, Nevada County is progressive in the art world, and we are already connected to many aerialists who are seeking a training space. The only way is up!

Aerial Yoga has been growing in the past 5 years, but as yet there is no space offering classes in the Nevada County area. Since we have an abundance of yoga-lovers, we are offering a new way to enhance their practice or transition into the air.

To support our class offerings, we will also be renting out The Lab studio to other ground-based instructors of yoga, dance, fitness and acro disciplines.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask us for business cards or flyers - if you can help us to distribute these to high-traffic areas, we would be delighted
  • Share our fundraiser details on Facebook
  • Assist us at our fundraiser on August 28th by offering to BBQ some goodies for us, bake some cakes, or sell raffle tickets as we give tours and show off our new studio!
  • Come and give us a hand in the studio with building the new floor, painting the walls and putting up the rigging gear

Thank you dearly. It takes a village!!!

story:
Who are we?

Cave Painting Theater Company was founded in 2012 by Gwen Kelly-Masterton and Heidi Mullins Lemieux as Anam Gan Ainm Theater; our name changed in 2013 to honor humanity's oldest form of recorded storytelling. Our mission is to explore the human experience and promote honesty and empathy in the human community through timeless stories and mind-expanding language, with a growing focus on gender-bent and racially inclusive casting. Now in our third season, previous productions have included The Player Queen, Andromache, The Dark Is Light Enough, and As You Like It. We tend to move around a lot, but The Tragedy Of Lear will take place on the West Stage of the Raven Theatre Complex in Chicago's Rogers Park neighborhood. You can check them out at www.raventheatre.com, and you can learn more about us at www.cavepaintingtheater.com. (Campaign video by Adam Stein.)

What's this “Tragedy of Lear” thing then, and don't we mean“King Lear”?

Sort of! The Tragedy of Lear is a completely gender-swapped adaptation of Shakespeare's King Lear, starring Elizabeth Kelly (The Dark is Light Enough, As You Like It) as Queen Lear. It's a story of children and parents: three brothers who can't agree on how to care for their increasingly confused and irascible mother (and her kingdom) as she descends into dementia; and two sisters, one the embarrassing result of a teen pregnancy and the other the adored child of a legal marriage, locked in a lifelong battle for their inheritance and their mother's love. The Tragedy Of Lear,, which will run February 12-21 2015, is being directed by CPTC Artistic Director Gwen Kelly-Masterton, and will feature returning CPTC actors Gabriel Howard, Jesse Hutson, and Helen Young as well as many exciting new faces.

Why tell this story?

The best tragedies, in our opinion, a) have humor in them and b) let the audience leave wiser than they arrived, whether they see a cautionary tale or gain insight into a “bad” person's emotional journey. Lear is a truly great tragedy; along with the exciting effects of gender-swapping a well-known classic tragedy, which we talk about in the video, our production will explore on a wide range of important topics: sibling rivalry, a marriage disrupted by the internal dynamics of one spouse's family of origin, an individual's “personal” choice heavily impacting others (whether it's their family or an entire country), and the effects of aging and dementia on both its sufferers and their loved ones. We're willing to bet that anyone reading this has been affected by at least one of these issues at some point in their lives, and we hope that by the time the lights fade on our final performance, audience and company alike will understand them differently than before.

Where's the money going?

Good question! Your gifts will help us bring you this important piece of theater. Here's a breakdown:

Initial Goal: $1,800

This will cover our rent for eight performances at a beautiful black-box in a wonderful, easy-to-find theater with a parking lot and a lobby full of comfy chairs for our audience to enjoy, as well as an ingenious (and beautifully painted) convertible set designed by Zoe Mikel-Stites and Elena Amesbury.

Stretch Goal #1: $1,935+

This will allow our inestimable costumer, Katie Cravens, to buy some clothing and masks, rather than just raiding her own (admittedly comprehensive) closet, to create a cohesive look for the play and help the audience remember who everyone is.

Stretch Goal #2: $2,160+

Super Exciting Goal: This will allow us to rent some BROADSWORDS! Lear has a fair amount of violence-- knock-down drag-out brawling between Kent (Helen Young, Andromache) and Oswald (Carolyn Biery), the famous maiming of Gloucester (Sandra Howard), and sundry other duels, attempted muggings, and domestic disputes as well as an epic battle for the fate of a kingdom. Not all of his violence involves swords, but it will all be choreographed by the wonderful Gabriel Howard (The Dark Is Light Enough, As You Like It), and we would love to give the cast some weapons worthy of their talents and his... because in Shakespeare (and life?) some disputes can only be settled with a large, pointy broadsword (used in a safe and theatrically effective manner, of course.)


Stretch Goal #3: $2,300+

This will cover all our production costs, and help us explore further avenues in publicity and planning for future seasons.

And-- last but not least-- your gift gives us the ability for us to continue operating on a shares system. Because CPTC's productions are entirely funded by donations, we can divide all the money we receive from ticket sales between the actors, artists and crew involved with the show. None of us are in it to get rich, obviously, or we'd probably be starving in Hollywood (where it's warm) instead of here, but we firmly believe art is worth money and artists should be paid. Help us make that happen!

What do I do now?

Get involved-- donate! Every bit helps. Give early. Give often! And share, share, share. Tell your friends, tell your enemies, tell those people on the Social Media that you probably know from your old job or something. With your help, we can make this happen. Also, of course, we have some perks for our backers! Look to your right. There they are. (You may notice there are fewer material-object-type perks than for previous campaigns-- that's because we humans all probably have too much stuff, our director was never great at mailing them in a timely fashion, and we decided to try forgoing most of them this time and see how you responded. However, if you really want a physical memento, just contact us and ask! We're happy to make and send them on special request.)

Thank you, with all our hearts, for your gift. And see you at the show!

story:
Our Story

"It's Good 2 be Crazy," by intriguing young Los Angeles playwright Joanclair Richter, is having its world premiere at the Hudson Guild on Theater Row in Hollywood on July  8, 2011 for 6 weeks. The birth of this play and the launch of this new writing talent is a very exciting process!

 

 

About The Play

A Gen-Y coupleʼs love is tested when a young woman follows her dream of becoming a successful recording artist.  Little does she know the lengths she will go to for success, and her boyfriend isnʼt too happy about it either.

 

“It’s Good 2 be Crazy” centers on relationships, the creative process and ambition in the 20-something generation.

 

Merryl lives in a white-walled, one bedroom, Hollywood apartment with her boyfriend of 5 years, Joel. Her dream is to be a singer-songwriter and when she loses her part-time job, she has no excuse for not devoting herself full-time to making that demo album – right? When the months drag on with no tangible results, who can blame Joel for wanting to see some progress - right?  And when Doug, the successful music industry executive and family friend, who still harbors a schoolboy crush on Merryl, agrees to listen to Merryl’s demo - it is solely for its artistic merit - right?  If only it were that simple.

 

Critically recognized, “It’s Good 2 be Crazy” is a finalist in the Eventide Arts Competition and for the Kaplan Prize in Chatham, MA.

 


Where We Are
Pre-production is well under way and we are thrilled to have theatre Director, Lynne Moses (“Paging Dr. Chutzpah”), attached as director; Kurt Swanson of SST fame, as our Executive Producer, and Rosemary Marks, better known for her film producing achievements (“Thirteen” etc.), as our Producer.  The talented and Ovation award-nominated Lindsay Seim plays the lead, "Merryl."  Playing "Joel," is Nick Warnock, instantly recognizable from his many appearances in television series, including a stint as a contestant on “The Apprentice.”  The fabulous Max Decker plays "Doug," the superb Sara Sanderson is our understudy for Merryl and the versatile Cuyle Carvin for both Joel and Doug.

 

Others are also already on board to provide their expertise, including Mandy Brown (graphic design), Hilary White (Director of Interactive Public Relations), and Tim Meehan as our swing production assistant.  Casting director Pam Gilles did an amazing job helping us cast our female lead and male supporting actor, together with our understudies. 

 

Crew hiring is also gathering speed, with our stage manager, lighting designer and set designer, among others, to be named shortly.  

 

We have raised part of our budget, but now we need your help to provide the balance of the funding so we can open the show on July 8th!

 


What We Need

A staged reading of the play inspired one attendee to give a donation to help make our dream a reality and then another round of fundraising brought us closer to our goal.  Now we’re on the home stretch and just need a final $6,000 to cover our costs.

 

As this is a joint venture between Strictly Stages and SST Productions (a 501(c)3 non profit organization), all contributions are tax deductible.

 

 

How Your Money Will Be Spent

 

$10 can buy a costume element at a thrift store;

 

$25 rents a truck for a day to pick up, deliver and load in our set furniture;

 

$50 will pay our stage manager for one night – the curtain can’t go up without this vital person, who oversees and runs everything from lighting to sound to making sure the actors are on time;

 

$100 takes care of our music recording needs – after all, Merryl is a recording artist;

 

$200 gets our posters and postcards printed;

 

$500 pays for 40 hours of rehearsal space; and

 

$1,000 designs and builds our set!

 

These are only a few examples of our expenditure and, as theater lovers, we are inviting you to help bring this play off the page and onto the stage.

 

Your contributions will make this world premiere production of “It’s Good 2 be Crazy” possible. We are begging, borrowing (but not stealing!) to bring this theatrical production to life but can’t do it without you. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to making a financial contribution, you can help in other ways too!

 

1.      Expand your involvement – tell your friends, family and other theatre lovers what you’ve done and invite them to join us too!

 

2.      Donate your talents – we have a variety of needs that might line up with your skills. Furniture store-owner in Los Angeles?   We need to furnish Merryl and Joel’s apartment!  You get the idea.  Let us know if you can help us trim our budget by contributing goods and/or services.

About The
Play 
A Gen-Y coupleʼs love is tested when a young woman follows her
dream of becoming a successful recording artist.  Little does she know the lengths she will go to for success,
and her boyfriend isnʼt too happy about it either.
 
“It’s Good 2 be Crazy”
centers on relationships, the creative process and ambition in the 20-something
generation. 
 
Merryl lives in a white-walled, one bedroom, Hollywood apartment
with her boyfriend of 5 years, Joel. Her dream is to be a singer-songwriter and
when she loses her part-time job, she has no excuse for not devoting
herself full-time to making that demo album – right? When the months drag on with no tangible results, who can
blame Joel for wanting to see some progress - right?  And when Doug, the successful music industry executive and
family friend, who still harbors a schoolboy crush on Merryl, agrees to listen
to Merryl’s demo - it is solely for its artistic merit - right?  If only it were that simple.
 
Critically recognized, “It’s Good 2 be Crazy” is a finalist in the
Eventide Arts Competition and for the Kaplan Prize in Chatham, MA.
 
Where
We ArePre-production is well under way and we are thrilled to have
theatre Director, Lynne Moses (“Paging Dr. Chutzpah”), attached as director;
Kurt Swanson of SST fame, as our Executive Producer, and Rosemary Marks, better
known for her film producing achievements (“Thirteen” etc.), as our
Producer.  The talented and Ovation award-nominated Lindsay Seim plays the lead, "Merryl."  Playing
"Joel," is Nick Warnock, instantly recognizable from his many
appearances in television series, including a stint as a contestant on “The
Apprentice.”  The fabulous Max
Decker plays "Doug," the superb Sara Sanderson is our understudy for Merryl and the versatile Cuyle Carvin for both Joel and Doug. 
 
Others are also already on
board to provide their expertise, including Mandy Brown (graphic design),
Hilary White (Director of Interactive Public Relations), and Tim Meehan as our
swing production assistant.  Casting director Pam Gilles did an amazing
job helping us cast our female lead and male supporting actor, together with
our understudies.  
 
Crew hiring is also
gathering speed, with our stage manager, lighting designer and set designer,
among others, to be named shortly.  
 
We have raised part of
our budget, but now we need your help to provide the balance of the funding so
we can open the show on July 8th!
 
What
We Need 
A staged reading of the
play inspired one attendee to give a donation to help make our dream a reality
and then another round of fundraising brought us closer to our goal.  Now we’re on the home stretch and just
need a final $6,000 to cover our costs. 
 
As this is a joint
venture between Strictly Stages and SST Productions (a 501(c)3 non profit
organization), all contributions are tax deductible. 
 
 
How Your Money Will Be Spent 
 
$10 can buy a costume
element at a thrift store;
 
$25 rents a truck for a
day to pick up, deliver and load in our set furniture;
 
$50 will pay our stage
manager for one night – the curtain can’t go up without this vital person, who
oversees and runs everything from lighting to sound to making sure the actors
are on time;
 
$100 takes care of our
music recording needs – after all, Merryl is a recording artist;
 
$200 gets our posters
and postcards printed;
 
$500 pays for 40 hours
of rehearsal space; and
 
$1,000 designs and
builds our set!
 
These are only a few
examples of our expenditure and, as theater lovers, we are inviting you to help
bring this play off the page and onto the stage.
 
Your contributions will
make this world premiere production of “It’s Good 2 be Crazy” possible. We are
begging, borrowing (but not stealing!) to bring this theatrical production to
life but can’t do it without you. 
 
Other Ways You Can HelpIn addition to making a financial contribution, you can help in
other ways too!
 
1.     
Expand your involvement – tell your friends, family and other
theatre lovers what you’ve done and invite them to join us too!
 
2.     
Donate your talents – we have a variety of needs that might line
up with your skills. Furniture store-owner in Los Angeles?   We need to furnish Merryl and
Joel’s apartment!  You get the
idea.  Let us know if you can help
us trim our budget by contributing goods and/or services.

story:
The Stage Theater's mission is to create a genuine, inclusive, artistic community that produces an exceptional theatrical experience. We will strive to create a community built through collaboration in the production of professional-quality entertainment. The ground work has been laid. Now, we invite you to share in our excitement in this new venture.

Our building is located in the main business area of Hickman, Nebraska, just a few miles from south Lincoln.  While the space has many positives, there are also a few renovations that need to happen before we can stage our first show.  We also need lights, costumes, set pieces....all the trimmings!

 

The Stage Theater is a non-profit community.  All of the participants, including the Board of Directors, are involved on a purely volunteer basis.  100% of funds raised will be used for building and operating costs.
