story:
Sweet Charity

is based on Federico Fellini's film "Nights of Cabria".  Sweet Charity as originally conceived, directed and choreographed by Bob Fosse.  This show tells the story of one women's pursuit of love and happiness.  This adult favle originally opened on Broadway in 1966, and was revived in 1986, and 2005. 

Please help Director Edmund Senkowski and Lakeland Players bring this great show to life in Waterford Michigan


The Impact

 From rental fees to production costs, the campaign's impact will go towards covering those costs. The more money we raise, more costs covered.

Costs Covered:

  • Venue Rental 
  • Lights and Sound Rental 
  • Production Costs: Building the set
  • Specific Costume Pieces 
  • Printing Costs: Media, Programs etc
  • Musicians to play in the pit

                                        Sweet Charity

Directed By Edmund Senkowski

Join us or a night of romance as we watch Charity Hope Valentine search for love.

Performances March 21,22,23,27,28,29,30

at Central United Methodist Church,, Waterford Michigan

www.lakelandplayers.net

Book by Neil Simon

Music by Cy Coleman

Lyics by Dorothy Fields

with Special arrangement with Tams Whitmark

story:
Summary

My name is Davey Strattan White, and my company is called A Whole New Missoula. It includes a wonderful director, Jill Harrison, and an intrepid co-producer, Susan T. Kinniry. Our goal is to produce my solo theatre piece, The Foundling Wheel, in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. With this play, we hope to explore the ever-growing animosity between the liberal and conservative concepts of America through the lens of extremely personal characters and their problems.

In the story, a liberal young hipster, frustrated by career displacement, goes to a tea party rally, and steals a baby. A conservative in crisis ditches his wife, and choir practice, and goes down the river on a canoe. Charon, the ferryman of the river Styx is forced to bear souls to the afterlife with or without his obulus payment. An odd story about financial redistribution, baby-snatching, and macro-cultural confusion.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our costs are simple

  • $300.00 to book Hodge Podge Arts performance space at 1212 South Street in Philadelphia
  • $200.00 to advertise, get the word out, and engage our audience
  • $200.00 for insurance, as required by the Philadelphia Fringe Festival
  • $125.00 to pay our director's stipend
  • $100.00 for some very minimal scenery
  • $75.00 for extra folding chairs to increase the capacity of the space
  • $100.00 for rehearsal space.

$1,100.00 total.  

Besides creating a vital and necessary piece of art that offers an opportunity for members of our community to explore the effects of political stubbornness and argumentativeness, donors will get comp tickets, and a donor party to be held in conjunciton with the festival.  A list of donors (omitting those who wish to remain anonymous) will be distributed to audience members, and Facebook shoutouts will publicly thank our benefactors and partners.

 

About the Artists

Davey Strattan White is a playwright and actor based in Philadelphia.  His plays have been produced in Philadelphia, New York, and Chicago.  They include The Amazing Irene Craigmile, Liverpudlian Sleeve, Simulations, An Imperfect Sonnet, Reindeer-Magnetosphere, and Still Life of a Moving Picture. He is also developing a new piece about Penn State fans.  

As an actor, some favorite roles on stage have included Cloud 9 at the Wilma Theatre, MacBeth at Indiana Repertory Theatre, In the Heart of America and The Last of the Boys at InterAct Theatre Company, Harlequin in The Game of Love and Chance at Commonwealth Classic Theatre Company, and The Winter's Tale at Delaware Shakespeare Festival.

He is a member of the adjunct faculty at Temple University and Montgomery County Community College.

Jill Harrison hails from NYC where she has worked as a freelance director and assistant for such companies as Playwrights Horizons, New York Theatre Workshop, Nora’s Playhouse, NYC Frigid Festival, Brooklyn Playwrights Collective, and Peculiar Works Project.

Since moving to Philadelphia in 2009, Jill has worked as the Associate Artistic Director at Simpatico Theatre Project and currently serves as the Festival Director for Philadelphia Theatre Company’s PTC@PLAY and the founder of The Directors Gathering, a Philadelphia-based directors’ collective. With Simpatico, she has directed the Philadelphia premiere of Sarah Ruhl’s Dead Man’s Cell Phone and the acclaimed Philadelphia premiere of Samuel D. Hunter’s Obie award winning play, A Bright New Boise. She has also directed Charles Mee’s Big Love and an excerpt of Stefanie Zadravec’s Honey Brown Eyes for Temple Theaters.

Jill holds a MFA in Directing from Temple University and a BA in Theatre from Lehigh University; and is a member of Lincoln Center Theatre Director’s Lab, a former member of the Directing Corps at Williamstown Theatre Festival, and an associate member of SDC.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please consider sharing the video in the link above.  Or just tell your friends they should consider helping out.  Use the Indiegogo share tools.  And by all means, we would love for you to come see the show in September.

story:
About Us

The 1500-seat, majestic Lincoln Amphitheatre is home to the outdoor musical drama about President Lincoln’s Indiana boyhood years, A. Lincoln: A Pioneer Tale. Lincoln Amphitheatre’s mission is to tell President Lincoln’s inspiring journey from Indiana pioneer to president of the United States. His stories come to life on the very grounds they took place nearly 200 years ago. With that said, funding for the arts is decreasing and we are looking for partners to help bridge the gap. Your monetary donation will play an integral role in keeping our most regarded President’s legacy alive.

Abraham Lincoln spent 14 of his formative years in Indiana.  His family settled in what is now known as Lincoln City, Indiana. During this time he experienced the loss of his mother and sister. He was a merchant, flatboat operator, book reader, and loved history. He was constantly learning and growing. On a trip to New Orleans he witnessed the horrible treatment and devastation that was slavery. Each of these events shaped Abraham Lincoln’s life and future.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is $50,000 by September 30. Funding will be used in conjunction with ticket sales and grant funding to compensate artists and production personnel, as well as to help cover the cost of the production. A. Lincoln: A Pioneer Tale has approximately 50 cast members and 25 technicians and design staff.
  • As a “Thank You!” donors will receive recognition on our website and our exclusive donor only e-newsletter. This newsletter will let you know about theater happenings before the general public. You could also receive free tickets and invites to our opening reception for A. Lincoln: A Pioneer Tale.

The Impact

We strive to provide professional, educational, and entertaining theater to our guests at affordable prices. We want to be able to invite individuals, couples, and large families to experience the unique atmosphere of our outdoor drama. The cost of each production makes it very challenging to achieve this goal. That is why we ask for your help. It is generous support from people like you who continue to help us reach our goals. Keep in mind every Abraham Lincoln helps! (Think in $5 increments not pennies.)

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to help out financially. We hope you'll take a second to help us spread the word.

  • Forward our email blast to people you think might be interested.
  • Let your friends and family know on Facebook and Twitter
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our Story:

Devon Frieder is an aspiring performer raised in Santa Fe who recently graduated from The Boston Conservatory with a B.F.A. in Musical Theatre. Over the last several years, she discovered a passion for directing, choreographing, and teaching young people as well, which she developed while producing multiple shows to provide other young aspiring performers in Santa Fe and Albuquerque with exciting new performing opportunities. This winter, she has the very exciting opportunity of producing the hit Broadway musical The Wedding Singer at Musical Theatre Southwest’s new black box, which performs the first two weekends of January. 

This will be the 8th show she has directed, produced, and choreographed for teens/young adults in New Mexico.  Past shows include Gypsy, You're a Good Man Charlie Brown, The Fantasticks, and the New Mexico premieres (and extremely successful productions) of The Drowsy Chaperone, 13: The Musical, and most recently, Xanadu at Warehouse 21 and The Box Performance space.

The Impact:

In just over three years, Devon has assembled a large company of over 60 young actors, singers, dancers, and crew members.  Many of these young people have appeared in multiple productions because of the impact the shows have made on their lives.  Devon has received multiple letters from former cast members thanking her for helping them rediscover their love for theatre and, in some cases, overcome their fears of performing in public.   

In addition to gaining an intensive theatre experience that many no longer receive in school due to lack of arts funding, they are also developing artistic passions that they may not have had before and building life-long friendships and connections.


What We Need:

The majority of the funds needed for this project will go towards renting the rehearsal and performance space, officially licensing the show through Music Theatre International, and providing accompaniment tracks, props, costumes, and sets.  All of Devon's shows would not have been possible without the extremely generous help of patrons and supporters like you.  Please help make this production of The Wedding Singer a reality with your contribution today. Even $5 can buy a necessary prop, and $20 can costume an entire character.


Other Ways You Can Help:

Spread the word!  If you have ever been involved in or seen one of Devon's shows, you understand the kind of impact they have on both performers and audiences alike.  We urge you to tell everyone you know about this campaign and pitch in; remember, every little bit helps!

story:
We're Back At It Again In 2013!

We are so excited to present our third season!

This year we are presenting two original adaptations -

"Anthem" - based on the novella by Ayn Rand, Artistic Director Jennifer Sandella brings to life her re-imagining of this pivotal work in its US premiere!

"Libations Bearers" - Martin Meccouri and Jennifer Sandella team up to give you a bloody, tribal, and earthy retelling of the Greek Tragedy.

PLUS WE'RE TEAMING UP ONCE AGAIN WITH BROOKLYN BRIDGE PARK!

After our smash summer hit "Twelfth Night" hit the NYC park system, we're back at it again with a brand new take on Shakespeare's MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING directed by Jessica Ko and Christopher Shepard! This production will bring great free Shakespeare to the Park's Bard on Pier 1 Series and have its very own full NYC run!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your funds will go directly towards funding our season!

  • After you give, you'll get a thanks from the "RAT Pack" with real-time twitter updates about how your generous donation is being utilized by our crew-- such as paying for set pieces, props, and costumes. Your donation will also go towards compensation for our cast and crew. And this is how RAT stands out from the rest!
  • In these economic times, it's becoming more common that the only jobs highly skilled and educated workers can find are unpaid internships. But agreeing to be free labor has always been the reality and norm for emerging theatre artists. Random Access Theatre strives to foster a supportive community by holistically addressing the artist's needs. We want to nurture creativity, but we also recognize the need to earn a living, and so compensate his/her energy, skills, and time accordingly. But as emerging artists ourselves, we can't change the status quo all on our own. So we ask you, our supporters, to partner with us in preserving the dignity of all workers!.

The Impact

We are dicated to creating a thriving and vibrant community of artists and art lovers and we hope to continue making great work for years to come. But we need your help.

This year is especially important - by this time next year we are working towards being in our own space where we can develop our work and begin to offer the chance for other artists to bring their work to the city in a nurturing and affordable atmosphere. With the help from YOU - our dedicated network of supporters, family, friends and fans, we can make this a reality!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know times are tough, and sometimes you just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word on social media! Together we can make great theatre happen!

story:
Who We Are & What We Are Doing

Prairie Kitten Productions is an independent production company that creates films and theatre pieces telling stories of the strong women around us. Our team, comprised of Vanessa Wenzel, Elaine Yang, Danelle White, and Cayley Wreggitt strongly believe in producing work that reflects the modern Canadian community. We pride ourselves in acknowledging and embracing the growing diversity in our community, and we hope to further encourage inclusivity in the entertainment industry. We are proud that all of our projects have gender parity and we work to ensure that women hold many if not all the key creative roles in our work. 

The Stand Up is a one act play we are taking on the road to the Kelowna Fringe Festival.  In 2017 we made a short film version of The Stand Up and now two years later we are reverting it back to it's original form as a stage play and we need your help. 

What We Need & What You Get

An excellent play requires many things, talented actors, amazing designers, a bomb creative team and materials to make it all look polished and professional. 

To take The Stand Up on the road to Kelowna we need $3,600. This money will go towards renting rehearsal space, set and costume materials, travel expenses from Calgary to Kelowna, and lodging during the run of the show. Any profits made from the Fringe production will be split using a profit share model, and it will all go back to compensate the artists who have poured their hearts into this show.

But there are perks to donating to PKP, check out our giving levels and perks on the side of the page! They range from a postcard from our trip, to the chance to sit in on a rehearsal of The Stand Up!

Other Ways You Can Help

There's more than one way to help! 

Please Share our Indiegogo page on your social media! 

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram at @prairiekittenproductions 

Keep an eye out for our upcoming Merch that will be going on sale! 

If you are interested in volunteering  for PKP please contact us at info@prairiekittenproductions.com
story_txt:
Who We Are & What We Are Doing
Prairie Kitten Productions is an independent production company that creates films and theatre pieces telling stories of the strong women around us. Our team, comprised of Vanessa Wenzel, Elaine Yang, Danelle White, and Cayley Wreggitt strongly believe in producing work that reflects the modern Canadian community. We pride ourselves in acknowledging and embracing the growing diversity in our community, and we hope to further encourage inclusivity in the entertainment industry. We are proud that all of our projects have gender parity and we work to ensure that women hold many if not all the key creative roles in our work. 
The Stand Up is a one act play we are taking on the road to the Kelowna Fringe Festival.  In 2017 we made a short film version of The Stand Up and now two years later we are reverting it back to it's original form as a stage play and we need your help. 

What We Need & What You Get
An excellent play requires many things, talented actors, amazing designers, a bomb creative team and materials to make it all look polished and professional. 
To take The Stand Up on the road to Kelowna we need $3,600. This money will go towards renting rehearsal space, set and costume materials, travel expenses from Calgary to Kelowna, and lodging during the run of the show. Any profits made from the Fringe production will be split using a profit share model, and it will all go back to compensate the artists who have poured their hearts into this show.
But there are perks to donating to PKP, check out our giving levels and perks on the side of the page! They range from a postcard from our trip, to the chance to sit in on a rehearsal of The Stand Up!

Other Ways You Can Help
There's more than one way to help! 
Please Share our Indiegogo page on your social media! 
Follow us on Facebook and Instagram at @prairiekittenproductions 
Keep an eye out for our upcoming Merch that will be going on sale! 
If you are interested in volunteering  for PKP please contact us at info@prairiekittenproductions.com

story:
Short Summary

Jessica Butcher is a performer, writer and feminist. Anoushka Lucas is a singer, songwriter and feminist too. We believe it is very important to create more three dimensional female characters and have their stories heard.

 

SPARKS examines the difficulties of grief and the female experience through multiple perspectives. It’s a show full of humour and love. It’s an honest story about being a woman and what it means to lose your mother. In this case, there's the added layer of losing your mother to multiple sclerosis. SPARKS doesn’t shy away from the hard questions, but it embraces the joy in the strength we find even in the darkest times. 

 

Should you be able to contribute to this crowdfunder you will help us connect directly with people who are experiencing grief. You will help us grow our relationship with MIND, Winston’s Wish (the childhood bereavement charity, and the M.S. Society. You will be help us tell a universal story that connects everyone.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

To get us off the ground we need to raise £3,500 by the beginning of November. This money will allow us to get all the right creatives in a room, fund our artwork for the show, and most importantly help us build our relationships with our chosen charities. This will kick-start SPARKS and allow us time to R&D the project prior to entering an intense rehearsal period. We need to raise £10,000 overall, and we will be doing this in stages, including an Arts Council Application and help from various charities.

 

Should you be kind enough to donate we can offer you some rewards! Free tickets to an Anoushka Lucas gig in London. A morning with us in rehearsal. A behind the scenes video. A party with our sponsors and charities. Jessica will write you a story on any subject you wish.

 

The Impact

We believe this play is highly important because it will provide a space for the audience to reflect on their own experiences of loss and it will hopefully make them laugh too. We are particularly interested in talking to people who are feeling held back by their self doubt. Your contribution will directly help in getting people talking and sharing their experiences is a safe and creative environment.

 

Our team are experienced in bringing compassionate and entertaining theatre to the world.

 

Who We Are

Jessica Butcher is an actress who was most recently in OFFSIDE (Edinburgh Festival 2017 & U.K. Tour). Jessica is known for playing Lucy Fuller in Camilla Whitehill's award winning play WHERE DO LITTLE BIRDS GO? Sometimes she's in EastEnders. SPARKS is her first play. Her second play, BOOTS, will also premiere in London in March 2018.

 

Anoushka Lucas is a multi-instrumentalist singer and songwriter. Her music has been championed by Jazz Fm (Love Supreme winner 2013) and Radio 2 (Jamie Cullum show, BBC Introducing).

Composer: Klook's Last Stand (Book by Che Walker, Park Theatre 2014), The Etienne Sisters (Book by Che Walker, Stratford East 2015), Klook's Last Stand (NAMT, Oct 2017)

Actor: Jesus Christ Superstar (Mary Magdalene, Regent's Park Open Air Theatre, Olivier Award Best Musical Revival), Murder on the Orient Express (Pianist, dir: Kenneth Branagh, 20th Century Fox), Been So Long (dir: Tinge Krishnan, BFI/Film4/Greenacre)

 

Jessica Edwards is a freelance director and Artistic Director of Flipping the Bird. She holds a first in English from Oxford University and associate directed for the Almeida, the Jamie Lloyd Company, the Young Vic and in the West End. She is Resident Director of drag-girl-super-group DENIM, who are associate artists of Soho Theatre.

Recent directing: Denim: World Tour (Soho Theatre / Underbelly); Punts (Theatre503); Revolutions (Arcola / Old Vic Lab); The Gulf (Old Vic Lab); Torch (Latitude / Edinburgh Festival 2016); Haters Make You Famous (Almeida Theatre); Queering Marlowe (Jamie Lloyd Company / Duke of York’s Theatre); White Hot & Weak (Old Vic New Voices Festival) The Box (Latitude / Theatre Delicatessen); The Itinerant Music Hall (Lyric Hammersmith / Watford Palace / GDIF / Latitude); Jekyll & Hyde (Southwark Playhouse / Assembly Edinburgh)

 

Michelle Barnette is a freelance producer and general manager. Recent theatre credits include Dust (Underbelly Edinburgh); Brutal Cessation (Assembly Edinburgh / Theatre503); The Scar Test (Soho Theatre & U.K. Tour). She has previously worked for The Kevin Spacey Foundation and was a Young Producer with the Westway Trust. Her short film The Girl in The Bubble screened at BAFTA in September 2017.

 

Risks & Challenges

With every new project comes risk and challenges. We have a solid team around us to make sure the play happens in February with huge energy.

 

Our producer Michelle Barnette is highly experienced in making new, exciting work and is totally committed getting this story on the stage. Jessica Edwards (director) specialises in female led theatre and is widely experienced in working with charities.

 

We’ll ultimately be looking to bring on PR and marketing to ensure that the play is in the public awareness. We will be working closely with them to secure features and bring in our target audience. 

 

We’ve set our ticket prices for the run at £10 to make sure the show is accessible, and we are confident that we will have a strong audience base. Our biggest risk is that no one turns up to the show but with your help we can make sure this isn’t the case. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, we thank you so much for reading this crowdfunder, and very much hope that you can come to the show in February.

story:
Short Summary

DanceCrush Kids is a charitable organization dedicated to developing children physically, emotionally, socially, and academically, through dance.

  • As Latin dance instructors in West Palm Beach, we saw a need in the community and immediately decided to help.  It began as a small idea and quickly grew into reality!  There are so many more children whose lives we could change if we had resources and assistance from people who are inspired by our mission.
  • This campaign allows us to admit additional children into our program who otherwise could not afford after-school programming. It is important they are occupied with productive physical activities after school because juvenile crime rates escalate between 3-7pm, and because 3 out of 10 children are obese or overweight.  With 1 out of 5 young people living in poverty, too many students are falling victim to negative influences during after-school hours and will greatly benefit from being an active part of DanceCrush Kids.  
  • Your contribution allows us to expand our program's hours, number of students admitted, and the amount of space we lease to accommodate the children, staff, and activity rooms.  The more we raise, the more lives we save by keeping kids in this community off the streets & motivated to achieve!

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our program operates on a sliding scale in which some parents/guardians are capable of covering part of the expense.  Every dollar you donate allows us to continue providing partial scholarships into our program for those who can afford to pay at a discounted rate.  However, many of our children are low-income and do not have any funds to contribute.  That is also where you come in!
  • It costs $15 per day to cover all of the expenses for a child to participate in DanceCrush Kids after school.  For $75, you can sponsor a DanceCrush Kid for a week.  For $300, you can help a child benefit academically, emotionally, socially and physically for an entire month.  And for $3,600 your generous gift has changed a child's life in ways we can only dream about.  Every dollar helps!  It is our vision that the children we serve will grow up to become productive citizens with strong values that lead them to paying it forward and positively contributing to society.
  • For specific increments of donations, you will receive either a brochure, a large booklet, or a DanceCrush Kids T-shirt.

The Impact of Dance

  • Physical - Dancing is a lifelong skill that promotes health and well-being far beyond kids' time at DanceCrush.  As an aerobic cardio exercise that, unlike most team and individual sports, requires little to no special equipment, dancing provides a healthy, low-cost way for kids to be active.  
  • Academic - Dancing is a creative outlet for kids that builds an appreciation for the arts.  Studies have shown students who receive dance instruction do better in math and science, and have higher test scores, than those with no instruction.
  • Emotional - Dance creates confidence and increases self-esteem.  It also provides a mechanism to help kids cope with stress, anxiety, and depression in a positive, non-judgmental environment.
  • Social - Dance builds connections to others in a constructive way.  Kids who participate in dance learn teamwork, communication skills, and co-operation, all while forging new friendships.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, you can still be vital to our operation & growth!

  • Volunteers needed! :) Please consider donating some of your free time for the kids!
  • Tell your friends about us & get out the word! Share this link via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn and email!
  • Come work for us! As we grow, we'll need to add talent to our staff :)

story:
"If thou couldst spare a farthing..."

Short Summary

Who are we?

  • We are a completely student run Shakespeare troupe
  • Director Justin LaVergne is a student at the University of Texas at Austin
  • Our team is comprised of UT students from various years and majors

What do we do?

  • We want to bring the works of Shakespeare to new audiences by reinvigorating the old English text with cutting edge concepts.
  • We aim to give opportunities to students of all skill levels a chance to contribute to every part of a production
  • We want people to leave our shows with the knowledge that Shakespeare doesn't always have to be the same show you did in high school

Why do we need your help?

  • We are in desperate need of money!
  • This money will go towards staging our debut performance, The Macbeth Project
  • We are all students and money is hard to come by
  • We believe that being creative in our lives is extremely important! This is our way to contribute to the world in a meaningful way.

What We Need & What You Get

At EDP, we see theatre as a collaborative art form, and without contributors like you, we would be nothing.

  • We are hoping to receive $1000 thanks to your generous donations
  • With that money, we will fund production costs such as props and costumes as well as publicity

In exchange for your help, we can offer you tons of thank-you gifts like shout outs on our social media, producer credits, a DVD of the show, an EDP t-shirt, a signed playbill, or even lifetime access to any future EDP shows plus one guest! We want to show our gratitude!

    The Impact

    This project is our company’s inaugural production, and we want nothing more than for it to be successful. With an incredible first project, our group will be able to gain exposure and draw more people to our company and to the art of Shakespeare.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Hey, we get it. Sometimes you just can't donate. What you can do is...

    • Spread the word! Tell your friends, tell your mom, tell your Great Aunt Suzie! The more the merrier.
    • Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter and Tumblr! You can find the links to our social media below.
    • Come see the show! Opening night is April 24, 2015.

    Thanks for your support!

story:
UPDATE

• Beloved Prey premieres on November 24th, 2015 at 8:00 PM (sharp) at The Secret Theater (4402 23rd St. Long Island City, NY 11101)

>> CLICK HERE TO GET YOUR TICKETS!<<

ATTENTION: Select Tue Nov 24, 2015 8:00 PM from the drop down menu! 

General Admission - $15 advance / $20 at the door
Seniors & Students (with ID) - $12 advance / $14 at the door

• As of 11/13/15, seats are 70% SOLD OUT. Get your tickets now, before it's too late!




• We are accepting tax-deductible donations, please contact us ASAP to proceed! (belovedprey@gmail.com)


We think of animals as different from us. When we say the word animal, we often mean ‘not human’. Beloved Prey is a story inspired by a strange phenomenon in nature where a predator animal adopts a prey animal, instead of eating them. Through this story we explore what we consider human emotion, compassion, feeling, is very much animal.


THE TRAVELING OPERA

When we hear the word opera, we think of a big orchestra, aristocratic costumes, grandiose theatres, and lyrics you can’t understand. The origin of the oral tradition, however, was more modest; bards and minstrels who spread stories from place to place on foot. The focus was on storytelling and less on theatrics.

We tailor the story and the production to be portable so that the show can be put on virtually anywhere - folding backdrops for easy transport and instant staging, a score composed specifically for very few instruments, sets that don’t need elaborate lighting and articulate lyrics that don’t need electronic translation.

Grand opera made these stories stationary. We’re putting opera back on the road.

http://www.japanculture-nyc.com/2015/10/10/koto-performer-kento-iwasaki-develops-his-concept-of-portable-opera/


BRINGING NEW OPERA INTO EXISTING SPACES

Grand opera uses a theatre space  to bring old operas to life. Beloved Prey transforms existing spaces into a stage to bring new operas to life. Our production brings the emphasis back to opera’s key elements: music, story, gesture and your imagination.


MUSIC- Beloved Prey blends Japanese traditional music with elements of European opera. A rich palette is painted through only 3 instruments and a handful of singers, creating an intimate yet immersive experience.

STORY - Our focus isn’t reproducing historical operas, but using the medium to tell stories. With an emphasis on articulation, and lyrics that merge the colloquial and poetic, Beloved Prey brings the wisdom of nature to a wide audience, not only those in reach of an opera house.

GESTURE - Choreography that blends traditional Japanese Noh theatre and dance creates a stylized and immersive language of gestures. Movement embodies and gives life to the story.

IMAGINATION - Your imagination is always there! It’s not only activated in an opera house!  Your imagination is what makes the experience, whether inside or outside a traditional theatre space.



WHY OPERA SHOULD TRAVEL

Not everyone lives in a major metropolis with an opera house. However, everyone should have access to the arts - live, not just on Youtube. We want to bring Beloved Prey to you, wherever you are. Experiencing art should not be a privilege of city-dwellers alone, opera is an art form of storytelling and should be accessible anywhere.



WHO WE ARE

Beloved Prey is the first of many operas the Traveling Opera Company plans to produce and put on the road. We are pioneering a new genre: "traveling opera". Beloved Prey demonstrates how a small-scale production can compete against a grand opera production. We believe that imagination, efficiency and quality is key.

We envision bringing opera to a variety of spaces, not just limited to the theater - zoos, museums, art galleries, anime conventions, archways, even resonant parking lots can be transformed into opera spaces through The Traveling Opera Company. We want to create a company that has the administrative power to engage in new productions and booking existing productions year-round. Products need marketing, so do artistic works. Therefore, we wish to hire booking agents, marketers, PR, so “traveling operas” becomes a household term. This is a movement, not just a flash in the pan.  We encourage the public to engage in our artistic process as such a movement is impossible without your support.

KENTO IWASAKI

Founder of The Traveling Opera Company, Kento Iwasaki is a classically trained composer and koto performer. His goal is to create music that acts as a bridge between the traditional and current moment, fusing old and new, East and West,  helping us connect with our ancestors. He studied koto with Satomi Fukami and Yoko Reikano Kimura and received training in opera composition from Libby Larsen, John Corgliano and and William Bolcolm. He also received training in the art of collaboration at the Nautilus Music-Theater/New Dramatists Composer-Librettist Studio. Previous composition teachers include Mark Jurcisin, Matthew Greenbaum and Richard Danielpour.

CRIS RYAN

Cris Ryan is the librettist and costume designer for Beloved Prey. Ryan's costume designs have made various appearances on Chinese national television shows, such as Day Day Up and Super Boy, as early as 2010.  Upon relocating to New York City in 2012, Ryan has worked under designer Matthew Hemesath on musicals and film productions, such as Legally Blonde and John Wick. That same year his writing was discovered by composer Kento Iwasaki, describing Ryan as having a poetic voice particularly inclined for opera libretti. Ryan's first libretto was evaluated by composer Mark Stambaugh, who praised the duo to develop operatic works. In May 2014, Ryan attended the John Duffy Institute, where he studied opera theatrics with mentors including Libby Larsen, John Corgliano and Michael Korie. In the future, Ryan intends to write a handful of new works that will innovate the traveling opera movement.

THE DUO

When we were invited to the Duffy Composer’s Institute to workshop an opera scene we composed, we were inspired by our mentors to do an opera that radically redefines what opera is. We began playing with the idea of a portable opera featuring a lioness who adopts a baby antelope. Libby Larsen, one of America’s greatest opera composers responded very enthusiastically to our synopsis and project idea. So did Diane Wondisford, President of Music-Theater Group (which produced Tan Dun’s ‘Marco Polo’). This compelled us to take on this crazy new opera idea - an opera that would never fit the mold of what would be performed in an opera house.


WHAT WE’VE ACCOMPLISHED SO FAR

We  began working on Beloved Prey in 2014 upon receiving a residency with Exploring the Metropolis. We previewed the first half of the opera in December at several festivals and held a private showing for Sir Norman Rosenthal. Encouraged to complete the opera, we received a grant from Queens Council of the Arts in early 2015. Working with arts & startup incubator Distillate Collective, we expanded our vision, founding The Traveling Opera Company to take Beloved Prey - and future shows - on the road. Our project has received coverage on Fox News 5, Clocktower Radio, and the Queens Tribune.



HOW YOU CAN HELP MAKE BELOVED PREY POSSIBLE

The first full length performance of Beloved Prey will be on November 24th. The grant from the Queens Council of the Arts has helped us get started, however it does not cover all of the costs, low though they are due the portable nature of the production.

We need your help to premiere this traveling opera and take it on the road - and bring it to you!

Your donations will go directly to paying our talented performers, musicians, and team.


In exchange for your generous support, we’re offering exclusive merch and rewards which we can’t wait to send you. Illustrated librettos, production credits, ringtones, opera glasses, logo tees, patron’s gift bag, and even a full-scale hand-painted replica of the set (which serves as stunning room divider!) Here are just a few:


$55 - Koto Request Live!

Kento will play and record your song of choice on koto and send you an MP3!

$150 - Noh traditional theatre lesson (NYC only)

Get a taste of the traditional arts that samurai practiced! A lesson in Noh theatre with choreographer Toshinori Hamada. Also included is a ringtone of the theme from the opera.



$250 - Beloved Patron

Antelope or Lioness tote bag with white, gold metallic, or maroon print logo on black - with all of our merch! Limited edition t-shirt, logo gift bag and illustrated libretto. Also included is a ringtone of the theme from the opera.

$2000 - Backstage Pass

Get a handpainted replica of our 5-panel painting traveling opera set - painted by the artist! - as a stunning room divider for your home. If this isn’t the coolest reward ever, we don’t know what is. You will also receive Opera Producer credit, an illustrated libretto, and a ringtone of the theme from the opera.



$100 - Friend of Beloved Prey - Teeshirt

Womens & Mens teeshirts available in Antelope or Lioness design. Colors available: black with white logo, light heather grey with maroon logo, or white with maroon logo. All sizes available.


#BELOVEDPREY - Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Tell a friend who likes animals, music, culture, or art about Beloved Prey!

  • Check out and share our Facebook page www.facebook.com/belovedprey  

  • Use #BELOVEDPREY and tell your friends about traveling opera on Instagram and Twitter!

  • We’re taking this show on the road and we want to know WHERE you want us to go! Tweet us to let us know where you want to see us!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!


This project is made possible by our sponsors who have donated their time, resources, and expertise to help make The Traveling Opera Company a reality:

  • EtM ConEdison Composers' Residency, administered by Exploring the Metropolis.

  • Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council

  • Distillate Collective, an incubator for startups, creatives, and makers.

  • Special thanks to Juliie Azuma & Brian Kish.
story_txt:
UPDATE• Beloved Prey premieres on November 24th, 2015 at 8:00 PM (sharp) at The Secret Theater (4402 23rd St. Long Island City, NY 11101)
>> CLICK HERE TO GET YOUR TICKETS!<<ATTENTION: Select Tue Nov 24, 2015 8:00 PM from the drop down menu! General Admission - $15 advance / $20 at the doorSeniors & Students (with ID) - $12 advance / $14 at the door
• As of 11/13/15, seats are 70% SOLD OUT. Get your tickets now, before it's too late!
• We are accepting tax-deductible donations, please contact us ASAP to proceed! (belovedprey@gmail.com)

We think of animals as different from us. When we say the word animal, we often mean ‘not human’. Beloved Prey is a story inspired by a strange phenomenon in nature where a predator animal adopts a prey animal, instead of eating them. Through this story we explore what we consider human emotion, compassion, feeling, is very much animal.


THE TRAVELING OPERA
When we hear the word opera, we think of a big orchestra, aristocratic costumes, grandiose theatres, and lyrics you can’t understand. The origin of the oral tradition, however, was more modest; bards and minstrels who spread stories from place to place on foot. The focus was on storytelling and less on theatrics.
 We tailor the story and the production to be portable so that the show can be put on virtually anywhere - folding backdrops for easy transport and instant staging, a score composed specifically for very few instruments, sets that don’t need elaborate lighting and articulate lyrics that don’t need electronic translation.
Grand opera made these stories stationary. We’re putting opera back on the road.


http://www.japanculture-nyc.com/2015/10/10/koto-performer-kento-iwasaki-develops-his-concept-of-portable-opera/

BRINGING NEW OPERA INTO EXISTING SPACES
Grand opera uses a theatre space  to bring old operas to life. Beloved Prey transforms existing spaces into a stage to bring new operas to life. Our production brings the emphasis back to opera’s key elements: music, story, gesture and your imagination.
MUSIC- Beloved Prey blends Japanese traditional music with elements of European opera. A rich palette is painted through only 3 instruments and a handful of singers, creating an intimate yet immersive experience.
STORY - Our focus isn’t reproducing historical operas, but using the medium to tell stories. With an emphasis on articulation, and lyrics that merge the colloquial and poetic, Beloved Prey brings the wisdom of nature to a wide audience, not only those in reach of an opera house.
GESTURE - Choreography that blends traditional Japanese Noh theatre and dance creates a stylized and immersive language of gestures. Movement embodies and gives life to the story.
IMAGINATION - Your imagination is always there! It’s not only activated in an opera house!  Your imagination is what makes the experience, whether inside or outside a traditional theatre space.



WHY OPERA SHOULD TRAVELNot everyone lives in a major metropolis with an opera house. However, everyone should have access to the arts - live, not just on Youtube. We want to bring Beloved Prey to you, wherever you are. Experiencing art should not be a privilege of city-dwellers alone, opera is an art form of storytelling and should be accessible anywhere.

WHO WE ARE



Beloved Prey is the first of many operas the Traveling Opera Company plans to produce and put on the road. We are pioneering a new genre: "traveling opera". Beloved Prey demonstrates how a small-scale production can compete against a grand opera production. We believe that imagination, efficiency and quality is key.We envision bringing opera to a variety of spaces, not just limited to the theater - zoos, museums, art galleries, anime conventions, archways, even resonant parking lots can be transformed into opera spaces through The Traveling Opera Company. We want to create a company that has the administrative power to engage in new productions and booking existing productions year-round. Products need marketing, so do artistic works. Therefore, we wish to hire booking agents, marketers, PR, so “traveling operas” becomes a household term. This is a movement, not just a flash in the pan.  We encourage the public to engage in our artistic process as such a movement is impossible without your support.





KENTO IWASAKI
Founder of The Traveling Opera Company, Kento Iwasaki is a classically trained composer and koto performer. His goal is to create music that acts as a bridge between the traditional and current moment, fusing old and new, East and West,  helping us connect with our ancestors. He studied koto with Satomi Fukami and Yoko Reikano Kimura and received training in opera composition from Libby Larsen, John Corgliano and and William Bolcolm. He also received training in the art of collaboration at the Nautilus Music-Theater/New Dramatists Composer-Librettist Studio. Previous composition teachers include Mark Jurcisin, Matthew Greenbaum and Richard Danielpour.
CRIS RYAN

Cris Ryan is the librettist and costume designer for Beloved Prey. Ryan's costume designs have made various appearances on Chinese national television shows, such as Day Day Up and Super Boy, as early as 2010.  Upon relocating to New York City in 2012, Ryan has worked under designer Matthew Hemesath on musicals and film productions, such as Legally Blonde and John Wick. That same year his writing was discovered by composer Kento Iwasaki, describing Ryan as having a poetic voice particularly inclined for opera libretti. Ryan's first libretto was evaluated by composer Mark Stambaugh, who praised the duo to develop operatic works. In May 2014, Ryan attended the John Duffy Institute, where he studied opera theatrics with mentors including Libby Larsen, John Corgliano and Michael Korie. In the future, Ryan intends to write a handful of new works that will innovate the traveling opera movement.
THE DUO
When we were invited to the Duffy Composer’s Institute to workshop an opera scene we composed, we were inspired by our mentors to do an opera that radically redefines what opera is. We began playing with the idea of a portable opera featuring a lioness who adopts a baby antelope. Libby Larsen, one of America’s greatest opera composers responded very enthusiastically to our synopsis and project idea. So did Diane Wondisford, President of Music-Theater Group (which produced Tan Dun’s ‘Marco Polo’). This compelled us to take on this crazy new opera idea - an opera that would never fit the mold of what would be performed in an opera house.



WHAT WE’VE ACCOMPLISHED SO FARWe  began working on Beloved Prey in 2014 upon receiving a residency with Exploring the Metropolis. We previewed the first half of the opera in December at several festivals and held a private showing for Sir Norman Rosenthal. Encouraged to complete the opera, we received a grant from Queens Council of the Arts in early 2015. Working with arts & startup incubator Distillate Collective, we expanded our vision, founding The Traveling Opera Company to take Beloved Prey - and future shows - on the road. Our project has received coverage on Fox News 5, Clocktower Radio, and the Queens Tribune.HOW YOU CAN HELP MAKE BELOVED PREY POSSIBLEThe first full length performance of Beloved Prey will be on November 24th. The grant from the Queens Council of the Arts has helped us get started, however it does not cover all of the costs, low though they are due the portable nature of the production.We need your help to premiere this traveling opera and take it on the road - and bring it to you!Your donations will go directly to paying our talented performers, musicians, and team.In exchange for your generous support, we’re offering exclusive merch and rewards which we can’t wait to send you. Illustrated librettos, production credits, ringtones, opera glasses, logo tees, patron’s gift bag, and even a full-scale hand-painted replica of the set (which serves as stunning room divider!) Here are just a few:$55 - Koto Request Live!Kento will play and record your song of choice on koto and send you an MP3!


$150 - Noh traditional theatre lesson (NYC only)
Get a taste of the traditional arts that samurai practiced! A lesson in Noh theatre with choreographer Toshinori Hamada. Also included is a ringtone of the theme from the opera.


$250 - Beloved Patron
Antelope or Lioness tote bag with white, gold metallic, or maroon print logo on black - with all of our merch! Limited edition t-shirt, logo gift bag and illustrated libretto. Also included is a ringtone of the theme from the opera.


$2000 - Backstage PassGet a handpainted replica of our 5-panel painting traveling opera set - painted by the artist! - as a stunning room divider for your home. If this isn’t the coolest reward ever, we don’t know what is. You will also receive Opera Producer credit, an illustrated libretto, and a ringtone of the theme from the opera.$100 - Friend of Beloved Prey - TeeshirtWomens & Mens teeshirts available in Antelope or Lioness design. Colors available: black with white logo, light heather grey with maroon logo, or white with maroon logo. All sizes available.#BELOVEDPREY - Other Ways You Can Help!

We’re taking this show on the road and we want to know WHERE you want us to go! Tweet us to let us know where you want to see us!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

This project is made possible by our sponsors who have donated their time, resources, and expertise to help make The Traveling Opera Company a reality:

Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council

Special thanks to Juliie Azuma & Brian Kish.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Elisabeth, and I am an advanced ballet dancer living in Sherwood Park, Alberta, Canada. I have been dancing ballet since I was 3 years old, and it has always been my dream to dance in a professional ballet company. Being in Grade 11, and nearing the field of professional dance, I need to be in an intense daily training program in order to achieve my goals.

I auditioned for several full year programs, not even expecting to be accepted. I was then offered this incredible once in a life time opportunity to train throughout the year in the professional program at the prestigious Goh Ballet Academy in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. I am so excited that I have this amazing opportunity, which will be a huge stepping stone in my career!

The only thing stopping me from attending is the huge financial cost. After everything is paid for, the costs will come to over $20,000 dollars. My family cannot pay for this alone, and we will be fundraising in many different ways to try and realize my dreams!

Dancing means the world to me and I could not imagine life without it. Ballet is the only thing I have ever wanted to pursue as a career, and this incredible opportunity will allow me to further myself on this path. Please support me in this endeavour, and help me to live my dreams!

What We Need & What You Get

I will need a total of $20, 000 to support this endeavor. (It is a ten month program spanning from September 2013-June 2014). My Indiegogo goal is $500, as we will be fundraising in many different ways.

-Tuition (cost of classes): $6,810

-Billet/Homestay (cost of food and board): $9,000 ($900/mth)

-Pointe Shoes (I go through a pair every 2 weeks): $2,400

-Other Equipment (Bodysuits, tights, hair supplies, ballet shoes): $460

-Flight Costs (beginning and end of year/holidays): $1.330

If I do not achieve my total goal from funds raised on this site and elsewhere, the funds will go towards saving up for attending a trainee/apprenticeship program with a ballet company the following year, after I graduate from high school.

The Impact

It has always been my dream to become a professional ballerina. Finally I have been given this amazing opportunity, and it would mean the world to me to be able to attend this world renowned school. This is the opportunity that will allow me to pursue the career of my dreams. It is the perfect stepping stone to my professional career. To be able to successfully pursue my passions, I need to be in an intense program with good quality training, and lots of hours. This program at the Goh Ballet Academy offers all of these things, and more. This is the opportunity of a life time, and I would be crushed if I missed it. Any help we can get in supporting this endeavor would be amazing.


Attending this school would allow for me to improve immensely, and grow incredibly as a dancer and a person. It is truly the opportunity of a lifetime, and in no way could it possibly fail to improve my ballet technique, stamina, and strength. It will open doors to opportunities that I will never have if I stay training where I am. Please give any support possible. Even the most minimal contribution will make a huge difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to make a personal contribution, please spread the word! Tell everyone you know about this campaign, and share my campaign on all the social media sites your participate in! Sharing by word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter etc. will be extremely helpful! Make sure you let everyone know about my campaign, and let them know that even the smallest contribution is helpful! Thank you!

story:
At this year’s New York City Fringe Festival Colleen Scriven will be presenting a creative reimagining of Moliere’s classic as part of the Fringe AL FRESCO series, the free outdoor theatre arm of Fringe. The dialogue remains from the original, but that’s about it. This bold rethinking will place the well known characters into modern day Brooklyn, representing all of the different types of people from the borough, from uptight Park Slopers to Williamsburg hipsters.

The cast includes Louis Laurens as Orgon, the Park Slope yuppie father in the midst of a midlife crisis who is seduced by the too-cool ways of Tartuffe (Stephen Sherwood ). Orgon’s family who see through Tartuffe’s thrift store and vinyl exterior will include his children Mariane (Lianne Frankel) and Damis (Luke Wise), as well as his new wife (Nastasha Strang). Lorenzo Landini will play Cleante, the voice of reason, Christopher Chwee will play the tough Valere, Mariane’s boyfriend, John O’Hara will play the roles of M. Loyal and The Exempt, and Jen Flanagan will take on the legendarily sassy role of Dorine.

story:
Who are we?:

We are a group of performers who have been working in Ayrshire for the past five years.  Our town is currently without a theatre and we have been trying to keep the performing arts alive using non-theatre spaces.  Our campaign is to raise money for a family-friendly production that can be enjoyed by our entire community. It will introduce a younger audience to the magic of theatre and will entertain audiences of all ages with a unqiue take on a children's classic. 

The money needed:

We are asking for $1400 which would allow us to bring Lewis Carroll's world to life.  The money would go towards equipment, marketing, costume, props and actors exspenses.  The money would also contribute towards the 'special effects'.  Our production will use animated projections to bring this fantastical tale to the stage and so money will go towards local artists.  By paying these artists we can ensure they are able to dedicate the huge amounts of time that go into animation.  If we do not raise the full funds needed we will dedicate the money raised to providing high-quality projections during the show meaning that the magical worlds will remain with cuts being made else where, such as costumes and props.

Incentives:

For people who donate $25 we will include your name in our programme as one of our sponsers.  Donations of $50 will get you a DVD of the finished event. For donations of $1000 we can provide a DVD, a signed cast photograph and one of the props used during the production.

Conclusion:

Contributions will be going towards creating an unforgetable performance.  

If you are unable to contribute we would be grateful if you could spread this campaign using social-media and help us reach our target so that we can entertain and continue to do what we love.

story:
So here's the deal, Brilliantly Different Productions, a theatre production company based in Henderson, Ky that strives to create new and modern theatrical productions, is creating a new production of "Chaplin" the musical. Written by Christopher Curtis and Tony Award winner Thomas Meehan, the musical chronicles the life of Hollywood legend Charlie Chaplin. The show, which ran on Broadway in 2012, has not been seen in North America since and we will be one of the first productions of this new version of the show.

My name is  J. Farley Norman and I am the artistic director of Brilliantly Different Productions. When this journey with "Chaplin" began in December, it was like a dream come true for myself and for my team. This is a show that we have been interested in since we discovered it and we could have never imagined it would be happening so soon. 

When we started looking at the show, we were posed with the question, from writer Christopher Curtis, why tell this story? In answering this question, it becomes very simple, we want to tell this story because it lets us show the life of a man who has become a legend, and to show that he was just a man, with a creative mind and a dream. Chaplin is more than a man to us, he embodies what creativity and art can be in a fast paced, modern world. He proved that art can be used to show a message and make people understand the world around them.

The biggest challenge with the show is telling it in the modern style that Brilliantly Different is known for. By using projection technology that has never been used on stage, we are able to fully immerse the audience in the world of Chaplin and the silent-era of Hollywood. Using ground breaking technology, we are able to take the audience on a journey that is sure to entertain. With this technology comes expense, and a show of this size does not come cheap. We need your help to get the show funded and on its way to success, some of our expenses include:

-Audition space rental

-Paying creative team members

-Rehearsal space rental

-Technical rentals (lighting, sound, projections, etc.)

-Venue rental

-Costuming, Make-Up, and Scenic Construction

These expenses do not come cheap and we need your help to make this show happen. By becoming involved with the show, you are helping us bring this fantastic story to life and create a show that is sure to be a staple for Brilliantly Different in the coming years.
