story:
Dancing Towards the Future...Dreams DO Come True!!

                   

Sylvani stands upon a threshold...she is 17...at the age when pre-professional dancers begin their final steps to their career.  Please help her go to Oregon Ballet Theater's 6-week Summer Ballet Intensive, where she will prepare to launch into her Dream!



The Synopsis: 

(That's "Ballet Talk" for "The Short Version")

Sylvani has known since she was 3 that she is a Dancer. To Sylvani, dancing is life, dancing is breathing. Dance is where she expresses her soul and touches yours.

This summer, Sylvani is hoping to go to Oregon Ballet Theater's 6-week summer ballet intensive, where she will be in the top level, and offered a possible opportunity to dance professionally with their second company!!!

Please will you help her meet the cost of this program? Any contribution helps!
Sylvani has been training, both at her home studio in Eugene, Oregon Ballet Academy, since she was 3, and also at wonderful summer intensives (Joffrey Ballet, Oregon Ballet Theater, Texas Ballet Theater, and Whitman Summer Dance Lab) each year since she was 13. 
Sylvani has been honored to dance lead roles in her studio's Fall ballet productions. She has occasionally been invited to dance in other venues as well. Her artistry, her musicality and her beauty in story telling are evident to any who watch her. 
Audience members have told us that they can't take their eyes off Sylvani when she dances! Sylvani's devotion to Dance, as an art form that transforms those who witness it as well as the dancer herself, is core to everything she does.    

                       

Sylvani spends over 20 hours every week in dance class during the school year--after school and on weekends. Even more when rehearsing for a performance. But aspiring professional dancers must go to summer intensives with a ballet company: 5-6 weeks of dancing all day, 40 hours a week or more, at a ballet company academy, with current professionals, company faculty, and guest artists helping to further refine and strengthen her technique, giving insight into careers, and making connections for her future. It's hard, rigorous work...and it's what Sylvani loves. 

The audition process is rigorous and competitive, only about 10% of dancers are even accepted during national audition tours. Sylvani regularly is not only accepted, but offered some level of scholarship.

This past winter, Sylvani auditioned for several summer intensives, with her most desired ones being Joffrey Ballet and Oregon Ballet Theater. 

                                 

Age 17, for a dancer, is time to make one's final launch plans for a ballet company apprenticeship and then a career. She essentially has one more year to go before auditioning for company apprenticeships and trainee positions. 
After much consideration, she has decided that Oregon Ballet Academy is her best step this summer. Here's why:
  • She is already placed in OBT's top, pre-professional level.
  • It is close to home, with family members in town, so less cost and also easier possibility of immediately moving there for year-round training.
  • 4-6 week attendees have an chance to be picked for OBT2, OBT's second company. 
  • Most important: The personal attention and smaller classes she found at OBT, in their top level with company members taking class with her, will help her really fine tune, giving her the edge she feels she still needs to be ready for Joffrey's top professional level in next summer's intensive, and to audition for either company the following fall!
Sylvani has a big dream, and she has thoughtfully decided that OBT's program will get her there.

"I have come to understand that dancers emit a speech-- a song-- through their bodies. I think that Oregon Ballet Theater's summer intensive could help me learn to facilitate that within myself.  As I have grown up and changed and become aware of so much of the world around me-- the breakthroughs and the barriers, the struggles between humans and nature, especially between humans and other humans-- I have found how dance itself has matured into an agent of change. The nuances of movement can convey such rich and intense emotions that they can completely transport an audience, which I have experienced at OBT performances. I understand that ballet is extremely competitive, and opportunities to get one's pointed foot in the door are rare, but I hope that with the proper training, and a great opportunity like OBT2 (OBT's second company) to work for, I could have a shot." --Sylvani

The Cost Breakdown:

  • 6 weeks Tuition: $2205
  • Room and Board: $3100
  • 8 pairs of pointe shoes, 5 leotards, 6 pairs of tights: $670

Full Cost: $5975

Subtractions we've already been able to make: 

  • -$500 from my tax refund
  • -$1000 (2 weeks housing at Grandma and Grandpa's in Portland)
  • Applied for OBT scholarship: Hope to receive $1000  (UPDATE: ACTUALLY RECIEVED $1500!!! we reduced our goal by $500! )  
  • A friend, Mike Jones, contributed $100 directly through another campaign.

Total: $3375

We were thankfully able to reduce our goal to $2875, because OBT gave Sylvani a $1500 scholarship--$500 more than we'd hoped!  AND WE REACHED THAT GOAL!!! 

But there are still many costs not covered here, so we hope you will still contribute to Help Sylvani Dance! 

If you contribute, check out the wonderful "perks" on the sidebar!  You can also use the "share" tools near the top to help spread the word--"Crowdfunding" takes a crowd!  

Watch this video of Sylvani's transformation in pictures!


Read on for the Full Ballet...

Dreaming of Sugar Plums...

 

Sylvani has always known she was a dancer! When she was only 3, I took her to see "The Nutcracker", and she told me she wanted to be the Sugar Plum Fairy one day. Her grandparents agreed to pay for ballet lessons (my mother is a dancer, too), and the dream began. 


At age 14, Sylvani was honored by her main teacher, John Grensback, Artistic Director of Oregon Ballet Academy, to be one of a triple cast chosen to dance the sparkly fairy of the Land of Sweets!

          

Becoming a Swan...

At age 6, after seeing "Swan Lake", Sylvani informed me she would one day dance as Odette, the Swan Queen. Many little girls dream of putting on a tutu, but most eventually turn to other things. Not Sylvani...she was determined, Sylvani kept going, kept dreaming.

At age 15, Mr. Grensback honored her once again with the role of Odette/Odile in a triple cast in his production of "Swan Lake"! I don't know how many little girls set their sights on something like this, but to dance THE ultimate ballet role, even in a student production, at this age was a dream come true!

         


Snow White...Telling an Entire Story...

      


This year, Sylvani was again cast in the lead role in a triple cast...this time "Snow White and the Seven Dancing Dwarves", Mr. Grensback's own creation.  (photos from rehearsals)

The role of "Snow White" was unique to even most lead roles, in that Sylvani danced in nearly every scene. Rehearsals every day, AFTER regular dance class, AFTER high school (where she is pulling down all A's and B's).  Learning to act with innocence and love with her "Prince"...

Meeting Fairies in the Forest who protect her and the animals...                                             

Dying tragically when the "Queen" gives her a poisoned apple. 
And comic timing, story telling, and joy in partnering with seven "dwarves" of varying ages. 

         

 

                   

Sylvani had to take on the full role, beginning to end, to tell the story of the beautiful "Snow".                                                                                                                                                     

A Rare Journey of Self Knowledge, and the Support of So Many...

If you watch the video at the very top of this campaign, you glimpse an incredible journey through photos...a rare one...the journey of one who has ALWAYS been destined to be a Dancer, with the incredible gift of always knowing it. 

You see someone who has with a work ethic: through painful pointe shoes, pulled tendons, and "costume malfunctions", and never let her audience know. 
You see growth: long hours striving for perfection,  hard work,  the fulfillment of each step in a dance, and maybe...you see the Future.


There is something else you will see...you see many, many other people along the way.

You see teachers who have given their knowledge, their drive, their own spirit of love from their own similar journeys.




You "see" the audience, (though invisible, as if from the lights of a stage), who

Sylvani dances for, and hopes to give a piece of her heart to.

And you see yourself... YOU, are such an important sponsor, without whom Sylvani could not continue to reach for her dreams of bringing her unique dance "voice" to the world. Sylvani dreams of bringing change to the world through dance--and you bring the means for that to happen!
Sylvani has received so much support from so many!
It's been truly incredible, and overwhelming, to see just how many people want to give to help her succeed! Sylvani's grandparents on my side have paid for her year-round ballet lessons since she was 3. Sylvani's grandparents on her father's side, may their memory be for a blessing, gave love endlessly, and help with additional costs. Sylvani had an anonymous sponsor who so kindly paid for all her intensive costs and many other things for a year--though we do not know what happened to him, we bless him for giving us a sense that all this IS possible! 

Some have given a place to stay while traveling, or airline miles (this year, no planes!). 
And there have been so many more, hundreds of you, who have been willing to give $1, $5, $10 (if 100 people give $10, we've raised $1000!),$25, $50 and up to $100, $200, $300, even $1000!!  Each one of you, we are so grateful for, for this would not happen without you. 

Journeys Afar...summers spent training away from home.

Whitman Summer Dance Lab...First Journey Away

When Sylvani was 12, her teacher's wife, Megan Murphy, who danced for San Francisco Ballet and Houston Ballet, told us it was time for her to audition for some summer intensives. A summer intensive involves several weeks of dancing all day, every day, with current professionals, company faculty, and former stars, then spending nights in the dorm with other dedicated young dancers--eating, sleeping, breathing dance! This is an opportunity to fully immerse in the world of Dance as both an artform and a profession, making contacts, learning different styles, and learning new techniques to help with "trouble spots".

Ms. Murphy said Sylvani was very young, and may not get accepted, but it would be good practice, as the auditions are high pressure. Sylvani auditioned for American Ballet Theater, and Whitman Summer Dance Lab. To her surprise, she was accepted to both! But they cost thousands of dollars. 

We launched a campaign here on Indiegogo. We called it "Help Sylvani Dance" and raised everything she needed to go to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for 2 weeks. Our local television station even did a news report on her!
Thanks to the "Go Go Factor"  of all the contributors, Sylvani was discovered by a wealthy sponsor who paid all her expenses for the following year! 

At age 14, Sylvani returned to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for a second year, this time for 5 weeks. She was among 10 top students chosen to participate in a professional dance festival, with San Francisco modern dance company, ODC Dance's choroegrapher, KT Nelson, creating a piece on them.
 

Texas Ballet Theater...Journey Farther Afield

The following year, at age 15, Sylvani again auditioned for many company intensives, and this time, was blessed to go to Texas Ballet Theater, where she was offered a 90% tuition scholarship! Once again, we raised the remaining funds her on Indiegogo, with "Help Sylvani Dance 2.0", and so many of you helped out!

Her primary teacher, Mr. Grensback, was guest faculty there, as he had been a Principal dancer under the TBT choreographer, Sir Ben Stevenson, when he was choreographer for the Houston Ballet in the 80's. Sylvani took class with current TBT company members, and all the TBT faculty, including former Houston Ballet Principals Kathryn Warakomsky and Li Anlin.

Joffrey Ballet in Chicago...Journey to Her Dream Company!

Last summer, Sylvani's teacher, Mr. Grensback, said that at age 16, if she had a company she really hoped to dance for one day, this was the time to go...both to

                                                                                

  

be seen by them, and also to gain insight into how to one day dance for them. Sylvani's favorite company is Joffrey Ballet, in Chicago, and when they offered her 50% off her tuition, and she also was one of 16 high school arts students nationally to win the Anthony Quinn Foundation Scholarship to help her go, Sylvani took her chance!
 "Help Sylvani Dance to Joffrey", with help from our community of family and friends, YOU, she was able to go! 
Dancing in the Joffrey Tower, staying in downtown Chicago, and learning choreography of the Joffrey repertoire was an amazing experience that she hopes to repeat. She learned so much! 

                                                               

However, she found that she still has a way to go. One thing Sylvani learned is that Joffrey places students in levels according to their age. This meant that she was in the third level at age 16, and if she goes back this summer, will likely be in their second level. Their top level is for 18 year olds and up, who are ready to move into a professional career or an apprenticeship with Joffrey's Studio Company. Sylvani also learned, from Joffrey Artistic Director, Ashley Wheaton, that he prefers to hire dancers who have professional experience with another company.

Oregon Ballet Theater-- on the Threshold of her Future Journeys...

After she returned from Joffrey, Sylvani was also able to attend Oregon Ballet Theater in Portland for 2 weeks.  Both were wonderful in different ways.  She still dreams of being a Joffrey dancer one day, but OBT showed her a path that feels  more "right" to actually achieve that dream, while giving her a company close to home where she can train--perhaps year round--and maybe even dance for! 

At the OBT intensive, a smaller environment, she received lots of direct attention, had company members taking class with her so she could watch them up close working on every detail, and felt she was able to gain real ground on the aspects of her technique that challenge her. She also was thrilled to take class with Africa Guzman, Principal Dancer from Compania Nacional de Danza in Madrid, Spain. Ms. Guzman was the muse of Nacho Duato, a thrilling contemporary choreographer, and she taught Sylvani's class several short pieces of Mr. Duato's choreography. She is energetic and joyful, and Sylvani felt lifted by the experience. Ms. Guzman is expected to return this summer to OBT. 
Sylvani was also very excited to learn that she had caught the eye of both the OBT academy's Director, Anthony Jones, who taught some of her classes, and the OBT Company Artistic Director, Kevin Irving, who often observed classes.

The Choice for age 17 is Oregon Ballet Theater...The Journey Continues... but getting SO close! 

Sylvani  was accepted to all the intensives she auditioned for (Boston Ballet, Texas Ballet Theater, American Ballet Theater, Joffrey and OBT).  Joffrey and OBT were her "first" choice--for different reasons.  
Though she would love to go to both, their main intensives overlap dates, and of course, there is the money. So, Sylvani's choice for this summer is OBT. 
Here's why:
  • Placement Level: OBT has placed Sylvani in their top, Pre-professional level. This means she will dance with the best students OBT has, get the highest level of instruction, and even possibly have company members taking class alongside her.
  • Second Company: Oregon Ballet Theater has a "second company"--OBT2--an entry level scholarship year-round performance and training group that performs with the main company in larger productions and also has their own performances. Students in the top level at OBT's summer intensive for at least 4, and preferably 6 weeks are considered for this amazing opportunity. Current and former professionals who know Sylvani are telling us she has a very good chance of being chosen! 
  • Personal Attention/Smaller classes: OBT offers a smaller program, so there is much more personal attention. Every dancer has her technique challenges, whether it is faster turns or higher jumps. Sylvani felt that she received more direct corrections at OBT than elsewhere. 
  • Closer to Home for Year-Round Training: While this is just tentative, it may be time for her to move to a company's year-round academy. She may be able to graduate high school early next year, and OBT is in Portland, two hours from us, and where the rest of our family lives.  
Sylvani feels OBT's full 6 week program will push her skills to their highest level yet, and give her what she needs to actually begin her dance career in the next two years! 

Talent, Drive, Dedication, What Else Does She Need?....$$$!!!

This training is  very necessary, but also very expensive, and I cannot afford it without your help. Sylvani has been blessed with so many opportunities, and has worked so hard all these years...she is nearly there! I wish I could just pay this for my daughter, but my income is limited and I'm helping to support an adult daughter with chronic disabling conditions, as well as now her little baby (my granddaughter!), and I'm also the sole income for our family at home. Sylvani works hard, and has a real chance at a dance career--she is just a year or two away, so this summer is very important. I'm able to help some, but must turn to you for help. After all these years, if Sylvani couldn't continue, well..that would break my heart, and it would also mean that we might not ever know what all that passion can become...Please help Sylvani continue her journey.

What we Need

Here's the Cost Breakdown:

  • 6 weeks Tuition: $2205
  • Room and Board: $3100
  • 8 pairs of pointe shoes, 5 leotards, 6 pairs of tights: $670
  • There are myriad other costs that add up, but we are not including them here.

Full Cost: $5975

Subtractions we've already been able to make: 
  • -$500 from my tax refund
  • -$1000 (2 weeks housing at Grandma and Grandpa's in Portland)
  • Applied for OBT scholarship: Hope to receive $1000
  • We received a direct contribution from Mike Jones, a longtime friend and supporter, and the campaign amount was reduced by $100 by Indiegogo because he made that contribution on another campaign.

Total: $3375

Will you please contribute to the goal of $3375, to Help Sylvani Dance?

If, we do not reach our goal, we will still put any money raised towards Sylvani's dance training...perhaps with a shorter time at OBT or extra lessons in Portland or at home. 
If we go OVER our goal, it may be possible for Sylvani to also go to Joffrey for 3 weeks!  Or to take extra lessons while at OBT. 

What You Get...

Contributions of ANY dollar amount will be gratefully received, and Sylvani will send you "perks" based on your contribution:                                                                                   

Photos of Sylvani as Snow White, A poster of her dancing in front of a fountain in Seattle, handwritten "Thank you" cards, refrigerator magnets, signed pointe shoes, even a desk calendar or photo book! All signed by Sylvani to thank you for your financial support. You can see all perks on the sidebar of this campaign.     

Most of all, you receive the knowledge that you have helped make a Dancer! Imagine how you will feel one day, if you get to see Sylvani dance on a stage, knowing that YOU helped her get there! 

Other Ways You Can Help...

We understand that not everyone has money to give. We would be grateful for even $1, because every single step counts!  
  • But if you simply cannot, please consider how you can help us get the word out--Crowdfunding takes a "crowd"! If we get 100 people to give $10 each, then that's $1000!!  And that's over a fourth of the way there! 
  • At the top of the campaign, there are easy to use sharing tools to help you post on Facebook, tweet on Twitter, email, embed a link in your blog, where ever you can share. 
  • You can also share the video at the top of the campaign, direct from YouTube, which has links to this campaign.
  • And always, always, just send your love, comment on the comments page to let Sylvani know you are thinking of her!                                                                     

Thank you so much, your generosity and support mean more than words can express!

 In Gratitude,

Sylvani and Fiora
story_txt:
Dancing Towards the Future...Dreams DO Come True!!

                    
Sylvani stands upon a threshold...she is 17...at the age when pre-professional dancers begin their final steps to their career.  Please help her go to Oregon Ballet Theater's 6-week Summer Ballet Intensive, where she will prepare to launch into her Dream!





The Synopsis: 
(That's "Ballet Talk" for "The Short Version")
Sylvani has known since she was
 3 that she is a Dancer. To Sylvani, dancing is life, dancing is breathing. Dance is where she expresses her soul and touches yours.
This summer, Sylvani is hoping to go to Oregon Ballet Theater's 6-week summer ballet intensive, where she will be in the top level, and offered a possible opportunity to dance professionally with their second company!!!

Please will you help her meet the cost of this program? Any contribution helps!Sylvani has been training, both at her home studio in Eugene, Oregon Ballet Academy, since she was 3, and also at wonderful summer 
intensives (Joffrey Ballet, Oregon Ballet Theater, Texas Ballet Theater, and Whitman Summer Dance Lab) each year since she was 13. Sylvani has been honored to dance 
lead roles in her studio's Fall ballet productions. She has occasionally 
been invited to dance in other venues as well. Her artistry, her 
musicality and her beauty in story telling are evident to any who watch her. 
Audience members have told us that they can't take their eyes off Sylvani when she dances! Sylvani's devotion to Dance, as an art form that transforms those who witness it as well as the dancer herself, is core to everything she does.    
                       
Sylvani spends over 20
 hours every week in dance class during the school year--after school and on weekends. Even more when rehearsing for a performance. But aspiring professional dancers must go to summer intensives with a ballet company: 5-6 weeks of dancing all day, 40 hours a week or more, at a ballet company academy, with current professionals, company faculty, and guest artists helping to further refine and strengthen her technique, giving insight into careers, and making connections for her future. It's hard, rigorous work...and it's what Sylvani loves. 
The audition process is rigorous and competitive, only about 10% of dancers are even accepted during national audition tours. Sylvani regularly is not only accepted, but offered some level of scholarship.This past winter, Sylvani auditioned for several summer intensives, with her most desired ones being Joffrey Ballet and Oregon Ballet Theater.                                  
Age 17, for a dancer, is time to make one's final launch plans for a ballet company apprenticeship and then a career. She essentially has one more year to go before auditioning for company apprenticeships and trainee positions. After much consideration, she has decided that Oregon Ballet Academy is her best step this summer. Here's why:

She is already placed in OBT's top, pre-professional level.

It is close to home, with family members in town, so less cost and also easier possibility of immediately moving there for year-round training.

4-6 week attendees have an chance to be picked for OBT2, OBT's second company. 

Most important: The personal attention and smaller classes she found at OBT, in their top level with company members taking class with her, will help her really fine tune, giving her the edge she feels she still needs to be ready for Joffrey's top professional level in next summer's intensive, and to audition for either company the following fall!

Sylvani has a big dream, and she has thoughtfully decided that OBT's program will get her there.
"I have come to understand that dancers emit a speech-- a song-- through their bodies. I think that Oregon Ballet Theater's summer intensive could help me learn to facilitate that within myself.  As I have grown up and changed and become aware of so much of the world around me-- the breakthroughs and the barriers, the struggles between humans and nature, especially between humans and other humans-- I have found how dance itself has matured into an agent of change. The nuances of movement can convey such rich and intense emotions that they can completely transport an audience, which I have experienced at OBT performances. I understand that ballet is extremely competitive, and opportunities to get one's pointed foot in the door are rare, but I hope that with the proper training, and a great opportunity like OBT2 (OBT's second company) to work for, I could have a shot." --Sylvani
The Cost Breakdown:


6 weeks Tuition: $2205
Room and Board: $3100
8 pairs of pointe shoes, 5 leotards, 6 pairs of tights: $670
Full Cost: $5975
Subtractions we've already been able to make: 


-$500 from my tax refund
-$1000 (2 weeks housing at Grandma and Grandpa's in Portland)
Applied for OBT scholarship: Hope to receive $1000  (UPDATE: ACTUALLY RECIEVED $1500!!! we reduced our goal by $500! )  
A friend, Mike Jones, contributed $100 directly through another campaign.

Total: $3375
We were thankfully able to reduce our goal to $2875, because OBT gave Sylvani a $1500 scholarship--$500 more than we'd hoped!  AND WE REACHED THAT GOAL!!! 
But there are still many costs not covered here, so we hope you will still contribute to Help Sylvani Dance! 
If you contribute, check out the wonderful "perks" on the sidebar!  You can also use the "share" tools near the top to help spread the word--"Crowdfunding" takes a crowd!  
Watch this video of Sylvani's transformation in pictures!

Their top level is for 18 year olds and up, who are ready to move into a professional career or an apprenticeship with Joffrey's Studio Company. Sylvani also learned, from Joffrey Artistic Director, Ashley Wheaton, that he prefers to hire dancers who have professional experience with another company. 
Oregon Ballet Theater-- on the Threshold of her Future Journeys...After she returned from Joffrey, Sylvani was also able to attend Oregon Ballet Theater in Portland for 2 weeks.  Both were wonderful in different ways.  She still dreams of being a Joffrey dancer one day, but OBT showed her a path that feels  more "right" to actually achieve that dream, while giving her a company close to home where she can train--perhaps year round--and maybe even dance for! At the OBT intensive, a smaller environment, she received lots of direct attention, had company members taking class with her so she could watch them up close working on every detail, and felt she was able to gain real ground on the aspects of her technique that challenge her. She also was thrilled to take class with Africa Guzman, Principal Dancer from Compania Nacional de Danza in Madrid, Spain. Ms. Guzman was the muse of Nacho Duato, a thrilling contemporary choreographer, and she taught Sylvani's class several short pieces of Mr. Duato's choreography. She is energetic and joyful, and Sylvani felt lifted by the experience. Ms. Guzman is expected to return this summer to OBT. Sylvani was also very excited to learn that she had caught the eye of both the OBT academy's Director, Anthony Jones, who taught some of her classes, and the OBT Company Artistic Director, Kevin Irving, who often observed classes.
The Choice for age 17 is Oregon Ballet Theater...The Journey Continues... but getting SO close! 

Sylvani  was accepted to all the intensives she auditioned for (Boston Ballet, Texas Ballet Theater, American Ballet Theater, Joffrey and OBT).  Joffrey and OBT were her "first" choice--for different reasons.  
Though she would love to go to both, their main intensives overlap dates, and of course, there is the money. So, Sylvani's choice for this summer is OBT. Here's why:

Placement Level: OBT has placed Sylvani in their top, Pre-professional level. This means she will dance with the best students OBT has, get the highest level of instruction, and even possibly have company members taking class alongside her.
Second Company: Oregon Ballet Theater has a "second company"--OBT2--an entry level scholarship year-round performance and training group that performs with the main company in larger productions and also has their own performances. Students in the top level at OBT's summer intensive for at least 4, and preferably 6 weeks are considered for this amazing opportunity. Current and former professionals who know Sylvani are telling us she has a very good chance of being chosen! 
Personal Attention/Smaller classes: OBT offers a smaller program, so there is much more personal attention. Every dancer has her technique challenges, whether it is faster turns or higher jumps. Sylvani felt that she received more direct corrections at OBT than elsewhere. 

Closer to Home for Year-Round Training: While this is just tentative, it may be time for her to move to a company's year-round academy. She may be able to graduate high school early next year, and OBT is in Portland, two hours from us, and where the rest of our family lives.  


Sylvani feels OBT's full 6 week program will push her skills to their highest level yet, and give her what she needs to actually begin her dance career in the next two years! 

Talent, Drive, Dedication, What Else Does She Need?....$$$!!!This training is  very necessary, but also very expensive, and I cannot afford it without your help. Sylvani has been blessed with so many opportunities, and has worked so hard all these years...she is nearly there! I wish I could just pay this for my daughter, but my income is limited and I'm helping to support an adult daughter with chronic disabling conditions, as well as now her little baby (my granddaughter!), and I'm also the sole income for our family at home. Sylvani works hard, and has a real chance at a dance career--she is just a year or two away, so this summer is very important. I'm able to help some, but must turn to you for help. After all these years, if Sylvani couldn't continue, well..that would break my heart, and it would also mean that we might not ever know what all that passion can become...Please help Sylvani continue her journey.

What we Need
Here's the Cost Breakdown:


6 weeks Tuition: $2205
Room and Board: $3100
8 pairs of pointe shoes, 5 leotards, 6 pairs of tights: $670
There are myriad other costs that add up, but we are not including them here.



Full Cost: $5975

Subtractions we've already been able to make: 


-$500 from my tax refund
-$1000 (2 weeks housing at Grandma and Grandpa's in Portland)
Applied for OBT scholarship: Hope to receive $1000
We received a direct contribution from Mike Jones, a longtime friend and supporter, and the campaign amount was reduced by $100 by Indiegogo because he made that contribution on another campaign.

Total: $3375
Will you please contribute to the goal of $3375, to Help Sylvani Dance?
If, we do not reach our goal, we will still put any money raised towards Sylvani's dance training...perhaps with a shorter time at OBT or extra lessons in Portland or at home. 
If we go OVER our goal, it may be possible for Sylvani to also go to Joffrey for 3 weeks!  Or to take extra lessons while at OBT. 

What You Get...

Contributions of ANY dollar amount will be gratefully received, and Sylvani will send you "perks" based on your contribution:                                                                                   
Photos of Sylvani as Snow White, A poster of her dancing in front of a fountain in Seattle, handwritten "Thank you" cards, refrigerator magnets, signed pointe shoes, even a desk calendar or photo book! All signed by Sylvani to thank you for your financial support. You can see all perks on the sidebar of this campaign.     
Most of all, you receive the knowledge that you have helped make a Dancer! Imagine how you will feel one day, if you get to see Sylvani dance on a stage, knowing that YOU helped her get there!   Other Ways You Can Help...
We understand that not everyone has money to give. We would be grateful for even $1, because every single step counts!    But if you simply cannot, please consider how you can help us get the word out--Crowdfunding takes a "crowd"! If we get 100 people to give $10 each, then that's $1000!!  And that's over a fourth of the way there! 
At the top of the campaign, there are easy to use sharing tools to help you post on Facebook, tweet on Twitter, email, embed a link in your blog, where ever you can share. 
You can also share the video at the top of the campaign, direct from YouTube, which has links to this campaign.

And always, always, just send your love, comment on the comments page to let Sylvani know you are thinking of her!                                                                     


Thank you so much, your generosity and support mean more than words can express! In Gratitude,Sylvani and Fiora

story:
We Are IRTE

Hello and welcome to IRTE's 2017 Season fundraising campaign!

We are the Improvisational Repertory Theatre Ensemble, a New York City-based, award-winning company of improvisational actors, producers, and creators of original, character-driven, improvisational comedy theater. Over the past five years we have conceived, developed, created, and performed about two dozen distinct productions.

In 2017, we embark on our sixth season, and we're excited to bring to our audiences 4 very different productions, including 3 brand new shows: The Sense-ations!, The Experiment, and Avoidance!; and for the first time ever, a sequel to last season's hilarious original show - Big, Rich & Powerful - BRP II !

 

IRTE 2017 Ensemble

Robert Baumgardner, Jamie Maloney, William Berg, Nannette Deasy, Curt Dixon

 

Your Contributions Make a Difference

Just as large performing arts organizations all over the country depend on contributions from an ever-expanding pool of committed sponsors, IRTE counts on the support of our audience not just at the theater attending our shows, but also as champions of our success behind the scenes as financial contributors.

At IRTE, we tend to each and every aspect of producing a full season of original theatrical productions. This includes renting rehearsal and performance space, paying directors and tech crew, promoting our shows, attending festivals both in New York City and out of state, insurance and overhead, etc.

Thanks to the generous support of people like you, IRTE has continued to prosper year after year in the very competitive theater market that is New York City. Never underestimate the value of even the smallest contribution you can make!

IRTE 2017 is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of IRTE 2017 must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

 

The Nitty-Gritty of the Numbers

It's going to cost us about $8,500 to mount our 2017 season - four original productions, four performances each. Add to that rehearsals to get us to where we need to be to produce the professional quality improvised theater that we love to create and share with our audience.

In 2016, our total expenses came to $6,729 for four productions. Inflation, right? This year, while the cost for rehearsal space remains the same ($240), our theater rental and tech costs have increased from $820 last year to $1,020 this year. Plus, for 2017, we've hired a fantastic PR company to promote our entire season, so we can continue to expand our audience and share what we love to do with even more people. 

Here's a handy pie-chart to illustrate how we covered our expenses last year.

That 13% shortfall comes to about $875. We'd love your support in making that disappear!

 

How Do We Do It?

Producing independent, improvised theater in New York City isn't easy, but we're entering our sixth season of doing it, and we're getting better and better every year. Although our core company is made up of the five folks you see pictured above, we certainly don't do it alone. Over the years we've cultivated strong working relationships with a wide variety of actors, musicians, directors, and people with expertise in technical and promotional fields that help make the whole thing function beautifully, not to mention making it a lot more fun!

Each of our productions features excellent improvisational actors beyond the ranks of our ensemble - we call them GIRTEs, or Guests of IRTE - to help us round out the cast. Every show also features a different local musical guest who we invite to perform during our musical break. Sometimes we even weave that musician's performance into the story we're creating. Hey, that's improv! Either way, it's a great opportunity for these talented musicians to share their music with a new audience.

Theater is truly a collaborative creation that demands the patience, skill, passion and talent of countless people, including (especially) those people we call our audience. Without you in the theater with us, we'd be up there playing just for ourselves. Likewise, without your generous contributions (of any amount) we'd have a much harder time doing what we do, and we'd have fewer opportunities to share it with other people, performers and audience members alike.

 

Our 2017 Season!

The five of us at IRTE got together and struggled through the daunting task of paring down 36 excellent show pitches to the 4 we're presenting in our regular season this year. We are all very excited about the variety of ideas we're going to shape into full-fledged productions. Here they are!

 

 

 

Visit our website for more IRTE info and to purchase tickets, season passes and more! Like this t-ShIRTE (also available as one of our Perks)!

And Now...Some Awards and a Few Kind Words...

  • Winner: 2014 SHITFA (Supreme Honorary Improvised Theater & Film Award) from Unscripted New York Improvised Theatre and Film Festival
  • Winner: “Artists Whose Work Made Me Laugh The Most” Award at the 2017 Asheville Fringe Arts Festival
  • Nominated for Outstanding MITF/Variety Performance for DIG at the Midtown International Theatre Festival
  • Awarded ﻿Certification of Appreciation, Arts Connection

Since 1979, ArtsConnection has provided innovative arts programming to millions of students in the New York City public school system, enhancing children’s intellectual, personal and social growth, while developing award-winning educational models. ArtsConnection’s programming for students, professional development, and research all contribute to a comprehensive approach, nationally recognized for its quality, design and impact across diverse learning communities.

IRTE is a proud partner of High 5 Tickets to the Arts, ArtsConnection's resource for young people to experience the best dance, music, theater, film, and visual arts New York City (and sometimes New Jersey and Westchester!) has to offer.

"The newest production from IRTE (Improvisational Repertory Theatre Ensemble) rehashes all of the awkward, hilarious, unforgettable shenanigans that occur whenever families get together to celebrate... an unforgettably entertaining evening." - Catherine Santino, Spoiled NYC, Laugh-Your-A$$-Off-Funny: Check Out These 2 Can’t-Miss Comedy Shows in NYC

﻿"Big, Rich, Powerful...and FUNNY!" - Inola McGuire, Drama Queens

"...surprise-a-minute..." - Jay Lloyd, CBS Philly, KYW News Radio

"Big, Rich and Powerful was a soap-opera style comedy... that was truly worth watching... They captured the idea of the late night drama beautifully and pulled you right in with humor and ingenuity.... astonishing." - Emmy Pai, Outerstage, Big, Rich and TALENTED people

 "IRTE is a cutting edge improv group" - ﻿Theatre has its Goddesses: Women making a difference off-off Broadway

 

Ways You Can Show Your Support

  • Donate NOW - Every contribution makes a big difference, no matter the size!
  • Help spread the word - Share this campaign with others!
  • Come see our shows - We'd love to see (and hear) you in the audience!
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, ... or around town!
  • Join in on the fun - let us know if you'd like to work box office or tech for us and see the show for free!

story:
If you don't know about Rachel Brice-

Please enjoy this clip of her and Datura at Tribal Fest 13

 

 

8 Elements™ Intensive 1: Initiation

I need your help, pretty please...!

My name is Valerie Bravo Woodruff and I am currently a FatChanceBellyDance® Sister Studio and teach American Tribal Style® Belly Dance in Colorado Springs, CO on the weekends. My passion for learning and teaching dance makes me a perpetual student. In order for me to become the best teacher, I must take my education further by studying with the best of the best. I have a full time day job that recently cut my hours and now I am having a hard time paying my way for this Intensive in March 2014.

 I typically do not like asking for help, as I pride myself in paying my own way. However, my passion for dance is setting my pride aside- I really would like to take advantage of this rare and much sought after opportunity. I have a desire to study Tribal Fusion with Rachel Brice so that I have a better understanding of it. I want to improve my movement quality. I also want to help Tribal Fusion students that are now learning ATS® belly dance differentiate the Tribal Fusion movements rooted from the ATS® vocabulary.

I believe in challenging myself and my students. By studying Tribal Fusion and diving deep into choreography, history, and music theory, I will definitely advance my dance knowledge.

If my goal for this campaign is not met, the money contributed will go to furthering my American Tribal Style® Belly Dance knowledge at the FatChanceBellyDance® Studio in San Francisco, California

 

What I need and really don't want to ask for

The Breakdown of what I need:

  • $320 for the 2nd installment for tuition for 8 Elements™ Intensive 1: Initiation Rachel Brice's Eight Elements Initiation
  • $500 for the round-trip flight from Colorado Springs to Portland
  • $680 for lodging for 6 nights at the Paramount Hotel - not including meals

Every little bit helps

Seriously, I can't thank you enough.

  • Your contribution brings me closer to my goal
  • Because of you, I will be able to study with Rachel Brice, a Master Instructor of Tribal Fusion belly dance
  • Sharing my campaign helps spread the word, bringing me closer to my goal!

Thank you so much for your love and generosity! I appreciate you!

story:
Hi, we are KissBang,

a new London-based company of young, talented (starving) theatre professionals.

Having already produced new writing and devised work, we are now embarking on our first production of an established play, The Star-Spangled Girl by Neil Simon.

One of Simon’s less produced plays, this frantic 1960’s farce is screaming for a revival. It’s hilariously funny, relentlessly energetic, deliciously witty, and best of all – it’s RETRO!

Set in a shabby San Francisco apartment/publication office, the story revolves around the desperate attempts of would-be revolutionary magazine editor Andy to reach his publication deadline, while his best (and only) writer Norman is rendered completely useless by falling head-over-heels for their new All-American-Olympic-swimmer next door neighbour.

The play will be on from 28th April till 18th May at the new and exciting Ophelia theatre in Dalston.

 

Why we really do need your support

Currently this production is completely self-funded and as we’ve already established, we are but young (starving) artists. This venture will involve many expenses we will not be able to cover without your support. Your money will go towards:

*Paying for performance rights

*Securing the venue

*Hiring rehearsal space

*Production design (set, props, costume)

*Printing PR materials and advertising

Apart from our eternal love and great karma, every contributor will receive a little special something from us, from programme thank-yous and signed posters to free tickets and drinks vouchers.

 

Support us in bringing this wonderful play to life and give emerging talent the opportunity to shine.

We plan to see our company grow and produce lots more of highly entertaining, artistically valuable work. With your help we can make it happen.

story:
****PLEASE SEE THE GALLERY TAB FOR VIDEOS AND PICTURES*****

What do mermaids, church hats, Godzilla, and Patti LaBelle have in common? They are all in the script of my new play – Self Portrait.

I am Sasha Sinclair and I am an artist. Art was not encouraged in my family. But looking back art was all around me - in the people, places and experiences that influenced me, nurtured me and comforted me. Art gave me an outlet to express myself and to develop a strong sense of self-worth through good and bad times.  Self Portrait is the story of that journey.

 Self Portrait is a semi-autobiographical solo play that uses humor and drama to explore how life, death, family, and place have shaped who I am as an artist.  The play employs a combination of spoken word poetry, musical performance, and digital imagery to enhance the storytelling.

I need your help to bring this play to the stage. The money raised will go to pay the director, stage manager, ops board, tech and stage crew. Also I need assistance with funding printing, advertising, photography and videography. Phew! It adds up.

In exchange for your generous support, I am offering  perks. They include:

·  An autographed Self Portrait script 

·  Signed art prints

·  Art and sewing lessons

·  National Gallery of Art docent tours

·  Commissioned works of art

·  …and much more (see details by clicking on the Gallery tab above)

This play will make its world premiere at the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival – but only with your help.  If you are unable to contribute at this time, then please be an ambassador for the play. Reach out to everyone you know and tell them about the fundraiser and encourage them to give. Thanks in advance you for your support!

Cheers!

Sasha

"Singing Down the night" - the signed 8"x10" art print donors will receive with at least at $50 donation.

****PLEASE SEE THE GALLERY TAB FOR VIDEOS AND PICTURES*****

In exchange for your generous support, I am offering  perks. They include:
· 
An autographed Self Portrait script 
· 
Signed art prints
· 
Art and sewing lessons
·  National Gallery of Art docent tours
· 
Commissioned works of art
· 
…and much more (see details by clicking on the Gallery tab above)
This play will make its world premiere at the
2014 Capital Fringe Festival – but only with your help.  If you are unable to contribute at this time, then
please be an ambassador for the play. Reach out to everyone you know and tell
them about the fundraiser and encourage them to give. Thanks in advance you for your support!
Cheers!
Sasha"Singing Down the night" - the signed 8"x10" art print donors will receive with at least at $50 donation.

****PLEASE SEE THE GALLERY TAB FOR VIDEOS AND PICTURES*****

story:
about may violets spring

MAY VIOLETS SPRING is a new play adapted primarily from Shakespeare's Hamlet but featuring many of the Bard of Avon's other plays and sonnets, along with the introduction of original verse by James Parenti. Produced by Dare Lab and directed by Reesa Graham, this production focuses on Ophelia's journey as a protagonist through the canon events of Hamlet. It's a love letter to classical heroines slighted by the narratives of our past and too often also in productions of the present.

The play will run this upcoming April 16th through April 27th, 2014 at The Bridge Theatre in Shetler Studios and we need your help!


our budget

For full transparency, you'll find laid out below everything that's going into our budget for this production. You may notice that our goal is much lower than the total cost. This is because the main purpose of this Indiegogo is to pay our actors and crew. We'd absolutely love to receive more funding towards our other production costs; it's every production's dream to break even!  But the most important thing to Dare Lab is that those putting their hearts and souls and precious time into bringing May Violets Spring to life be compensated to the best of our abilities.

$2500.00 (actors and crew)
$2000.00 (theatre space)
$1500.00 (rehearsal space)
  $200.00 (promotion)
  $200.00 (costumes)
  $100.00 (set)
___________________________
$6500.00 (total)



the perks

First and foremost, anyone that contributes towards May Violets Spring will be featured and thanked in our program.  There are levels!

  • $1-$99: You will be listed as Daisy level donor in our program.
  • $100-$299: You will be listed as a Rosemary level donor in our program.
  • $300 and up: You will be listed as a Violet level donor in our program.
We've also dreamed up a ton of creative perks to thank you for helping us bring this production to the stage, which you can find to the right!


a note from the playwright

The whole idea in the first place was to do Hamlet, plain and simple. But in doing the work of preparing the role, I became excited and frustrated by Ophelia's place in the story and in the world of Denmark. What was her relationship with Hamlet like? How much did she know about the Ghost and its accusations? What did she see that drove her mad?

And so she shared the soliloquies. Lines were cut and re-assigned so that they became conversations: Ophelia talking Hamlet into bating the King with a play, the two of them debating the nature of mortality, and so on. And once she had this new life, her story became more interesting to me than his. It quickly became very clear that Ophelia was the heroine of a new story running parallel to Hamlet's.

The completed text of the play is a collage of Hamlet, my own verse, and a number of other plays in the canon: The Winter's Tale, Twelfth Night, Richard II, Othello, King Lear, The Tempest, Love's Labour's Lost, Romeo and Juliet, All's Well That Ends Well, and Cymbeline, to name a few. Lovers of Shakespeare will find the words of their favorite plays echoed here, finding new and rich resonance from being placed in a new context. It's my hope, though, that the piece flows seamlessly and stands alone as a completely new piece of theatre, which tells the story of a young woman fighting to make her own place in the world.

James


a note from the director

When James first approached me about directing May Violets Spring, I was excited. I knew he had been working on it for awhile, and I loved where he was taking the story. The first version of the script I heard was MUCH different than the one now, as he tinkered and added and tried to figure out what story he was telling.  

The story he told is one that desperately needs telling - May Violets Spring is, quite simply, the story of a woman finding her place in the world. Parenti uses the lens of Hamlet and his world, a story most are at least vaguely familiar with, to take a journey with this young woman who has to step out of what she believed she should do and be, what society told her she should do and be, and find out what she thinks she should do and be. It's a story that could not be more relevant in 2014, and one that should be told louder and more often than it actually is being told. I am so thankful to be part of telling that story. Wouldn't you like to be part of telling that story, too?

Reesa

story:
Overview: blarg Theatre will produce a full-length production of “Sorry, Please Try Again” an original play by Newfoundland playwright Martin Poole at Raymonds Restaurant in June 2014.

Along with the play there will be a secret exhibit by artist Mike Mouland, a short film by Michael Daly, and an experimental musical intro by Geoffrey Hewett.

Similar to blarg’s debut production of HOUS in September, 2013 we will use our surroundings as our stage. While our primary focus for this project is theatre, the aim of blarg Theatre is to facilitate artistic growth in Newfoundland and Labrador by combining multidisciplinary practices into unforgettable experiences.

Funding for this project will go towards professional actor fees, fees for helpers, and stage rental.

story:
The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on 
fighting the old, but on building the new.

-Socrates


A Bit About Portal Theatre and No Belles

Well, we might as well start out with what this campaign is really all about:  we need your support and funds to help us get our show to Edinburgh!  Your support enables our vision to become a reality.  Please donate to Portal Theatre!  (And, it's tax deductible!)

We are thrilled to tell you a bit about ourselves, and our new show, No Belles.  And, to ask for your help. 

So, here's the question that we started with:  what do you do if you want to face your fears, build something new, and create good art?  

Portal Theatre is a new company which focuses on original works on a broad (and fun!) range of topics.  We're based in Oregon.  When we started the company, we really wanted to make an impact with our very first outing.  Go big or go home, right?  So, we're going big (and, we need your help!) by taking our very first show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.  Did I mention that we need your help?

Our show is No Belles, which tells the stories of some remarkable women scientists.  Here's a statistic you should care about:  out of the 566 individual people who have won Nobel Prizes in the sciences, only 15 have been women.  Only fifteen!  That's less than 3%. And, most of them you've probably never heard of.  Hearing their stories will open your eyes to the passion and dedication of these women, and the very real changes and benefits they've brought to your life.  (We're also including some women that didn't win the Prize, but maybe should have).  

We're so happy to be performing the show this summer at the Sweet Grassmarket venue at the Edinburgh Fringe, the largest arts festival in the world.  It's a great opportunity.  But, we need your help.  As you can imagine, it's expensive to take a show to the Fringe.  See below for more details about our budget, and how you can help us out by donating to the cause!

What We Need & What You Get

This show represents a real investment in the future of the company.  We (obviously) believe in the arts, but it's a reality that no theatre company can exist without the support of friends who believe in it.  We're inviting you to join us in this grand adventure by giving, in whatever amount you can, in support of the company and our trip to Edinburgh.  Here are some details:

  • We've included our full budget below, but for this campaign we're essentially looking to cover the cost of flights for the five company members from Portland to Edinburgh - about $7,500.  That's not nearly the entire cost of the project, but it represents a significant expense.
  • We've got a number of nice perks for you, depending on the amount given!  Just check out the right side of this page for all the details.  Please note:  any gifts that are mailed out will be sent in early September, after we return from Scotland.  
  • So, what happens if the amount raised is below (or above) the requested amount?  We're using Flexible Funding for the campaign, which means that even if we don't quite reach the goal, any funds raised will still be put to good use!  And, if we raise more than our stated goal of $7,500, so much the better!  (See the budget below for the total costs of the project.)
  • Finally, we operate under a 501c3, which means that your gifts are tax deductible!  (Portal Theatre is associated with Western Oregon University, who will process all of our donations.)  Win/win, right?

The Budget

Your contribution, in whatever amount, is really important to us.  And, we thank you in advance for believing in the company, the show, and for your support for the arts.  We couldn't do it without you.  For your info, below is a breakdown of our budget.  Some of it is still estimates (advertising and printing, for example) since we haven't paid for that yet.  But, everything else is pretty darned accurate.

  • Venue rental at the Edinburgh Fringe:  $4,660
  • Housing for the company in Edinburgh:  $7,699
  • Flights for 5 to Edinburgh:  $7920
  • Fringe Fees:  $494
  • Marketing, Advertising and Printing (approx.):  $1,125
  • Subtotal:  $21,898
We've received an initial grant of $3,500, and, of course, we will be selling tickets for the show at the Fringe.  Given the average, we think we can make about $7,000 in ticket sales.  (It could be more or less.)  So, that means:
  • Subtotal:  $21,898
  • Grant:  -$3,500
  • Estimated ticket sales:  -$7,000
  • Outstanding Costs:  $11,398

    Other Ways You Can Help

    So, we're asking for your help.  Any contribution you can make is very, very appreciated, and will be put to good use putting on the best show possible at the Fringe this year.  

    But, we also realize that some of you may not be able to give financially.  No problem!  There are other ways you can really help us out:

    • Get the word out to friends and family who may be interested and have the means to support the project.  In other words, make some noise about our campaign!  Send the page link out, announce us to friends on Facebook, etc.  You know how this works, so help us work it!
    • There are also a number of Indiegogo share tools on this page!  They're very handy in spreading the word.  So, please, whether you can personally give financially or not, help us out by sending our campaign far and wide!  
    • Finally, go to our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/opentheportal and "Like" us!  There, you'll be able to keep up with what we're doing throughout the Fringe.  And, look for us on Instagram under #portaltheatre, where we'll be posting lots of photos from Edinburgh.

    From the bottom of our boots, thank you so much for any support you can give to Portal Theatre and our show, No Belles.

Get the word out to friends and family who may be interested and have the means to support the project.  In other words, make some noise about our campaign!  Send the page link out, announce us to friends on Facebook, etc.  You know how this works, so help us work it! There are also a number of Indiegogo share tools on this page!  They're very handy in spreading the word.  So, please, whether you can personally give financially or not, help us out by sending our campaign far and wide!  
Finally, go to our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/opentheportal and "Like" us!  There, you'll be able to keep up with what we're doing throughout the Fringe.  And, look for us on Instagram under #portaltheatre, where we'll be posting lots of photos from Edinburgh.

story:
By Jove Theatre Company is a London based theatre ensemble that re-works myth, legend and stories from the cultural canon for 21st century Britain.  Founded in 2011, the company has pursued a number of different projects including a feminist reinterpretation of Aeschylus' Oresteia and a pantomime version of Jane Austen's classic novel Pride and Prejudice. 

Othello is By Jove's first venture into Shakespeare and allows us to tackle some of the most pressing issues facing Britain today.  Shakespeare's classic play about prejudice, passion and betrayal is re-worked against the backdrop of the debate surrounding Britain's recent same sex marriage bill.  Othello is recast as a lesbian working in Britain's military and she is about to enter into one of Britain's first same sex marriages. Featuring new text in creative tension with Shakespeare's dialogue we retell this tale to ask questions about how misogyny, homophobia and racism can collude to bring about an all too real tragedy.  As a company we are committed to raising awareness of important political issues facing us today including domestic violence, cultural homophobia and systemic racism. We believe this project addresses all three. 

The money raised through Indiegogo will go towards the purchase of essential props, costumes and set pieces. This will make all the difference in allowing us to create a compelling piece of theatre and illustrate this story as best as possible.  At this point in the production we have assigned £200 to costume, £200 to set and £100 to props, as guidelines figures within the overall £500.  However, the exact distribution may change as the project develops. 

We offer a range of perks to our sponsors. With a donation of £50 or more, you will not only receive two tickets to the play, you will also be invited to attend our press and publicity evening on August 12th. This includes a drinks reception and an opportunity to mingle with the cast, crew, industry professionals and members of the press. 

Your contribution would not only mean the world to us, and make all the difference to our production, but would help support emerging artists in an industry where funding is scarce. 

Praise for By Jove:

'By Jove theatre company are one to watch.' Broadway World

'Absolutely fantastic ... I enjoyed every second.' Everything Theatre, on By Jove's Pride & Prejudice: The Panto 

'An ingenious production'. A Younger Theatre, on By Jove's Pride & Prejudice: The Panto

story:
Dear friends and dance lovers,

 Since 2008, Aura Fischbeck Dance has been creating and presenting original dance theater work in the San Francisco Bay area.  And we are at it again!  We are currently in process creating our newest dance theater production, entitled Time Studies, which will premier at the Joe Goode Annex in San Francisco,  September 12-14, 2014, alongside the amazing Deborah Karp Dance Projects. 

About the work:

Time Studies contemplates the nature of time as both a subjective and relative
experience. Inspired by the seeming quickening of time passing in this modern age of technological inertia,Time Studies asks the question “are we keeping time, or is it keeping us?” and positions the moving body at the center of this question. Drawing inspiration from scientific, metaphysical and mythological
perspectives Time Studies utilizes task based processes, changing physical states and durational experiments as choreographic devices, each of which reveals something about the way time is translated through the moving body.  This new work features performances by Arletta Anderson, Caroline Alexander, Aura Fischbeck and Alison Williams, lighting design by Delayne Medoff, and set design by Christopher Wise. 

Why we need your support:

In the same way that the creation of a work of art is often a collaboration with many people giving of themselves in service of one vision, funding artistic projects in this economic climate functions much in the same way.  With the current state of arts funding being so limited, grassroots fundraising has become an indispensable component of the way creative projects are able to thrive.  

This is where you come in! 

We need your help to make this project possible and to continue to sustain our work as a thriving independent San Francisco based dance company!

We are undergoing this fundraising effort  to ensure that the participating artists get compensated for their time and energy and creative genius, as well as to offset the plethora of production costs such as rehearsal space rental, theater rental, publicity, and costumes, to name a few.

Please consider being a part of our artistic collaboration by helping us to meet our fundraising goals!  We would reach our goal if:

  • 200 people gave $15
  • 100 people gave $30
  • 50 people gave $60
  • 25 people gave $120
We hope you will consider making a donation to Aura Fischbeck Dance to support this and future projects.  A little bit goes a long way, and every little bit counts.

Our sincere gratitude and appreciation,

Aura Fischbeck and the collaborating artists

For more information on Aura Fischbeck Dance visit www.aurafischbeck.com

50 people gave $60
25 people gave $120

We hope you will consider making a donation to Aura Fischbeck Dance to support this and future projects.  A little bit goes a long way, and every little bit counts. Our sincere gratitude and appreciation,Aura Fischbeck and the collaborating artistsFor more information on Aura Fischbeck Dance visit www.aurafischbeck.com

story:
BENEFIT CONCERT for the show

Come check out our good friends PigPen, nest+rest, and Jacob Martin at our Benefit Concert on April 19th!

Come for the music, stay for the great company, cheap drinks, free food, silent auction, and more. Get your VIP tickets (free drinks all night!) right now by donating here!

   Thursday April 19th, 8pm

   26-15 Jackson Ave., Long Island City (E,M,7,G trains to Court Sq.)

   $15 suggested donation


ROMEO and JULIET

Empirical Rogue has teamed up with chashama to produce a revolutionary, four-actor Romeo and Juliet in an exciting, never-performed-in, abandoned space in Long Island City. 

Just one block from Court Square (E,M,7,G trains), 26-15 Jackson Avenue was emptied out less than a year ago to be demolished for a new highrise (the 50-story Citigroup building is right next door). The space is still empty, and chashama has opened it up for our explosive version of Romeo and Juliet to run May 19th through June 10th.

Romance, politics, fighting, revenge, passion, music, and revolution. 

Oh, and cheap drinks!






 

THE IMPACT

Romeo and Juliet is about what it takes to change the world, and what happens when people have the courage to do that. We're trying to do the same thing, and so their story is our story. And yours.

1,500 people will experience this production. We're going to bring friends, artists, students, businesspeople, families, kids, and YOU to this space. We're going to perform this piece sixteen times. And then after two months, it will all come down.

We're going to completely reinvent this space with our Romeo and Juliet. In a few years, the building will be demolished. And another highrise will go up.

Help us make this Romeo and Juliet happen, and let's cherish an opportunity to change the world. They don't come along often!



WHAT'S IN IT FOR YOU?

Check out all the perks to the right. Seats, VIP tickets, Limited Edition merchandise, Producing credits, etc. etc.

We want you to come see this thing, and we want you to take pride in having helped out.

We'll give you some stuff to show off, and we'll treat you right!



SO WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

Rent

Our space is curated by chashama, a not-for-profit that finds abandoned spaces all around New York City and rents them to artists. An average 65-seat theater in New York City rents for around $2500-$3500 per week. 

We're renting our chashama space for two solid months for just $3,000.   Total!

That means we'll rehearse, build, tech, and perform, all in the same space. The accumulated creativity and energy will be astounding.


 

Materials

We're lighting, costuming, building, and propping this bad boy in the most bare-bones, downtown, elbow-grease way possible.

We've all spent time in New York, Moscow, New Haven, Boston, and Seattle doing this kind of ground-up theater. It's cheap, it's dirty, it's exhilarating, and it creates the rawest, most powerful stuff you will ever see.


Food Money!

Everyone that works on this production will get a paycheck. Each one is modest, and they're all about the same amount.

There are four brilliant Actors, one excellent Musician, a Producer/Director, a Production Designer, an Associate Production Designer, a Technical Director, a Costume Designer, a Fight Director, a Stage Manager, an Assistant Stage Manager, a House Manager, and a Press Representative. All of them are essential, and most of them are taking on extra duties.

That's a 15-person team, working for less than minimum wage, to bring you an unforgettable experience.


 

Students

We want to bring this show to local NYC-area high-school students. We want to bring them to the space to experience the most cutting-edge, avant-garde classical theater happening. Then, we want to bring our actors and creative staff into schools to teach them about our new take on Shakespeare and this play.

With your help, we can make this show not only a brilliant artistic success, but an invaluable educational tool.

 



OTHER WAYS TO HELP

 

Go to our website! Sign up on our mailing list! Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter!

Let us know if you have materials that we could use (chairs, scaffolding, rope, pallets, worklights, flashlights, paint, dropcloths). Let us know if you'd like to cook us dinner sometime.

TELL EVERYONE YOU KNOW. This show is going to be huge, and we hope you can help make it happen.

story:
Who are we?

Mondays Dark Theatre Company, a brand new not-for-profit arts organization in NYC, is dedicated to the development and production of exciting theatrical works. It is our mission to create invigorating theatre with a youthful, contemporary voice that gives our audience a fresh perspective of the world we all share. Mondays Dark is also equally dedicated to the development of new talent. We are committed to discovering the unheard voices of new writers, directors, designers, and actors and giving them a platform to tell their stories.


We need your support!!!
Running a not-for-profit is no easy task! Did you know that less than 50% of most not-for-profits income is from ticket sales? This means we're relying on our community to help get us off the ground! That's why MDTC is launching this fundraising campaign - to help us supplement the costs of our inaugural season.

What will this money go towards? 
$25,000 is a lot of money, but once you factor in all the elements involved in producing theatre in New York, you'll see that the numbers add up quickly: $12,000 (Theatre Rent) + $5,000 (Actor Salaries) + $4,000 (Set, Costumes, Lights) + $2,000 (Marketing) + $1,000 (Insurance) + $1,000 (Rehearsal Space). Your tax-deductible contribution will truly bring Mondays Dark to life. 

$25,000 is only a quarter of what we need to produce a full season, and we're busy working on some fun and exciting ways to meet our goals! Your support of our IndieGoGo campaign is key to helping fulfill our goal and provide New York with exciting new theatre, and WE CAN'T THANK YOU ENOUGH FOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION!!!

What are we working on?! 
We are proud to announce "If You Start a Fire" [Be Prepared to Burn]" will open This Fall right here in New York City.  Our first production is a hilarious new comedy by playwright Kevin Kautzman which follows a couple, Chris and Lucy, as they each explore surreptitious ways to survive the difficulties of the economic recession starring Lenny Platt from Tv's "One Life to Live"!

To learn more about us, visit our website at www.MondaysDark.org.

We'll be very busy this summer as we prepare to launch our inaugural season! We have three groundbreaking shows that we are beyond thrilled to bring to New York! Stay tuned for announcements!!!

story:
"a modern-dance choreographer with a piquant imagination and visual sense to match"  Jennifer Dunning, The New York Times

 

Hi Everybody! Great news!

My company was invited to participate on a month-long space grant @chashama to develop a new piece in July at their venue 'Anita's Way' - the pedestrian through-block connecting 42nd and 43rd Street, between Broadway and 6th Ave. And I need your support!

I am creating Architecture Runway, a new piece for 10 dancers with live percussion by Jay Rosen. The piece is inspired by the architectural feel and energy of the space as it affects me.

I am very excited about this project because I have been interested in creating works for different spaces and this is an opportunity to investigate new possibilities.

There will be two FREE performances: July 26 and 27 @ 1 PM.

Your generous contribution will help me achieve my goal of providing fees to everyone involved in this exciting project!


Here is the breakdown:

10 dancers @ 300 each = 3,000

Musician, photographer, videographer @ 300 each = 900

Costume designer = 300

Video editor (promo DVD and final excerpt @ 250 = 500)

Other costs related to project (programs, fees, transportation of instruments) = 300

Total project cost $5,000

How you can get involved:

You can get involved by making a donation. Starting at $10 and up to as much as you would like to contribute, all funds are going toward the project. Each donation corresponds to a perk such as a photo from the Company, a CD, or a private dance class.

The impact:

After Architecture Runway premieres, it is our intention to take the piece to other cities and venues, as well as internationally. Your name will be posted as a contributor in the program.

We have recently toured twice to Brazil (Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo), and we hope to bring Architecture Runway there.

Wrapping it up:

Creating art and especially dance is not an easy task these days. But I get inspired at every rehearsal, working with these beautiful dancers. We all do it because we are fascinated with movement, form, and aesthetics, and it is too much fun! We look at the world through these lenses and love to bring the final product to you, the audience.

Thanks for reading and for your generous support!

Please spread the word about my campaign! Share this link with your friends on Facebook, and Twitter.

OBRIGADA! Thank You!

Learn more about my Company: http://reginanejmancompany.blogspot.com/

story:
Mr. and Mrs. Workshop Production

Cathy (the director) and I (Connie, the playwright) are excited about this latest version of my play, Mr. and Mrs. The play explores the nature of a friendship which crosses barriers of culture, generation, self-deception, and personal mythology.

Cathy directed a staged reading at the University of Washington last January, which sent me back to refining, elaborating, and rewriting. Now we're ready to give the play a more in-depth exploration in a workshop production in late fall of 2012.

Our Backgrounds

Cathy and I previously collaborated on my play, Joan: In Her Own Voice, about Joan of Arc during her months of imprisonment, in a production at the University of Washington School of Drama. Reviews were very positive, including Joe Bolling's Theater Puget Sound ranking the production in the top 5% of shows he reviewed that year.

Cathy is a master of helping actors apply the principles of the Alexandar Technique to their performances, and teaches in the Professional Actors Training Program at the University of Washington. Her directing experience includes many original works, and she brings a subtle and perceptive understanding to her directing.

Connie is an award-winning screenwriter, but has focused on playwriting for many years, including working as an artist-in-residence in a Seattle public school for three years, guiding 5th graders in developing original plays for graduation, as well as serving as writer, director, and performer for numerous productions at the annual Women of Wisdom conference.

Why We Need Your Help

The staged reading process was very quick with just a few hours of rehearsal before the reading. Nevertheless, the characters jumped off the page, and as one audience member said, "I couldn't believe how many people were crying at the end."

A workshop production, fully realized, will further the development of the play. Connie will attend the rehearsals while Cathy leads the actors in exploring the material scene-by-scene through text analysis, improvisation, and other exercises. This, coupled with in-the-moment rewriting, is essential for honing the unity of the action, dialogue, and theme.

What We Need & What You Get

While we are experts at producing exciting theater on a shoestring budget, and the venue will provide in-kind donations of lighting, costumes, and rehearsal and performance space, we need your help for props and set pieces and for actor stipends. The more we raise, the more we can pay the actors, and the more fully we can realize our vision!

A special, and magical, element of the set, and leit-motif of the piece, are Wisteria Vines, which will grow, blossom, and fade during the play. This will enhance audience members appreciation for the passage of time (scenes occur in post-WWII East Germany, and contemporary Seattle over a period of two decades).

We need at least $500 (more will be super fantastic!) to pay for props, set pieces, marketing, programs, and actor stipends.

Your perks:

  • $5 A digital production photograph
  • $10 Name listed as donor in the program
  • $25 One comp ticket for the production in late autumn of 2012
  • $50 Two comp tickets plus a piece of the wisteria
  • $75 One comp ticket and the opportunity to attend a rehearsal
  • $100 One comp ticket and a casual dinner for one with Connie and Cathy
  • $500 Two comp tickets plus fine dining for you and one guest with Connie and Cathy

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. by posting the link on Facebook, Tweeting, or emailing everyone you know
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
