story:
Hard Sparks is raising funds for its inaugural production of Eightythree Down opening September 1st, 2011 at Under St. Marks.

Eightythree Down is an exciting new play by J.Stephen Brantley staged by award-winning director Daniel Talbott. Set in a suburb of New York City on the last night of 1983, Eightythree Down is a sexy, stylish, dangerous new drama about the futility of isolation, the consequences of indulgence, and our desperate need for something genuine in an increasingly artificial world.

Horse Trade Theatre Group in association with Hard Sparks presents

Melody Bates, Ian Holcomb, Bryan Kaplan & Brian Miskell in

Eightythree Down 

by J.Stephen Brantley

Directed by Daniel Talbott


Sound by Janie Bullard + Set by Eugenia Furneaux-Arends

Lighting by Brad Peterson + Costumes by Tristan Raines


Assistant Director Evan Cacciopoli

Stage Management by Amanda Michaels

Assistant Stage Manager Alex Mark


September 1-17 at Under St. Marks Theater

94 St. Marks Place between 1st and A

For information and tickets, please visit www.horsetrade.info or www.HardSparks.com


Hard Sparks champions the work of early- to mid-career playwrights and actors for a diverse audience of urban theatre-goers hungry for daring performances of dangerous plays.

Hard Sparks provides its audience with a meaningful experience at a reasonable price, and does so without sacrificing the integrity of those who create it. Our artists are fairly compensated for their work. Always.

Hard Sparks sees rehearsal as development. We commit to playwrights and their plays by actually producing new works rather than allowing them to languish in developmental limbo.

Hard Sparks recognizes the importance of supporting fellow community-based organizations working to improve the lives of those in need.

story:
When a religious, Middle American suburb is infiltrated by an alien from the Planet Homo posing as a suburban housewife will the good folk of Pleasant Valley Pines notice before the whole town erupts in chaos and depravity?

Alien invasions! Gay wrestling! Raucous church choirs! Cheerleader blood baths! Live rock’n’roll and horny suburban housewives all to song and dance!

Created by B-Movie filmmaker and NYC’s answer to John Waters, Lola Rock-N-Rolla, (Dragzilla,Night of the Living Gay, Nefertitty) and seminal punk guitar player and songwriter, Gina Volpe, (Lunachicks/Bantam) pooling their talents together in homage to Hedwig and The Rocky Horror Picture Show to make the next cult hit “Homo the Musical!”

But we can't do it without you! We need your help! Opening night is just a few weeks away and there's fake blood and oversize wigs to buy. There's expensive wireless mics to rent, actors to feed and handbills to be printed. Until we hit the big stages of Broadway we're scraping our pennies together to pay our expenses and still we just don't have enough, and that's where you come in. Any amount contributed will be a tremendous help to us. Your generosity will go a long way we guarantee! Because of your donations we will be able to put on a kick ass show that will leave you in stitches (and in blood, fake of course). 

‘Cause in these times who doesn’t need a good ass probing joke and a light hearted jab at the American religious right?!

Thank you!!

And you can also help us by just spreading the word! Like us on Facebook and tell your friends!

Facebook-

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Homo-the-Musical/342991349129089

www.homothemusical.com

www.thewildproject.com

Your generosity will go a long way we guarantee! Because of your donations we will be able to put on a kick ass show that will leave you in stitches (and in blood, fake of course). 
‘Cause in these times who doesn’t need a good ass probing joke and a light hearted jab at the American religious right?!
Thank you!!
And you can also help us by just spreading the word! Like us on Facebook and tell your friends!


Facebook-
http://www.facebook.com/pages/Homo-the-Musical/342991349129089
www.homothemusical.com
www.thewildproject.com

story:
Dear friends, family, fellow artists,

Part of the Minnesota Fringe Festival (August 2-12, 2012; Minneapolis/St. Paul),  Voices of Action: Women in Performance is the collective effort of four independent female performing artists based across the country.  The performances feature the work of Lynn Andrews, Elizabeth June Bergman, Krista DeNio, and Taja Will, movement theater/dance/improvisation artists exploring the theme of women performers past and present. 

In order to produce these compelling works, we must raise production funds.  We need to raise a minimum of  $1000 in order  to cover travel expenses, studio rental, and basic production costs.  Whether you can give $5, $25 or $100, we have tokens of appreciation to offer you for your support! Check out our list of "perks" for each level of contribution on the website! 

You can also find more information about the show there or at: www.fringefestival.org or on our Facebook event page http://www.facebook.com/events/311884992238312/.  

The smart, physical, and highly entertaining show we're putting together does require capital other than just the contributing artists' time and talent; we ask very humbly but with conviction regarding how much we value performance as a means of dialogue, poetic exploration, and shared human experiences.  We have an amazing show planned and hope you can make it possible for us to meet our goal, today!

See you in the theater!

Elizabeth, Taja, Krista, and Lynn

story:
2 duets, some awkward moments, a long silence and a slow dance.

This summer I am embarking on a new creative expedition. I have been very interested in integrating character into dance and have 3 amazing oppertunities this summer to show some expieriments. I have the oppertunity to show this dance at:
 
 
Dixon Place as part of the HOT! festival:
 
https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe/9692825
 
 
The Current Sessions Vol II, Issue I:
 
http://thecurrentsessions.com/Sessions_2/menu.html
 
 
and finally continue to develop the work at a fantastic creative residency, The Freight, in upstate NY. I am so excited for these incredible opportunities and I need your help!
 
Round 1 of this piece is going to be graced with the endless talent of:
 
Chris Ralph
Sara Mettin
Sarah Stanley
Amy Ruggiero
Elliot Reiland
Alexander Dones
Georgie Caldwell
Francesca Romo
Brendan Duggen
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, just COME SEE THE SHOW! There are amazing dancers, and a lot of other awesome work going up, so come on down and watch some dance! Hugs, high fives, pats on the back and big sloppy smooches will also be gladly accepted donations.
 
http://www.jonathanroysewindham.com/

story:
Saskatchewan Native Theatre Company
NEEDS YOUR HELP!

In this world, a common question is "What can I do to help?" We believe giving issues platform through excellent artistic offerings generates awareness, sympathy and curiosity, sparking conversations where these large questions can be answered.

We entered into co-production with ARTICLE 11 on a very important piece of theatre called In Spirit with the hope of staging it here in Saskatoon, and as part of Performing Turtle Island: A Gathering of Indigenous Theatre and Performance at the University of Regina on September 19th, 2015. The production would see core creators Tara Beagan and Andy Moro working with Saskatchewan-based actor Dakota Hebert, creating an SK-based version of this tremendous project.

SNTC has been creating powerful theatrical works since 1999. ARTICLE 11 is a new Indigenous Arts Activist company with an impressive production history including work at Toronto's ROM and the NAC in Ottawa. Both companies are mandated to further the Indigenous voice in the contemporary arts.

As a mighty duo, we were disappointed to learn that we lost out on necessary federal granting monies to do a run of the show in Saskatoon. We remain committed to the offering in Regina. As full funding was not in place, both companies and the entire creative team agreed to take a large pay cut to make this important production possible. We are rehearsing in Saskatoon, in donated venue space. While this generosity is inspiring, we still have production and travel expenses to cover. We would like to build a set that remains with SNTC.

From the playwright/director:

"I have always dreamed of getting In Spirit across Canada and into the hearts and minds of as many people as possible. This project is what little Andy and I can do for our missing and murdered women and girls, instead of feeling hobbled by the enormity of the tragedy. It's all about offering a powerful theatrical work that will unite people so that we are inspired to work together to make much-needed change happen in this country." -Tara Beagan, Ntlaka'pamux


IN SPIRIT

Inspired by the innumerable missing & murdered Indigenous women and girls, In Spirit by Tara Beagan is a beautifully woven tale of a young girl on the cusp of adolescence who mysteriously disappeared in the late '70's. There are all too many true stories like this one.

Performing Turtle Island: A Gathering of Indigenous Theatre and Performance will be presented by The University of Regina and the First Nations University of Canada. This Gathering will bring together established and emerging scholars and artists in the form of a national symposium on how Indigenous theatre and performance are connected to Indigenous identity and community health, and will provide a diverse range of keynotes, performances, seminars and workshops that touch on innovative approaches to performance, education, research, health, and community consultation.

EVERY CONTRIBUTION COUNTS
Share this initiative with friends, family and arts patrons. Every donation - that in time spent sharing this campaign, or a financial contribution, is of great worth. We are grateful for your support in every form.

SNTC is a charitable organization, and will issue tax deductible receipts for any donation of $25 or more, less the requisite $5 and (if selected by donor)  value of perk gift. Details in each individual perk.

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone!

We are Claudia, Mara, Elena, Olivia, Vlad, Andrei, Maria, Alin and Ioana and we just started the rehearsals for the first 100% Romanian play in the West End, London. 

Inspired by a real story found in the newspaper Florida Observer, Romanian-born playwright Saviana Stanescu’s Aliens With Extraordinary Skills was produced in 2008 by Julia Miles Theatre in New York to great acclaim. 

We believe that this new project will create a bridge and establish a significant connection between a team of young Romanian actors and creators living in London and their community.  

STORY 

New York, the city where people are always busy and a bit "zombie", living the American Dream with their eyes-wide open 24/7 . Two immigrant clowns, a girl from Moldova and a boy from Russia, arrive here on fake visas as "aliens with extraordinary abilities" in the circus, struggling to get the precious Green Card in their almost empty pockets. 

Nadia makes balloon animals in Central Park. Borat (an ill fated name coincidence that ruined his reputation) drives a yellow cab, talks over his mobile whilst driving and spends his tips at the most popular exotic dance club in Manhattan. 

And in this big circus called Life, on a second-hand couch, the two meet Lupita and Bob.  

What’s next? Green Card, love or clown tricks? 

TEAM 

Claudia is the producer of "Tales Told In Romanian", a theatre series which has presented in London for the last three years sell out shows and built a significant and vivid Romanian theatre community at Leicester Square Theatre.

Mara Lubens is an upcoming film and theatre director with a background in commercials, music videos and short films in Romania and UK. She has previously worked with multi award winners directors like Radu Jude, Dominik Graf and Mike Elliot.  

We think it's now the time to produce our own theatre show

The new production will gather for the first time a Romanian cast and crew telling a universal story to a Romanian theatre audience living in London.

CAST 

Elena Harding as Nadia is a versatile actress, with extensive experience in theatre and film. On stage she is known for Lady Capulet in "Romeo and Juliet" (The Cockpit), Hermione in "A Winter’s Tale" (Theatre Mono) and Heather Peterson in "Hamlet For Girls" (Edinburgh Fringe). 

Olivia Popica as Lupita  is without a doubt a rising star, making her mark with impressive performances in film, television and theatre. She has appeared in the BBC TV productions "Holby City" and the BAFTA winning "Glasgow Girls", as well as in the popular American TV show "Tyrant" on FX Channel and BBC Radio 4’s drama "Tumanbay".  

Vlad Troncea as Borat is a promising and charismatic young actor, who has already received 4 awards for best lead actor in various Romanian theatre festivals. He has worked with well-known directors such as Radu Afrim, Mihai Maniutiu, Alexandru Darie and Nae Caranfil in various major theatres in Bucharest. 

Andrei Gliga as Bob is a multi-talented actor who studied drama at West London University. Since graduation in 2012, he has performed in five major plays produced by the Queen Mary Theatre in Oradea, Romania, and in other two roles at Arthur Cotterell Theatre in Kingston, London. 


Maria Alexe as Homeland Security Officer  has a vast on-stage experience and remarkable versatility. She has appeared in various theatre and film roles both in the UK and abroad, with the most recent credits including: High Priestess in 'Penthesilea' (Playades Theatre Company), Revenge in 'The Spanish Tragedy' (Lazarus Theatre Company) and Zena in 'The Godling' (Defiant Reality Theatre production at Etcetera Theatre). 

Alin Balascan as Homeland Security Officer  is a young rising star, who studied at the prestigious acting school East 15 and also with the Royal Shakespeare Company. He played Angus in 'Macbeth' at Shakespeare's Globe and appeared in Harold Pinter’s 'Night' and 'No man’s land' at Cockpit Theatre. In 2013 he made his debut in West End in 'In the Beginning Was the End'at Somerset House, in a double role that brought him encouraging comments in the London Evening Standard and the Guardian.

The cast, creative and production team includes:

Playwright: Saviana Stanescu

Producer: Claudia Cirlig for Tales Told in Romanian  

Director: Mara Lubens

Assistant Director: Armine Vosganian 

Translation in Romanian coordinated by Iulia Popovici

Set and costume designer: Ioana Curelea

Original music: Ciprian Iacob 

Technic consultant: Leo Bacica 

Nadia: Elena Harding 

Lupita: Olivia Popica

Borat: Vlad Troncea

Bob: Andrei Gliga

Homeland Security Officer: Maria Alexe

Homeland Security Officer: Alin Balascan 


What We Need & What You Get

Although we already have a small part of the funds, we still need to cover some costs. 

We need £1,750 to cover some of the production costs: 

  • renting the rehearsal rooms and the venue 
  • buying or making props and costumes
  • symbolic fees for the cast and the creative team (director, set designer, music composer) 

If you love our project and aren't able to contribute financially, here are other great ways in which you can support our production:

  • Spread the word about our campaign and our production!
  • Know anyone who would be keen to sponsor us? Please email us. 
  • Know a free rehearsal space? Please email us. 

The Impact

This would be the first 100% Romanian theatre show produced in London for a Romanian community. The show would have many runs in London and could tour to other cities in the UK and Romania. The cultural impact to communities living abroad would be significant as well as the bonding between different parts of the community.

story:
What is our project

Has the decision to have children become political?

Our Population is a multi-media performance by writer/director Allison M Keating about why people choose to have children and the factors that go into that decision.  Developed from the stories of men and women across the globe, Our Population exposes the intricacies of reproducing in the modern age through a vibrant, breathing collage of video and live performance.  Utilizing the multidisciplinary talent of several students from the California Institute of the Arts, Our Population had it’s first script development workshop within the School of Theater’s New Works Festival in May and now the team is ready to take the next step.

We are requesting donations to help cover travel expenses for CalArts student Allison Keating (Writer/Director), Yanda Li (Producer), and Sanmu Lin (Video) to travel to India on May 16th for a one month research trip to conduct interviews and collect video footage for the multimedia portion of the performance.  

Our Population’s narratives and visual elements weave together many stories.  Allison has been conducting interviews of international men and women from various backgrounds asking them basic questions such as, “Why do you want to have children?  What does your perfect family look like?  What factors into your decision to have children?”  Using Skype, she has spoken with people from Beijing, Washington DC, New York, Dubai, Barcelona, and Bangkok among others.  Each person has unique reasons for wanting to start a family.  Their diverse stories will be collaged within the live narrative and video component of the performance, expressing visually the diverse ways humans live and breed on the planet.  Our Population looks to celebrate diversity and the human race while raising awareness that we are no longer a population divided by nationalities, but a population united on one earth with one environment.

When it will happen:

Allison Keating (Director and Playwirter), Sanmu Lin (Videographer) and Yanda Li (Producer) are going to travel to China and India from May to June, 2012 to conduct interviews, research and collect video footage for the multimedia portion of the performance. Our Population will have a second workshop and forum in the Fall of 2012 to share our findings from our travels with the CalArts community followed by a full production in the Summer of 2013 presented at CalArts and The Edinborough Fringe Festival.  In addition, the project’s website will have an ongoing discussion board inviting international dialog.

Web-site: WWW.OURPOPULATION.NET

How you can help:

We still need about $3,500.00 to make it happen.  So even if you can’t donate, please help us to spread the word, share this page on your social media, spread our video, check out our web-site.

Every little bit helps, and in return we want to throw you some great thank-you perks.  Please check out the different levels, we have pretty creative perks, and we think those rewards are pretty fun. There’s stuff for every level of assistance, because every little bit will go a long way to helping us for this project.

story:
SHOWDOWN STAGE CO. SUMMER CAMP FOR KIDS AND TEENS!!!

Showdown is a one of a kind national non-profit theater company empowering children ages 6 to 18+ through theater.
 
It was founded by Industry pros, Flip Kobler, Cindy Marcus and Dennis Poore who had been transformed by theater in their youth and wanted to pay it forward.  Since its inception in 2002, Showdown Summer camps have helped hundreds of children of all walks of life not only feel better about themselves, but the world around them.  And it’s fun!
 
Kids who participate in Showdown’s one of a kind Summer camp experience spend mornings taking professional level classes in all aspects of the arts – from song writing to dance; and then afternoon in rehearsal for a live production of a show written especially for them.
 
Showdown’s unique opportunity – a chance for young actors to their original stamp on a role – is not only rare.  It’s special.  Because Showdown shows go on to be published and then performed all over the world.  Children participate locally, but experience their creative contribution globally. 
 
Showdown is the place to be.  And you can make it happen for a child.
It’s easy.  It’s fun.  And you’ll be so glad you did. 
 
When you sponsor a child you get all the cool bells and whistles that a contribution can give like tickets to shows and program listings, but best of all you will make a sizable difference in their life.  And give them memories that they will never forget.
 
You can contribute ANY amount $1.00 or more.  :)
There are perks if contribute $50.00 or more see right side of the screen.
If you want to donate to a specific child (like a family memember or friend) please let us know and we will make sure they receive 100% of your donation.
 
Please go to the "Gallery" tab above to see photos of the previous camps and an attached document that explains more about WHY Showdown is passionate about Transformation Through Theater!
 
Thank you so much for your support!!!

Showdown is the place to be.  And you can make it happen for a child.
It’s easy.  It’s fun.  And you’ll be so glad you did. 
 
When you sponsor a child you get all the cool bells and whistles that a contribution can give like tickets to shows and program listings, but best of all you will make a sizable difference in their life.  And give them memories that they will never forget.
 
You can contribute ANY amount $1.00 or more.  :)
There are perks if contribute $50.00 or more see right side of the screen.
If you want to donate to a specific child (like a family memember or friend) please let us know and we will make sure they receive 100% of your donation.
 
Please go to the "Gallery" tab above to see photos of the previous camps and an attached document that explains more about WHY Showdown is passionate about Transformation Through Theater!
 
Thank you so much for your support!!!

story:
My name is Dedra McDermott and I am a B.F.A Honours graduate with a degree in Choreography and Performance. Shortly after completing my studies I was very uncertain about which path I wanted to explore. To Be Announced is a passion project that was originally created to provide myself with a platform to create and showcase my work when no other opportunities seemed to be available. I am motivated to create this project at this point in my career development because I believe it is the next step in introducing myself to the dance community as more than a dancer. I am eager to present myself as a dance artist, emerging choreographer and artistic visionary interested in garnering a deeper understanding of her craft.

In addition to taking on the ambitious task of producing a full length performance, I am applying for my master’s degree in dance performance. The completion of this project is time sensitive because it is an essential portion of my graduate school application. With this new project underway, I am fortunate to experience the many angles of creating a show from production to performance. In addition to introducing myself as a multifaceted artist, I am so grateful to have 3 incredibly talented and diverse female artists sharing their work alongside me. This show will feature works by Jasmyn Fyffe, Alysa Pires, Kelly Shaw and myself.

Through this funding campaign I hope that all artists involved in this project will receive financial compensation. This is integral to my values as I feel it is important to acknowledge and support their dedication and hard work. As the producer behind this project, I am the sole financial resource other than this funding campaign and potential ticket sales. Your support will provide both financial relief and freedom to pay the artists involved in this project as well as supplemental aid for the cost of the venue rental, rehearsal space and performance venue insurance. I am excited and privileged to create opportunities for emerging and professional artists to share their work with the community.

story:
The Crowbait Club

The Crowbait Club was founded in Portland, Maine in 2012 with a specific mission: bring the performing arts community together on a monthly basis and encourage newcomers to explore the arts.

How? By giving people a barrier-free, no pressure experience in the arts. The monthly Crowbait Club Theatre Deathmatch is simple to understand yet hard to master. Audience members can submit a ten minute play, act, watch, in any combination. The plays and the actors are chosen at random. The playwright has two minutes to brief their cast and then it's go time. Ten plays are read over the course of the evening. At the end of the show, the audience votes for best actor and best play, and the winning play becomes part of the lineup for our annual short play festival: King of Crows.

Because to be in it, you have to win it. And anyone, ANYONE can come and be part of the excitement. It is not unheard of for a newcomer to walk in and win with a great script or give a terrific acting performance and take home the Best Actor award.

We have discovered that the audience is a very good judge indeed. They know what they like. And every year we take the scripts they have chosen and fully produce them in our notorious short play festival, King of Crows.

PLUS, because The Crowbait Club is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, the portion of your contribution that is above the value of any perk you select is tax-deductible!


King of Crows IV: All Hail The King

King of Crows IV: All Hail The King will be held at the St Lawrence Arts Center, 76 Congress St, Portland, ME on September 8-11, 2016

We are asking for funding in the amount of $3,000. These funds will help us pay for the hall and a very small stipend for the actors, musicians, crew, and staff. Not to mention the countless small expenses that occur in mounting a creative endeavor like this: funny hats, lighting gel, gaffers tape, strange props and the like. Whether the goal is met, exceeded, or not, all funds will be used for production expenses or saved for King of Crows V.

3,000 dollars covers about 40% of the show's cost. The rest is funded by saved funds from previous King of Crows shows and our monthly Deathmatches. Crowbait Club runs a tight ship financially: it's five directors are not paid and they even pay out of their own pockets every month for the silly prizes awarded to the Deathmatch winners.

What about perks? We've got them! Simple and to the point. Give $35 and get two tickets to your show of choice. This perk includes a $5 donation to the cause and our heartfelt gratitude for your support. $50 gets you KOC IV's "Orange King" poster beautifully designed by Artistic Director Jody McComan. $100 is the price for the poster signed by the company and two tickets to the show of your choice. The tip top is $200: you get two tickets to the show of your choice, the poster signed by the company AND the legendary original Deathmatch logo T-shirt designed by founder Cullen McGough in your size.

PLUS....there is a secret perk available if you have the link. Drop us a line and we'll send it to you.

What's not to love?


Why Should I Care?

Because we care.  And caring is important.

Because we are passionate about playwriting, acting and all the associated crafts the theater contains.

Because in 2012, three artists came together to figure out a way to make an arts opportunity accessible to anyone who wanted to try it. And they did it. With their own time and out of their own pockets. It's a party, it's an instantaneous literary event, it's cutting edge theatre and it's a chance to try something new and different without any barriers whatsoever.

People measure success in different ways. We are proud that our Deathmatches have generated over 600 new ten minute plays. We are proud that some of these plays have found production not only in King of Crows but in festivals and theaters from coast to coast. We are proud that actors whose first experience on the stage was at Crowbait Club are now working actors in our community.

We are proud that we can do this cheaply and effectively. The cost of admission to a Deathmatch is $5.00. Five dollars. To write, act, watch or all three. When we say we want to kick down barriers to participation in the arts, we absolutely mean it.

Do you love the arts? Then please consider a donation so we can continue doing what we do.


Other Ways You Can Help

That's the pitch. Thanks for reading it. We understand that sometimes money is tight. If you can't contribute to the cause, please talk us up, share this campaign with the IndieGoGo tools or like our page on Facebook. We would be grateful.

Check us out on Facebook at The Crowbait Club

Visit us on the web at thecrowbaitclub.org

But most importantly...


Get with us!

Do any of the above activities sound like fun to you? Do they sound like something you've always wanted to try? Get with us!

Crowbait Club's Monthly Theatre Deathmatch is held at Mayo Street Arts, 10 Mayo St, Portland, ME, the first Wednesday of every month except September. 7:30 doors, 8:00 show. 

Come with a ten minute play, come to act, or just come to watch the fun. Admission is $5.00 cash at the door.

The August Deathmatch theme is "Sacrifice" 

And if you are reading this, consider yourself invited. :)



Credits:

Artistic Director - Jody McColman 

Music Director - Victoria Stubbs

Directors -  Anna Cranage Conathan

                       Anna Gravel

                       Elizabeth Freeman  

                       Janice Gardner

                       Mnemosyne Heileman


CBC Committee Members - Charlie Cole

                                                       Elizabeth Chasse - King

                                                       Jody McColman

                                                       Michael Tooher

                                                       Victoria Stubbs


All KOC IV art by Jody McColman

Original Deathmatch logo by Cullen McGough

story:
PYGMANKENSTEIN [pɪgmænkənstɑjn] is:

  1. A portmanteau of Pygmalion and Frankenstein, two tales of Creation

  2. Committed exclusively to producing horror theatre

  3. The brainchild of Nora Kelly Lester and Lauren-Shannon Jones


Nora and Lauren first collaborated on a show called Grow in 2013, where they discovered a shared love for the uncanny, the unsettling and the macabre. In 2014 they worked together again on The Assassination of Brian Boru, funded by Unesco and commissioned by The New Theatre. This year they were selected by to lead The New Theatre’s first residency program. Olympia will be their debut show as director and writer in residence.


OLYMPIA [olɪmpiə]:

  1. Grew from the seeds of a chilling 19th century short story by ETA Hoffmann

  2. Promises to petrify

  3. Follows in the tradition of Gothic storytelling behind du Maurier, Gaiman, and Poe


Olympia tells the story of of Nathaniel, a neurotic but brilliant medical student, who falls madly in love with the strange daughter of his anatomy professor. Professor Coppola’s obsession with matching him with her daughter reveals itself to be something much, much darker; and Nathaniel’s pragmatic fiancee Clara and his hedonistic roommate Lothaire become his only hope to survive.


How Der Sandmann became Olympia:


Last January, Nora Kelly Lester sheltered from the rain in an antique bookshop. Remember the rain last January? It was terrible. As she pretended to browse the shelves and waited for the storm to pass a title caught her eye - Der Sandmann. She bought it mainly out of obligation, but as she read it on the journey home she was struck by its dark, paranoid atmosphere and its totally ahead of its time fixation on body-horror. It would (she thought) be perfect for the stage…


How can you help?

As a new company we are completely unfunded and so, we are looking for financial support to cover production costs including venue rental, stage materials and promotional materials. Any contribution big or small that you can spare would be greatly appreciated. And as a thank you, check out the list of rewards to see what you could get in exchange for your support.


The Faces Behind 'Olympia':


Conceived by PYGMANKENSTEIN


Directed by Nora Kelly Lester

Written by Lauren-Shannon Jones


Sound Design: Dylan Tonge Jones

Lighting Design: Conor Byrne

Set Design: Fionn McShane

Make-up: Gill Lambert

Stage Management: Cein Sookran

Marketing: Mark Ball

Design: Andre K'por

Producer: Ailish McCarthy


The Cast:

Michael-David McKiernan

Shane Robinson

Aenne Barr

Erin Gilgen

Claudia Kinahan


Nora Kelly Lester (director)

Nora Kelly Lester is currently Resident Director at The New Theatre. To date she has worked on The Assassination of Brian Boru (National Tour 2015) and is currently in production with Writer Dylan Coburn Gray on a new play Drawing Crosses On A Dusty Windowpane for this year's Tiger Dublin Fringe. Other recent work includes According to His Need (Reds Theatre Company) at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival, Grow (The Virgin Eclectic) and UCD Dramsoc's leaving cert show Macbeth in 2014. Nora graduated from UCD in 2012 with an honors degree in English and Drama and received her qualification in Drama Facilitation from NAYD in 2013.


Lauren-Shannon Jones (writer)

Lauren-Shannon Jones is a playwright and filmmaker from Dublin. Her first two plays opened to critical acclaim: Grow (The Virgin Eclectic, 2013) and The Assassination of Brian Boru (The New Theatre, 2014/15). She completed an honours degree in film production from Wolverhampton College this year. Her graduate film Enclave was awarded best screenplay, best direction and best overall production of the class of '15. Lauren is a member of the Irish Playwrights and Screenwriters Guild and the Screen Directors Guild of Ireland. Recurring themes in her work include future shock, sibling rivalry, cults, paranoia, body horror, and the utter unreliability of memory.

"..this young production shows great verve and promise....clever with plenty of twists and turns.." - Le Cool Magazine (Grow)


"Lauren-Shannon Jones’s play is entertaining, well-cast and very well written." ****

- Michael Moffatt, Evoke.ie (The Assassination of Brian Boru)


“...astute, clever and evocative.”

-Una McMahon, Entertainment.ie (Grow)


Olympia will run in The New Theatre Temple Bar from the 12th - 24th October 2015

story:
The Play 

Jude Beringer thinks she’s going mad.  Then she meets Leon, a young card magician who can make people disappear. What follows is the story of a burgeoning friendship between two young Londoners, told within the frame of a fictional game show about mental illness: This Is Your Mind. The narrative is dramatized through a series of games and challenges, which become increasingly surreal as the show goes on—and as its hosts, Fizz and Terry, reveal themselves to be far less benevolent than they at first appeared.

A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light is a witty and inventive exploration of mental illness and a powerfully compassionate play about family, friendship and illusion.

"entertaining and thought-provoking" - Cleo Sylvestre


The Production

Rather than scenes and acts, A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light is innovatively structured around a series of games and challenges.  Within these, the actors are given flexibility, engaging directly with the audience and encouraging their participation. Every performance is unique, entailing an element of chance and relishing in its own liveness.  We use a variety of performance techniques from naturalism to surrealism.  The production also contains an original score composed by Patrick Goodden, live song and dance.

Watch the full trailer here: https://vimeo.com/113926992

We first presented an extract at The Big Noise Festival in June 2014, which was a great starting point to develop the script.  After further research and development we performed the play to over 300 people during a week-long run at the Rosemary Branch Theatre, London in October 2014.  We were all delighted with the play’s reception, the full houses it received and to have now secured a slot at the well-respected Zoo Venues for this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival, from 7 - 30  August.  The play will undergo a rewrite to fit the classic hour-long festival slot and to make it our best version yet.

A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light, 2014 (c) Oliver King Photography


Why is this show important? 

As a company we feel very strongly that this story needs to be told as it is so representative of the thoughts, problems and anxieties that we both personally experience and see in the lives of our contemporaries.

We think that the play’s thematic exploration of mental health - of different viewpoints towards mental illnesses, their diagnoses and treatments - makes it a very important contemporary play, as mental illnesses are being diagnosed at an increasing rate in the UK. This exploration in turn leads to an exploration of broader notions of reality and perception, all within the framework of what is of is still a heartwarming and hopeful story.


The Writer

Ben Maier is a writer and performer. He recently co-wrote and provided songs for A Dashing Fellow (New Diorama). Other credits include extensive work with Skinnybone Theatre and Wireless Mystery Theatre in Belfast. His one-man show An Imaginary Circus, produced by Belka Productions, recently commenced a UK tour.  

‘Extraordinary energy and vitality […] a tour de force’ – Edinburgh Guide on An Imaginary Circus

The Director

Charlie's recent directing credits include: Cyber-babies (Park Theatre), The Seaside, A Little While Longer (Hen & Chickens), 82 to North Finchley, Fit For Work (Rosemary Branch); as co-director: The King of Cats (Secret Garden Party). She was selected for a week-long workshop with acclaimed theatre director Katie Mitchell, organised by the Young Vic.  Charlie also has professional experience as a choreographer, producer and stage manager, at venues including New Diorama, Pleasance and Southwark Playhouse.


The Company

London Grey & Green was founded in 2013 by Berengere Ariaudo de Castelli, Charlie Ely and Tessa Shrubsall, after the three met and bonded whilst studying at the Royal Central School of Speech & Drama. 

The theatre that we make focuses on contemporary stories and exploring the world around us through imaginative and varied performance techniques.  We are interested in intelligent and provocative new writing and are also committed to producing work with at least 50% female representation.

We have independently produced three successful week-long shows on the London fringe and been invited to perform our work at two arts festivals: Secret Garden Party and The Big Noise Festival. 

www.greyandgreentheatre.co.uk

@greygreentheatr

‘London Grey & Green Theatre Company will go far’ – Female Arts

‘an evening of challenging and passionate new writing’ – A Younger Theatre on CityShorts

The King of Cats, Secret Garden Party, 2013, (c) Tess A. Owen Photography


The Money

We feel confident that the play will be a success in Edinburgh, but it is a very costly endeavor, and we have a lot of fundraising to do in order to get it there! The production has been philanthropic in the past – we presented an extract of the play at a charity festival for the Big Issue Foundation and raised money for the Young Mind charity throughout our October run, but London Grey & Green currently receives no public funding and we now need to ask for financial assistance ourselves. 

As you can see, our budget is pretty conservative, and all of our dedicated cast and crew are involved on a voluntary basis.  We will, of course, support our team members that will be living in Edinburgh for the duration of the festival (one month), by paying for their travel and accomodation.  If we hit our goal of £2,500 this will cover the bulk of our accomodation costs.


Stretch Goal

Our team work really hard so if we exceed our funding goal any extra money will go to our actors and stage manager to help towards their living costs while in Edinburgh.


The Future

We think that the important themes of this production mean that it deserves a life beyond the festival.. If our run goes as well as we are hoping, we will use the momentum to tour the show to more theatres, but also to schools - so that young people who may have seen little experimental theatre can experience it and so we can spark discussions with them about the realities of mental illnesses.

Our company already works in schools delivering 'Play-in-a-Day' workshops. For more information, visit http://greyandgreentheatre.co.uk/play-in-a-day/

If you'd like us to bring the show to where you are, please get in touch with us here!


Any Questions?

Just send us an email to info@greyandgreentheatre.co.uk or talk to us on twitter @greygreentheatr


Thank you so much for your interest in A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light!  We'd be so delighted if you could support us on any level and we hope that you like the rewards we are offering in return!

Lots of love, London Grey & Green

P.S. Please help us spread the word about our crowdfunding campaign by sharing this on social media :)

What follows is the story of a burgeoning friendship between two young Londoners, told within the frame of a fictional game show about mental illness: This Is Your Mind. The narrative is dramatized through a series of games and challenges, which become increasingly surreal as the show goes on—and as its hosts, Fizz and Terry, reveal themselves to be far less benevolent than they at first appeared.

A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light is a witty and inventive exploration of mental illness and a powerfully compassionate play about family, friendship and illusion."entertaining and thought-provoking" - Cleo SylvestreThe Production
Rather than scenes and acts, A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light is innovatively structured around a series of games and challenges.  Within these, the actors are given flexibility, engaging directly with the audience and encouraging their participation. Every performance is unique, entailing an element of chance and relishing in its own liveness.  We use a variety of performance techniques from naturalism to surrealism.  The production also contains an original score composed by Patrick Goodden, live song and dance.

Watch the full trailer here: https://vimeo.com/113926992



We
first presented an extract at The Big Noise Festival in June 2014, which was a great starting point to develop the script.  After further research and development we performed the play to over 300 people during a week-long run at the Rosemary Branch Theatre, London in October 2014.  We were all delighted with the play’s reception, the full houses it received and to have now secured a slot at the well-respected Zoo Venues for this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival, from 7 - 30  August.  The play will undergo a rewrite to fit the classic hour-long festival slot and to make it our best version yet.
A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light, 2014 (c) Oliver King Photography
Why is this show important? 
As a company we feel very strongly that this story needs to be told as it is so representative of the thoughts, problems and anxieties that we both personally experience and see in the lives of our contemporaries.

We think that the play’s thematic exploration of mental health - of different viewpoints towards mental illnesses, their diagnoses and treatments - makes it a very important contemporary play, as mental illnesses are being diagnosed at an increasing rate in the UK. This exploration in turn leads to an exploration of broader notions of reality and perception, all within the framework of what is of is still a heartwarming and hopeful story.

The Writer
Ben Maier is a writer and performer. He recently co-wrote and provided songs for A Dashing Fellow (New Diorama). Other credits include extensive work with Skinnybone Theatre and Wireless Mystery Theatre in Belfast. His one-man show An Imaginary Circus, produced by Belka Productions, recently commenced a UK tour.  

‘Extraordinary energy and vitality […] a tour de force’ – Edinburgh Guide on An Imaginary Circus
The Director
Charlie's recent directing credits include: Cyber-babies (Park Theatre), The Seaside, A Little While Longer (Hen & Chickens), 82 to North Finchley, Fit For Work (Rosemary Branch); as co-director: The King of Cats (Secret Garden Party). She was selected for a week-long workshop with acclaimed theatre director Katie Mitchell, 
organised by the Young Vic.  Charlie also has 
professional
experience as a choreographer, producer and stage manager, at venues including New Diorama, Pleasance and Southwark Playhouse.
The Company
London Grey & Green was founded in 2013 by Berengere Ariaudo de Castelli, Charlie Ely and Tessa Shrubsall, after
the three met and bonded whilst studying at
the Royal Central School of Speech & Drama.  The theatre that we make focuses on contemporary stories and exploring the world around us through imaginative and varied performance techniques.  We are interested in intelligent and provocative new writing and are also committed to producing work with at least 50% female representation.

We have independently produced three successful week-long shows on the London fringe and been invited to perform our work at two arts festivals: Secret Garden Party and The Big Noise Festival. 

www.greyandgreentheatre.co.uk@greygreentheatr

‘London Grey & Green Theatre Company will go far’ – Female Arts

‘an evening of challenging and passionate new writing’ – A Younger Theatre on CityShortsThe King of Cats, Secret Garden Party, 2013, (c) Tess A. Owen Photography

The Money
We feel confident that the play will be a success in Edinburgh, but it is a very costly endeavor, and we have a lot of fundraising to do in order to get it there! The production has been philanthropic in the past – we presented an extract of the play at a charity festival for the Big Issue Foundation and raised money for the Young Mind charity throughout our October run, but London Grey & Green currently receives no public funding and we now need to ask for financial assistance ourselves. As you can see, our budget is pretty conservative, and all of our dedicated cast and crew are involved on a voluntary basis.  We will, of course, support our team members that will be living in Edinburgh for the duration of the festival (one month), by paying for their travel and accomodation.  If we hit our goal of £2,500 this will cover the bulk of our accomodation costs.



Stretch Goal
Our team work really hard so if we exceed our funding goal any extra money will go to our actors and stage manager to help towards their living costs while in Edinburgh.

The Future
We think that the important themes of this production mean that it deserves a life beyond the festival.. If our run goes as well as we are hoping, we will use the momentum to tour the show to more theatres, but also to schools - so that young people who may have seen little experimental theatre can experience it and so we can spark discussions with them about the realities of mental illnesses.

Our company already works in schools delivering 'Play-in-a-Day' workshops. For more information, visit http://greyandgreentheatre.co.uk/play-in-a-day/If you'd like us to bring the show to where you are, please get in touch with us here!
Any Questions?
Just send us an email to info@greyandgreentheatre.co.uk or talk to us on twitter @greygreentheatr
Thank you so much for your interest in A Sudden Burst of Blinding Light!  We'd be so delighted if you could support us on any level and we hope that you like the rewards we are offering in return!Lots of love, London Grey & Green
P.S. Please help us spread the word about our crowdfunding campaign by sharing this on social media :)

story:
Give the Gift of Theater this Christmas!

Don Nguyen's Red Flamboyant was first showcased in The Public Theater's Emerging Writers Group Spotlight Series in 2009. We've wanted to produce it ever since. 

We need $25,000 to make this story  of 4 heroic and quirky Vietnamese women living with HIV/AIDS come to life. 

This money pays for props, lights, set, sound, aerial equipment, puppet creation, and artist fees. Also, 10% of the ticket sales for this show will go to support the real life women who inspired this play through their Vietnam Relief Organization.

You can give the gift of theatre to your loved ones this Christmas by emailing firebonetheatrenyc@gmail.com with your mailing address after you have donated $25 or more to this campaign ($35 or more to secure tickets to the show). We will mail you a beautiful hand painted Red Flamboyant card to put under the tree in honor of your loved one.

Please partner with Firebone Theatre, Wizard Oil Productions, Grounded Aerial, and director Laura Savia,  by giving generously and by passing along our campaign to people you know who love good theater and great causes. 

Story Synopsis:
Mrs. Hue lives in present day Vietnam with a small group of women who are all living with HIV/AIDS. Bricks smash the windows of their small house. The locals fear they will be infected by the women. Mrs. Hue is forced to see help from a stubborn government official to protect her group. Unlikely heroes emerge both in this world and the next as these poor women reach new heights of courage.

Awards and Recognition: 
Red Flamboyant was developed in The Public Theater's Emerging Writers Group and the Ojai Playwrights Conference.  It was a finalist for the Woodward International Playwriting Prize, the O’Neill National Playwrights Conference, the Bay Area Playwrights Festival, and nominated for the L. Arnold Weissberger Award.

story:
Cloud City Circus is a grassroots circus troupe from Portland, Oregon. Founded over two years ago, the troupe consists of many talented and diverse performers, ranging from aerialists to hula hoopers, singers, dancers, flow artists, belly dancers and more! Cloud City Circus performs all over the greater Portland area, putting on variety and theme shows. Now it is time for us to spread our wings and begin creating bigger and better productions. We want to wow the crowds with high-end circus shows that tell a story while entertaining the audience.

Cloud City Circus needs your help to make this dream come true! To produce a show of this caliber takes elaborate sets and costumes, posters and flyers to reach the audience, lighting schemes, rehearsal space and many other expenses. Once off the ground the shows become self-funding, but initially it takes financial backing. This is where you come in; your contributions will help us to have the funds available to take the steps to produce large scale and dynamic shows!


Our Idea for these productions are seamless story driven shows with no breaks and multiple performers working together to tell a dreamy and ethereal show. We want the audience to feel emotions as they follow us into a surreal circus driven story. We have the ideas and script plans now we are working to take them from dream to reality for you our loving and dedicated audience!


From the beginning Cloud City Circus has performed on a grassroots donation and tip-based system. The small venues that have provided us a free space to have our shows allow audience members to tip the performers to express their appreciation. We want to retain that connection with the audience while providing you with an awesome show. 

You are why we put on the shows, your smiles are the fuel that drives us while we are hanging in the air, dancing on stage and twirling to the music. We want to give back to you the supportive community with shows that dazzle the senses. Our first show will be a surreal and dreamy story told utilizing dance, circus arts and singing as well as original music and whimsical costumes.

The funding you provide will be utilized as follows:
1. Rehearsal space procurement.

2. Fabric and original costume design.
3. Lighting required to meet the specific needs of the show.

4. Set design and production.
5. Original music creation and production.
6. Aerial props and rigging.
7. Marketing and promotion.

8. Glitter, makeup and other circus necessities.

We are so excited to begin this next evolution of our journey with you! Thank you for taking the time to share with us our passion for entertaining you.

https://www.facebook.com/cloudcitycircus

http://cloudcitycircus.tumblr.com/post/97747878256

Here is another video of some of our amazing performers!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KCDDdhjer-A

story:
"You ever walk into a guy's den and see a picture of him standing next to fourteen trout? No, he's holding a three thousand pound Marlin."
-Social Network

I have been told by several industry professionals that if you can last past your fourth year, you can then make a plan to survive for many more years to come. So, here we are. We are well past five years and going strong. I am proud to say we have survived this long! I don't wish to have The District Theatre become something that once was; I want this to be an organization that survives. I want this theatre to become something the Quad Cities can not live without.


To date, the theatre has survived a slum lord and a musty, old bank building; a rebranding; a very tiring and strenuous move across the river; a small "two car garage" temporary space; a major financial crisis that left us with some serious debt; the rise and fall of a not-for-profit not unlike the story of 'Social Network' albeit on a smaller scale; small scandals on the local and national level; the rumor mill, which will be churning for years to come; battles with an owner's group who "don't support the arts"; some major changes in the administration; and over forty productions ranging from Long Day's Journey Into Night to Sweeney Todd to Rent, not to mention six years of The Rocky Horror Show.


Since 2008, despite it's hardships and obstacles, has become one of the most acclaimed companies in the Quad Cities, known for its professional talent, hard hitting material and eloquent execution. It is my hope that, in the next year, we can not only continue that tradition, but also raise production values, build a larger subscriber base, and continue towards progress with an important capital campaign. 

In addition, and most importantly, it is necessary for the future of the theatre that establish an professional organization that will become a permanent fixture in the Quad Cities' artistic landscape.


People often ask, "What are you still doing here, why are you still trying to make this work?" This is the question I am asked most, and my response is always one of two things: my traditional "Livin' the dream" or "why not?" And yes, those two are correct, and I do feel that way, but it goes deeper than that. I love what I am able to do here and I love the people I get to work with. This is what I've always wanted to do. From the time I was old enough to speak, I produced plays, haunted houses and concerts in my parent's basement/backyard year after year. At age ten, I moved my operation to the public library once I discovered an unused back room and struck up a deal with the head librarian. I started producing things in the commercial market at age twenty and currently have over seventy five full scale productions and one Broadway investment to my name.

This is all I know. This is what I love. And I love this life and this job I have created. It is the definition of the American Dream. I built this from the ground up and have worked tirelessly to make sure this place survives. I have sacrificed several gigs, several important internships, several paychecks, personal relationships, and just about everything else I have to make sure this place survives. This "little theatre" is so much more to me. It is a life. It has become an important part of who I am, and who I will become. I am driven and motivated to become a leader not only in this community but in this industry.

There is nothing quite like it...


WHAT IS HAPPENING:


The District is renovating 5,000 square feet of the Rock Island Argus building that was built in 1925.


WHAT WE WILL BE DOING INSIDE:


-A raked seating platform that will seat 100 comfortably 

-Walls to create wings on the stage and hold lighting and sound instruments 

-A wall across the back of the stage which will hold lighting instruments, act as a cyc and provide a cross over from one side of the stage to another

-Rooms for props storage, costume storage, tools and building materials

-A box office

-A tech booth

-Paint and decor to match the beautiful Italian Renaissance feel of the space

-Sound equipment - floor and area mics, new speakers and new sound board

-Lighting equipment - dimmer packs, instruments and cabling 

-Shelves for storage and dressing rooms 

-Curtains for the magnificent but rather large windows 

-A new computer system for the box office

-Counter tops for the booth and box office 

-Banners and signage for windows and outside the building

story:
I'm María Elena Villasmil (Loto Bello), together with my friends Hermmankis Parra (Lucía Bello) and Ricardo Lugo (Lía Bello), we put together about 100 years doing theater in our country Venezuela (although if you look at us closely, we do not seem “that” old :)).

We write "Ellas Vienen de Maracaibo Show TV", a comedy where 3 Venezuelan immigrants and the son of one of them (The Bello family), are talking about political and social issues of Venezuela at this very moment.

We were moved to write because of the countless threads of history of Venezuelan immigrants that are heard randomly on any street in Santiago, Lima, Buenos Aires, Bogotá, Guayaquil or Miami. You can hear stories of rushed farewells; you can hear the Venezuelan everlasting birthday’s song and you can also see people putting their best smile on the video call for their family not to know they are sad because they are gone, far away; you can see children without their mothers; fathers are seen working hard in another country, doing jobs differents of those they were used to do to send money to their families "there". "There" we do not know very well if it is a nightmare or a utopia.

Having the script done, we want to play and make a tour starting in Chile (where I am, Hermmankis and Ricardo are in Venezuela... that's the thing with the fucking Diaspora) to show through theater what happens in our country.

For Hermmankis and Ricardo to reach Chile, we need 2 flight tickets Venezuela - Chile ( $1.000 +  $1.000 =  $2.000) as well as  $4.000 to start the general production (set design, costumes, puppet making, etc). so we are asking for $ 6,000! 

We know that we can rely on the help of our friends to achieve our goal. But beware, this is not a free help! We want you to become part of our effort and we want to be your voice (we have an elegant way to shout: Maduro, C’ETM!!!!).

For the help you give us you will have different perks (explained in the section "perks").

If you can not participate monetarily, we also receive the positive energy that you give us or the support by spreading our project among your networks. In advance, thanks a lot for the collaboration!

story:
Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White

As Mr. Kotomoto's Teas expands to selling dreams, a manager’s offensive email forces three employees to navigate their compromised morals and changing friendships. Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White is about the struggle of needing to work in a system you do not enjoy in order to survive.

NoMads Art Collective is so excited for this to be our first ever fully produced, full month-long run of a play! Kotomoto is a powerful, immediate play, recognizable to anyone who has worked in the service industry. Running from March 29 - April 21, 2019 at Strawdog Theatre in Chicago, this play will be made available to as many people as possible. To make this show the best it can possibly be, and to pay our artists the amount they deserve, we need your help!

Who are NoMads?

NoMads Art Collective was founded in 2013 by Ben Claus and Scott Jackoway. In 2018, NoMads changed focus to becoming a new play development company. We believe in development of work from its earliest forms to fully staged production. With our monthly play reading and art series, The Forge, and now this production of Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White, we work to embody our mission:

We, NoMads Art Collective, strive to develop new, experimental work. Our mission is to foster emerging artists as they grow to become the next turbulent American theatre. Our work often engages politics with absurdity as we complicate taboos and clichés⬅this is a cliché. We hope that through steadfast commitment to our art, we grow radical empathy in our audiences and ourselves.

Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White is the first fully staged play NoMads has produced in over a year. It has the longest run and biggest design team, and the artistic directors of NoMads Art Collective are leading the production together. Below you can learn a little bit about the artistic directors of NoMads and their role in Mr. Kotomoto.

  • Ben Claus (Playwright) is artistic director and resident playwright of NoMads Art Collective. Ben is a recent graduate from The Theatre School at DePaul's BFA Playwriting program, and has a minor in eastern religious studies as well. Along with writing plays, they also teach yoga and serve tea. 
  • Scott Jackoway (Director)  is artistic director of NoMads Art Collective. He is a director, actor, and sometimes writer. His artistic roots come from the Experimental Theatre Wing at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where he studied acting and grew his love of the absurd.
  • Danielle B. Szabo (Dramaturg) is artistic director and resident dramaturg for NoMads. She proudly hails from Flint, Michigan. She’s still looking for the right Snapchat filter to call home. She plans to hitchhike the galaxy, start a farm in Stardew Valley, and not panic.

Where does the $$$ go?

A fully funded Indiegogo will cover up to 60-75% of our goal budget. After paying the necessary fees for our rental of Strawdog Theatre, rehearsal space, and design budgets, all the rest of the money we raise goes directly to paying our artists, designers, and technicians. We are planning to employ 5 designers, 4 actors, 1 stage manager, and 4 production assistants. That's a lot of people!

Below you can see two graphs, one which is the bare minimum we need to produce Kotomoto, the other our ideal budget with a successful fundraising campaign.

 

In the above graph, you can see that our rental of Strawdog Theatre comprises the largest percentage of our budget. The space rental takes up over half of our minimum budget of $9,000. We have already raised almost $2,500, meaning if this campaign raised around $6,000, we could confidently produce the play without having to borrow from potential ticket sales. However, if this campaign is fully successful, we are on our way towards hitting our goal budget:

You can see now that the largest expense is paying our artists and technicians, which is what we believe a theatrical budget should look like. We believe that our 14 collaborators deserve to be paid for the close to 1,000 labor hours it takes to mount a full production. This budget totals over $15,000, so even with a fully funded campaign we are relying on our grant proposals and other fundraising efforts in order to pay our artists the amount they deserve.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that monetary donations are not the best way for everyone to support us. Or maybe you can donate but still want to contribute in other ways! We have many options for you:

  • Come see the show! 
  • Like us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter
  • Purchase season tickets, available now at nomadsartcollective.org/subscribe
  • If you are interested in large scale donations or sponsorships, please reach out to us directly at contactus@nomadsartcollective.org

Every dollar, every share, every mention of this campaign helps.  Thank you so much for making Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White happen!
story_txt:
Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White
As Mr. Kotomoto's Teas expands to selling dreams, a manager’s offensive email forces three employees to navigate their compromised morals and changing friendships. Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White is about the struggle of needing to work in a system you do not enjoy in order to survive.
NoMads Art Collective is so excited for this to be our first ever fully produced, full month-long run of a play! Kotomoto is a powerful, immediate play, recognizable to anyone who has worked in the service industry. Running from March 29 - April 21, 2019 at Strawdog Theatre in Chicago, this play will be made available to as many people as possible. To make this show the best it can possibly be, and to pay our artists the amount they deserve, we need your help!

Who are NoMads?
NoMads Art Collective was founded in 2013 by Ben Claus and Scott Jackoway. In 2018, NoMads changed focus to becoming a new play development company. We believe in development of work from its earliest forms to fully staged production. With our monthly play reading and art series, The Forge, and now this production of Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White, we work to embody our mission:
We, NoMads Art Collective, strive to develop new, experimental work. Our mission is to foster emerging artists as they grow to become the next turbulent American theatre. Our work often engages politics with absurdity as we complicate taboos and clichés⬅this is a cliché. We hope that through steadfast commitment to our art, we grow radical empathy in our audiences and ourselves.
Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White is the first fully staged play NoMads has produced in over a year. It has the longest run and biggest design team, and the artistic directors of NoMads Art Collective are leading the production together. Below you can learn a little bit about the artistic directors of NoMads and their role in Mr. Kotomoto.

Ben Claus (Playwright) is artistic director and resident playwright of NoMads Art Collective. Ben is a recent graduate from The Theatre School at DePaul's BFA Playwriting program, and has a minor in eastern religious studies as well. Along with writing plays, they also teach yoga and serve tea. 
Scott Jackoway (Director)  is artistic director of NoMads Art Collective. He is a director, actor, and sometimes writer. His artistic roots come from the Experimental Theatre Wing at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where he studied acting and grew his love of the absurd.
Danielle B. Szabo (Dramaturg) is artistic director and resident dramaturg for NoMads. She proudly hails from Flint, Michigan. She’s still looking for the right Snapchat filter to call home. She plans to hitchhike the galaxy, start a farm in Stardew Valley, and not panic.


Where does the $$$ go?
A fully funded Indiegogo will cover up to 60-75% of our goal budget. After paying the necessary fees for our rental of Strawdog Theatre, rehearsal space, and design budgets, all the rest of the money we raise goes directly to paying our artists, designers, and technicians. We are planning to employ 5 designers, 4 actors, 1 stage manager, and 4 production assistants. That's a lot of people!
Below you can see two graphs, one which is the bare minimum we need to produce Kotomoto, the other our ideal budget with a successful fundraising campaign.
 

In the above graph, you can see that our rental of Strawdog Theatre comprises the largest percentage of our budget. The space rental takes up over half of our minimum budget of $9,000. We have already raised almost $2,500, meaning if this campaign raised around $6,000, we could confidently produce the play without having to borrow from potential ticket sales. However, if this campaign is fully successful, we are on our way towards hitting our goal budget:

You can see now that the largest expense is paying our artists and technicians, which is what we believe a theatrical budget should look like. We believe that our 14 collaborators deserve to be paid for the close to 1,000 labor hours it takes to mount a full production. This budget totals over $15,000, so even with a fully funded campaign we are relying on our grant proposals and other fundraising efforts in order to pay our artists the amount they deserve.

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that monetary donations are not the best way for everyone to support us. Or maybe you can donate but still want to contribute in other ways! We have many options for you:

Come see the show! 
Like us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter
Share this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter
Purchase season tickets, available now at nomadsartcollective.org/subscribe

If you are interested in large scale donations or sponsorships, please reach out to us directly at contactus@nomadsartcollective.org

Every dollar, every share, every mention of this campaign helps.  Thank you so much for making Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White happen!

story:
My play ZAMBONI has just been accepted into the 20th Annual FringeNYC!

Jamie has been driving the Zamboni at the local ice rink for decades. With his mother dying, his only living relative, Jamie attempts to find love in other places: from the local convenience store clerk to a 14 year-old girl he talks to on the phone. But when he meets an age-appropriate love interest, Jamie's faced with an important decision- who should he choose to love? And also: how do you choose to love? Like the path a Zamboni makes along ice, Jamie's life has been a regimented routine-- but now he must face everything and make a decision before it glides him along an irreversible track. 

          This is going to be my first production, not only in NYC, but ever! I'm an early career playwright and a recent graduate from Bennington College - so this is an incredible opportunity for me. The Fringe only accepts a small percentage of applicants each year so this is also a very prestigious honor.  

          Self-producing requires a lot of time, energy, and (unfortunately) money! The FringeNYC provides a venue, a venue director, and help with marketing...but the registration fee alone is $700. This fee is due on May 15th. 
          
          In addition to the registration fee, I'm hoping to raise enough funds to give modest stipends to my actors (seven total!) and the crew who makes the magic all happen: director, stage manager, and designers. Not to mention a tip for my venue director which is expected by the end of the Fringe run in August (typically $100). 
          
          I'm trying to produce this play as modestly as possible. That means I'm planning on spending little to no money on costumes, props, and set pieces- but the reality is that I'll inevitably have to buy some things. 
        
          I have been working at Primary Stages off-broadway theater company for the past two years and have learned a lot of lessons in producing responsibly and creatively. They are giving me some in-kind donations, such as free rehearsal space, which is a huge savings (approximately $2,500) to my budget.
          
          I am so excited to be a part of the prestigious FringeNYC and the only thing holding me back is money. I am really proud of this play and I'm excited to finally get my first production (and of this caliber, too)! ZAMBONI is having a workshop at the Playwrights Center in Minneapolis this upcoming June and a production with FringeNYC would be the perfect follow-up to that. This is a dream come true and with your help this production will become a reality.  

Please spread the word (and this link!)! I know not everyone can contribute, but sharing this campaign to others is just as important (and free)! 

XOXO S-P O'B

story:
The National Theatre of MatMadia presents:

SHE MOON -

A show about butts, A celebration of booty, and a gathering of all different She's

Also we're doing a whole connection thing to the moon, mythology and paganism which is pretty cool. Butts and Moon Goddesses. 

 

SHE MOON will be a unique, one-night-only experience. We are transforming the Muse warehouse space to a magical lunar plain filled with butts in the sky. SHE MOON is a collection of stories told through vignette, burlesque (Buttlesque), clowning, aerial, butt puppetry, dance and magic.  

The ensemble of Butt Nymphs is prepared to bare all  talkin' 'bout big butts, small butts, putting foreign objects in our butts, how we move our butts, how we cover our asses and how we own our shit. SHE MOON is people telling their Butt Stories to the Moon, because she’s always there to listen.

ALL BUTTS GET PAID. And we have a lot of them 5 story tellers, 2 aerialists, 4 musicians and an ever growing  collection of crew and designers.

You can't shit exposure. ALL BUTTS GET PAID.... #allbutsgetpaid

We are artists funding other artists for the creation of art. 

 

EVERY DOLLAR HELPS

That dollar just paid for some hot glue, honey

... that 500 dollars just turned the lights on and that's good too. 

Where your Money Goes

Costume budget of mainly pasties, greacian dresses and LEDs

Lights and projectors to create the lunar scape

Paying artist to make Godesses head pieces and supplies

12 artists and innumerable crew ( 5 story tellers, 2 aerialists, 4 band members, Stage Manager, Production Manager.. etc. etc.)

Residency Fees (Keeping the lights on)

Butt related items

Balloons

What's In It For You?

Check out the prizes. Seriously. We catered them to really take care of your ass. One of them is getting a personal video message from Sailor Moon herself. Another is getting champagne poured in your mouth like a Goddess.  

*also a warm fuzzy and bit of a tickle- the one from funding an art show about butts*

The Impact

SHE MOON is an original piece and took months of careful development. SHE MOON says Women own their butts. Women can do what ever the fuck they want with their butts. What is a woman, any ways? Why are butts funny sumtimes and sexy looking other times? And why do we feel so damn connected to the Moon? 

But the problem is..

We are rated R. We do not pull punches, and we need your help to promote truth telling and uncompromising art to a large audience.

No haz Money....

That's cool. Please share the campaign. Every like on Facebook helps make us seen. Every time you share us through word of mouth, an indie producer gets her wings.  You can also follow our rehearsal process on Facebook and Instagram, and we'd love to see you at the performance. If you want to volunteer or be part of the night in any way, shoot me an email at shemoonnyc@gmail.com. I only require that you dress up like a moon goddess with the rest of us.

About the The National Theatre of MatMadia

The National Theatre of MatMadia, co-founded by Maddy Campbell and Matt Phillips, is a collective of Brooklyn based artists focused on putting fun, absurd and monstrous ideas on stage. With a base in clowning and bouffan combined with classically trained actors, we delve head first into extreme physical acting, fire performance and drag. Our stories use 'the mystique' to explore themes about mental illness, ‘fucking with gender’ and the psychedelic. Known to ‘not pull any punches’ our work is violent, messy and monstrous.

story:
What is 'Sad Clowns: A Fable'? 

Sad Clowns: A Fable is a brand new play written by  Gamal ElSawah and produced by Showdogs in a co-production with FRIGID New York.

Gamal, Conrado, and Sajda founded Showdogs - a theatre company committed to work that is provocative, diverse, and affordable to all - just over a year ago and Sad Clowns will be their first official, full-length production. 

The play follows a clown, named Clown, who doesn't feel much like a clown at all lately. In a world where people are defined solely by occupations assigned to them at birth, Clown and his friend Kitty – a cat with a passion for making suits – rebel against the norm as they try to find a new path for themselves. 

With your donation, you will make Sad Clowns a reality. You will not only help us pay our hardworking artists, but also invest in the future of an emerging theatre company that prioritizes underrepresented voices who might otherwise go unheard.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

There are many things to consider when putting up a show in New York City. Theatre is a deeply rewarding experience, but it requires a lot of work, time, and money. We crunched the numbers, and found that to put up this show we need a budget of at least $6,000.  

Specifically, your donation will be helping us: 

  • Rent the theater where our play will be presented. 
  • Pay for set pieces, costumes, and other materials to bring the world of our play to life.  
  • Make sure all the artists working on the show (actors, designers, and stage crew) get properly compensated for their work. 
  • Create promotional materials and a marketing campaign so that we can reach as many people as possible. 

To thank you for your donation we have come up with a few perks! Depending on your donation, you can get the behind-the-scenes blooper reel of our Indiegogo campaign, early access to Showdogs' official holiday movie, tickets to our show, and much more.
