story:
THIS IS PERSONAL

While you have the chance to unmute a person's voice after 80+ years, it is also about YOU! 

We aren’t simply telling one woman’s story. Rather, we are speaking to the experience of all who continue to face oppression and steadfastly appeal for their rights in turbulent times worldwide.

 

A RIVETING STORY

Institutionalized twice by her husband, the musical voice of a once ambitious composer fell completely silent in 1939. Just before the death of Amy’s daughter in 2018, Amy Thomson McKean’s great niece, Jamieson Thomson Thomas, recovered a trove of Amy’s handwritten and published scores. Amy’s story and compositions give the audience a rare look into the perspective of a female composer highlighting the natural world during some of the most turbulent and fascinating years in our nation’s history.

A publicity shot for a performance in New York City in 1916 portrays a woman ready to embrace the excitement of life in New York.  

In 1917, just as her brother volunteered to serve as an ambulance driver World War  I, Amy moved to Brooklyn, New York where she marched for women’s rights, rode the new elevated trains and subways, learned to drive a car, and composed music to accompany the poetry of the Harlem Renaissance. 

During her life, Amy was a celebrated musician and composer whose works were performed in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Boston, and Rhode Island. In addition to her music, she loved the outdoors and spent countless hours in parks with her children. 

Her performances ended abruptly in 1939 when the world plunged into turmoil. What happened to that confident woman? All photos of her performing at the piano and letters of correspondence have disappeared.  

With the success of this campaign, in March 2020, we will present eight pieces out of more than 50 handwritten scores in the process of transcription. Documentation of the performance at Timucua Arts Foundation in Orlando will be circulated to obtain future engagements and assist us in recovering archival information.   

 

SUPPORT US NOW BECAUSE:

The Mysterious Life of Amy Upham McKean is a story that deserves and needs to be told. Composer Amy McKean’s creative musical voice and fascinating life story were on the verge of being permanently and deliberately silenced both during her lifetime and posthumously. Amy was a composer living and working in New York during a turbulent time in the city’s and country’s history. She was institutionalized twice during her lifetime, and her correspondence was destroyed after her death. This project is an attempt to resurrect her music — which hasn’t been heard in public for 80 years — and her story.

 

With The Mysterious Life of Amy Upham McKean, writer Charlie Griffin aims to bring Amy to life on stage by imagining what she would say for herself if she could, while composer Mark Piszsczek has painstakingly and lovingly transcribed or arranged her actual music for live performances of vocal songs, piano works, and wind quintets. Amy’s grand-niece Jamieson Thomson Thomas, an artist herself, has overseen the project and done years of research and fact-gathering. This is an ambitious and emotionally compelling project. 

 

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?

Amy’s story is not just a composer’s story. It’s a woman’s story. In an era characterized by divisiveness, doubt, distrust and growing discrimination, voices are continuing to be silenced, just as they have been in the past. Our foremothers worked relentlessly and took great risks to strengthen women’s and minority rights and equality and Amy’s music is a haunting reminder of our past and the importance of protecting all that has been accomplished. We must continue to work for our rights to insure the future of the next generation.

 

This project is at a nascent stage, and once we create and document the first performance, we can take the story on the road.  

 

WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOUR HELP.

 

Our team has worked tirelessly scanning historical references to find the hidden story of Amy Thomson McKean. We’ve scanned photos, transcribed music, developed an hour-long script, and secured a location for the premiere performance. The resulting performance paints a picture of New York during her lifetime and recounts her story, as it may have been, through the voice of her past self as it would be told today.

 

ONLY THROUGH YOUR SUPPORT, can we bring the voice and recovered works of this remarkable composer to life. With your help we will create and document a performance that will unmute Amy Thomson McKean after 80+ years. 

 

While $ 6,000 will not take us to the project finish line, it will allow us to launch the first critical performance with outstanding performers and musicians, and to capture video documentation. Documentation will allow us to attempt to secure grants/funding to take the show on the road. Our goal is to perform in New York September 2021, and other venues (especially Boston, MA or Providence, RI, where Amy lived and performed during her lifetime). 

 

WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORT?

We have some terrific items to offer for your participation in this project. 

  • The transcription of Amy’s music.
  • Script writing of the story in Amy’s voice, as a ghost of the present representing her past.
  • The creation and preparation of the script
  • Hiring a professional actor/singer to play Amy in performance of script and music.  
  • Hiring six musicians to perform music. (piano, flute, clarinet, oboe, French horn, bassoon)
  • Creating video documentation of the performance  to be used to market performance to other venues, especially, Boston, Providence, Brooklyn, and Manhattan where Amy lived and performed during her lifetime. 
  • Marketing and programming to maximize visibility of her work and message.
  • Developing a framework to create scalable models that we can tour in other communities

 

* All donations will go directly into production and/or post production expenses such performers, venue and equipment rental, video production and marketing future performances. 

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

March 26, 2020 Performance:

Venue rental                                                              $ 1000

Recording studio rental                                              500

Actor rehearsal and performance                          1134

Wind quintet rehearsal & performance              1000

Pianist rehearsal and performance                        250 

Design of Video, Marketing, and Rewards            500

Other (graphic design)                                               500

Campaign Expenses                                                  1000

Subtotal                                                                        5,884

IF WE EXCEED OUR GOAL:

Post Performance Expenses:

Music Transcription and Arrangements            3000

Script Writing, Editing and Preparation             2000

Recording studio rental                                              500

Actor/singer for recording                                     2000

Publicity/Marketing                                                    500

Photography                                                                  500

Video Editing                                                                  250

Total  Post Performance Expenses                $     8750

 

Total Project Funding                                        $ 14, 634

 

On behalf of Amy and the collaborators who want her music heard and her story told, we are grateful for your support and thank you from the bottom of our hearts. 

 

LEARN A LITTLE MORE

ABOUT THE COMPOSER

Amy Thomson McKean, composer-pianist, resided in Jackson Heights, Long Island. She was born Feb 22, 1893 in Pawtucket, RI, and died on December 31, 1972 in NYC.

Amy’s family immigrated to the United States from Scotland in 1884 and settled in Pawtucket, R.I. She studied at Pawtucket High School where she wrote the words and music to her class ode. Her early training was for piano, with Felix Fox, concert pianist of Boston who established Fox-Buonamici School of Pianoforte in at 403 Marlborough Street in Boston's Back Bay. McKean advanced to specialize in voice and composition with Bainbridge Crist, composer, also of Boston. She later attended the Rhode Island School of Music and wrote for the violin, piano, and voice. She moved to NY in 1917 and lived at the Hotel Margaret, 95 Columbia Heights. She was a member of the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park, NYC and later became a member of the Poetry Society of America. She was involved with the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences and was regularly published in their Bulletin. Amy married Alexander Mckean at the end of her first year living in New York and they had two children: Robert, and a daughter Elaine (who are frequently seen with her in Cambridge Court and Prospect Park enjoying nature). She performed in Boston, Providence, and in Manhattan and Brooklyn at the Tonkuenstler Society, The Three Arts Club, Salon of the Seven Arts, Jackson Heights Music Club, New York Assembly Hall, First Congregational Church in Clinton, Mass, Hotel Bossert, Great Northern Hotel, Hotel Margaret, Hotel St. George, Apollo Studios, Chateau Garden Club, Various locations with the Jackson Heights Chorale Group, The National Arts Club, on the radio on WBBC, on The Voice of the Firestone with Margaret Speaks on WOR New York, and many private residences.

 

ABOUT THE COLLABORATORS

Composer Charlie Griffin is launching a second career as a writer of fiction and creative non-fiction. He recently graduated valedictorian with a BFA in Creative Writing for Entertainment from Full Sail University. With a background in improv, comedy and film acting, Griffin employs lessons learned in those fields in his writing. In 2017 he wrote, produced and starred in his own show for the Orlando Fringe Festival. His work has been published by Flash Fiction Magazine, The Scarlet Leaf Review, ArtBorne Magazine, and Hidden Remote. He is a writer and publisher member of ASCAP. 

“As soon as Mark Piszczek told me about his experience working with the music of Amy Upham McKean, I knew that there was a compelling story to be told there, and I was immediately curious to know what Amy's music sounded like. As director of the Central Florida Composers Forum, I knew we had a concert date reserved for March 2020, and already had my radar up for something fitting for Women's History Month. This project seemed more than perfect. Given the vision of the project as it grew, my experiences as a composer and a writer, along with my love of American 20th century cultural history, I was eager to inhabit Amy’s perspective. Amy’s life and rich story has been fertile ground indeed.”

 

Mark Piszczek (b. 1957) is a professional composer and arranger who performs on both oboe and saxophone. Piszczek has a deep background in both jazz and classical composition and performance.  His recent orchestral work, Songs from the Gulf of Sorrows, was premiered by The Brevard Symphony Orchestra in 2016.

“I've loved working on this interesting historical, musicological project with Jamieson Thomson Thomas. I've transcribed, adapted and made audio files of hand written musical manuscripts, songs and scores composed by her great aunt, Amy Upham Thomson McKean between 1914 and 1939. Amy was quite a talent and lived a fascinating life. Jamieson is working on uncovering most of the history while I'm transcribing some sixty compositions. There may be even more if we can find them.There are boxes of undated musical manuscripts, letters, photos, old newspaper articles  and we’re systematically going through all of these trying to unravel the true and sometimes tragic story of her mysterious, enigmatic life. She faced the daunting challenges and prejudices that many gifted, artistic women of her era had to endure.” 

Jamieson Thomas, great niece of Amy Thomson McKean, is an artist who explores cultural and personal history and the intersection between humanity and the natural environment. Through painting, photography, video and sculptural installations her interdisciplinary work addresses our individual imprint on our surroundings and questions our role of dominance in the global ecosystem, and considers solutions that will lead to balance and coexistence. www.jamiesonthomas.com

“When I received Amy’s music from her ailing 91 yr. old daughter Elaine McKean Stumpf, I attempted to gather information about her mother but she struggled as she recounted her story and became sad. She hadn't heard the music since she was young, and desperately wanted to hear the music again. Mark Piszczek transcribed a dozen pieces and burned a CD for me to play on a CD player. As we sat and listening, she began to cry and said the memory was too painful to share any more of the story. From the little I learned before Elaine’s death, I knew that Amy was a vivacious woman who loved living in Brooklyn and the energy of the city. She embraced the women’s movement and performed her music actively, and that while loving, her father could be stern. Elaine mentioned her mother had been institutionalized twice for “nerves” and I realized that there was much more to the story and I wanted to know what silenced her music.”

ABOUT THE PERFORMERS

Actor Singer: Kelly Morris Rowan

Kelly Morris Rowan is a full-time vocalist at the Voices of Liberty in Epcot. She also performs in various other shows at Disney and Universal. An accomplished regional theatre actress, renaissance faire performer, and cabaret songstress, she’s ever grateful for chances to tell a good story. Love and thanks to Arthur. www.kellymorrisrowan.com

Musicians

Piano Accompanist: Kristine Griffin

Kristine (b. Kulikova) Griffin is an award-winning pianist born in the Latvian seaport city of Liepaja, where she graduated in piano performance and pedagogy from the Emils Melngailis School of Music before moving on to a Post-Graduate Diploma in piano accompaniment from the Latvian State Music Academy in Riga.  She went on to become the piano concertmaster for the Liepaja Symphony Orchestra. She joined the Rollins College Music Department as a staff accompanist in 2012. With her main focus on chamber music, she has premiered many contemporary Latvian and American composers’ music, and performed in many multicultural and international projects.

The woodwind quintet is derived from the Alterity Chamber Orchestra, an Orlando-based ensemble known for its dedication to performing contemporary music at the highest levels: Tina Edelstein, flute; Beatriz Ramirez, oboe; Jessica Speak, clarinet; Matt Tavera, horn; and Christian Eberle, bassoon.

Link to Event at Timuqua Arts Foundation

FACEBOOK

INSTAGRAM
story_txt:
THIS IS PERSONALWhile you have the chance to unmute a person's voice after 80+ years, it is also about YOU! We aren’t simply telling one woman’s story. Rather, we are speaking to the experience of all who continue to face oppression and steadfastly appeal for their rights in turbulent times worldwide. A RIVETING STORYInstitutionalized twice by her husband, the musical voice of a once ambitious composer fell completely silent in 1939. Just before the death of Amy’s daughter in 2018, Amy Thomson McKean’s great niece, Jamieson Thomson Thomas, recovered a trove of Amy’s handwritten and published scores. Amy’s story and compositions give the audience a rare look into the perspective of a female composer highlighting the natural world during some of the most turbulent and fascinating years in our nation’s history.A publicity shot for a performance in New York City in 1916 portrays a woman ready to embrace the excitement of life in New York.  In 1917, just as her brother volunteered to serve as an ambulance driver World War  I, Amy moved to Brooklyn, New York where she marched for women’s rights, rode the new elevated trains and subways, learned to drive a car, and composed music to accompany the poetry of the Harlem Renaissance. During her life, Amy was a celebrated musician and composer whose works were performed in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Boston, and Rhode Island. In addition to her music, she loved the outdoors and spent countless hours in parks with her children. Her performances ended abruptly in 1939 when the world plunged into turmoil. What happened to that confident woman? All photos of her performing at the piano and letters of correspondence have disappeared.  With the success of this campaign, in March 2020, we will present eight pieces out of more than 50 handwritten scores in the process of transcription. Documentation of the performance at Timucua Arts Foundation in Orlando will be circulated to obtain future engagements and assist us in recovering archival information.    SUPPORT US NOW BECAUSE:The Mysterious Life of Amy Upham McKean is a story that deserves and needs to be told. Composer Amy McKean’s creative musical voice and fascinating life story were on the verge of being permanently and deliberately silenced both during her lifetime and posthumously. Amy was a composer living and working in New York during a turbulent time in the city’s and country’s history. She was institutionalized twice during her lifetime, and her correspondence was destroyed after her death. This project is an attempt to resurrect her music — which hasn’t been heard in public for 80 years — and her story. With The Mysterious Life of Amy Upham McKean, writer Charlie Griffin aims to bring Amy to life on stage by imagining what she would say for herself if she could, while composer Mark Piszsczek has painstakingly and lovingly transcribed or arranged her actual music for live performances of vocal songs, piano works, and wind quintets. Amy’s grand-niece Jamieson Thomson Thomas, an artist herself, has overseen the project and done years of research and fact-gathering. This is an ambitious and emotionally compelling project.  WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?Amy’s story is not just a composer’s story. It’s a woman’s story. In an era characterized by divisiveness, doubt, distrust and growing discrimination, voices are continuing to be silenced, just as they have been in the past. Our foremothers worked relentlessly and took great risks to strengthen women’s and minority rights and equality and Amy’s music is a haunting reminder of our past and the importance of protecting all that has been accomplished. We must continue to work for our rights to insure the future of the next generation. This project is at a nascent stage, and once we create and document the first performance, we can take the story on the road.   WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOUR HELP. Our team has worked tirelessly scanning historical references to find the hidden story of Amy Thomson McKean. We’ve scanned photos, transcribed music, developed an hour-long script, and secured a location for the premiere performance. The resulting performance paints a picture of New York during her lifetime and recounts her story, as it may have been, through the voice of her past self as it would be told today. ONLY THROUGH YOUR SUPPORT, can we bring the voice and recovered works of this remarkable composer to life. With your help we will create and document a performance that will unmute Amy Thomson McKean after 80+ years.  While $ 6,000 will not take us to the project finish line, it will allow us to launch the first critical performance with outstanding performers and musicians, and to capture video documentation. Documentation will allow us to attempt to secure grants/funding to take the show on the road. Our goal is to perform in New York September 2021, and other venues (especially Boston, MA or Providence, RI, where Amy lived and performed during her lifetime).  WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORT?We have some terrific items to offer for your participation in this project. 
The transcription of Amy’s music.
Script writing of the story in Amy’s voice, as a ghost of the present representing her past.
The creation and preparation of the script
Hiring a professional actor/singer to play Amy in performance of script and music.  
Hiring six musicians to perform music. (piano, flute, clarinet, oboe, French horn, bassoon)
Creating video documentation of the performance  to be used to market performance to other venues, especially, Boston, Providence, Brooklyn, and Manhattan where Amy lived and performed during her lifetime. 
Marketing and programming to maximize visibility of her work and message.
Developing a framework to create scalable models that we can tour in other communities
 * All donations will go directly into production and/or post production expenses such performers, venue and equipment rental, video production and marketing future performances.  BUDGET BREAKDOWNMarch 26, 2020 Performance:Venue rental                                                              $ 1000Recording studio rental                                              500Actor rehearsal and performance                          1134Wind quintet rehearsal & performance              1000Pianist rehearsal and performance                        250 Design of Video, Marketing, and Rewards            500Other (graphic design)                                               500Campaign Expenses                                                  1000Subtotal                                                                        5,884IF WE EXCEED OUR GOAL:Post Performance Expenses:Music Transcription and Arrangements            3000Script Writing, Editing and Preparation             2000Recording studio rental                                              500Actor/singer for recording                                     2000Publicity/Marketing                                                    500Photography                                                                  500Video Editing                                                                  250Total  Post Performance Expenses                $     8750 Total Project Funding                                        $ 14, 634 On behalf of Amy and the collaborators who want her music heard and her story told, we are grateful for your support and thank you from the bottom of our hearts.  LEARN A LITTLE MOREABOUT THE COMPOSERAmy Thomson McKean, composer-pianist, resided in Jackson Heights, Long Island. She was born Feb 22, 1893 in Pawtucket, RI, and died on December 31, 1972 in NYC.Amy’s family immigrated to the United States from Scotland in 1884 and settled in Pawtucket, R.I. She studied at Pawtucket High School where she wrote the words and music to her class ode. Her early training was for piano, with Felix Fox, concert pianist of Boston who established Fox-Buonamici School of Pianoforte in at 403 Marlborough Street in Boston's Back Bay. McKean advanced to specialize in voice and composition with Bainbridge Crist, composer, also of Boston. She later attended the Rhode Island School of Music and wrote for the violin, piano, and voice. She moved to NY in 1917 and lived at the Hotel Margaret, 95 Columbia Heights. She was a member of the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park, NYC and later became a member of the Poetry Society of America. She was involved with the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences and was regularly published in their Bulletin. Amy married Alexander Mckean at the end of her first year living in New York and they had two children: Robert, and a daughter Elaine (who are frequently seen with her in Cambridge Court and Prospect Park enjoying nature). She performed in Boston, Providence, and in Manhattan and Brooklyn at the Tonkuenstler Society, The Three Arts Club, Salon of the Seven Arts, Jackson Heights Music Club, New York Assembly Hall, First Congregational Church in Clinton, Mass, Hotel Bossert, Great Northern Hotel, Hotel Margaret, Hotel St. George, Apollo Studios, Chateau Garden Club, Various locations with the Jackson Heights Chorale Group, The National Arts Club, on the radio on WBBC, on The Voice of the Firestone with Margaret Speaks on WOR New York, and many private residences. ABOUT THE COLLABORATORSComposer Charlie Griffin is launching a second career as a writer of fiction and creative non-fiction. He recently graduated valedictorian with a BFA in Creative Writing for Entertainment from Full Sail University. With a background in improv, comedy and film acting, Griffin employs lessons learned in those fields in his writing. In 2017 he wrote, produced and starred in his own show for the Orlando Fringe Festival. His work has been published by Flash Fiction Magazine, The Scarlet Leaf Review, ArtBorne Magazine, and Hidden Remote. He is a writer and publisher member of ASCAP. “As soon as Mark Piszczek told me about his experience working with the music of Amy Upham McKean, I knew that there was a compelling story to be told there, and I was immediately curious to know what Amy's music sounded like. This project seemed more than perfect. Given the vision of the project as it grew, my experiences as a composer and a writer, along with my love of American 20th century cultural history, I was eager to inhabit Amy’s perspective. Amy’s life and rich story has been fertile ground indeed.” Mark Piszczek (b. 1957) is a professional composer and arranger who performs on both oboe and saxophone. Piszczek has a deep background in both jazz and classical composition and performance.  His recent orchestral work, Songs from the Gulf of Sorrows, was premiered by The Brevard Symphony Orchestra in 2016.“I've loved working on this interesting historical, musicological project with Jamieson Thomson Thomas. Jamieson is working on uncovering most of the history while I'm transcribing some sixty compositions. story:
Hello,

We are Orama Theatrical Enterprises and very excited about our new original production, SUMMER ROCK a new musical. We are industry professional voice instructors and founders of The School Of Singing. We began our journey of producing musicals with Ken Davenport in the revival of Godspell on Broadway. We successfully wrote and staged a modern rendition of Charles Dickens’ A CHRISTMAS CAROL a new musical at Davenport Black Box Theatre. Now, we are poised to do the same with our first original story and production of SUMMER ROCK a new musical.

We have been asked why SUMMER ROCK a new musical is so important to us. I would have to say that it’s greatest importance lies in the fact that through personal illness and trials, we have persevered and have attained one of the best schools in vocal training in Long Island and NYC. Now we are set to do the same with our original musical, SUMMER ROCK. Dreams really do come true with hard work.

Another factor of importance lies in the first ever cast recording of SUMMER ROCK a new musical, which is one of the driving forces of this campaign. The cast and creative team are ecstatic at the thought of having the opportunity of a cast recording, but we need your help to make that dream come true. In addition, fulfilling this campaign will afford the opportunity to bring you a fresh and new visual of SUMMER ROCK a new musical to the stage. Your summer won't be complete without it.

Your contribution to SUMMER ROCK a new musical will not only help us achieve the monetary means, but more importantly the dreams of this very talented cast that we invite you to live out your  dreams through. Any further words of how grateful we are of your support would only cheapen the magnitude of thanks we have for each and every one of you.

What We Need & What You Get

Take the journey with us through time and help us raise $2,000 in the following areas.

• The first ever SUMMER ROCK a new musical cast recording. The cast recording will take a monetary effort of $1,200, which will cover the recording engineer, mixing, mastering, artwork, and CD duplication.

• The remaining $800 will go toward the creative scenery needed to bring out the incredible journey the SUMMER ROCK a new musical cast and you the journey traveler will experience.

• We have a flexible goal, which allows us to collect what is raised and we hope to raise above and beyond our modest goal. Because of your support, we have special rewards made just for you.

The Impact

Why is SUMMER ROCK a new musical important and what impact will it have?

• Simply put, why not? In addition, the story is exactly what we need to see today, family and friends coming together because of the love they have for one another.

• We have one of the most successful schools in the art of singing and have produced five shows with great success. Though not without challenge, we aim to do the same with SUMMER ROCK a new musical.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

• Follow us on Facebook, and Twitter and share our posts to help spread the word about “SUMMER ROCK a new musical”.

• Utilize the easy to use Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Our final thoughts that need saying. SUMMER ROCK a new musical would not be possible without the help of the creative team Amanda Witowski, Alexander Watkins-Lopez, Nico Morejon, Marissa Harris, and Delaney Eckhart. Each bringing something unique to the table, this creative team is working extremely hard to create this heartwarming and distinguished production. Let us not forget to mention the incredible and talented cast of SUMMER ROCK a new musical. They look forward to performing for you, and by the way, all of this would not be possible without YOU!

story:
Plunge Theatre are devoted to making work which is accessible, worryingly relatable and digs into the depths of our grotesque humanity, before spitting it back out again as a joke. They always leave their audience laughing but thinking about something too, with a proven success rate for opening conversations with their disarming, but brutally honest brand of comedy. (see Fig 1.)

Fig. 1

CLINGFILM will do this too. This time putting a Pole, Turk, a Brit and their unlikely friendship in the spotlight, in a show that is as much about their secret anxieties, their embarrassing habits and their culturally informed quirks, as it is about turning 30 in a London headed for Brexit.  

This friendship and this combination of cultural backgrounds, hasn’t been put on stage before - and it’s about bloody time! It’s important for representation, it’s important for women and it’s important for the comedy world. If not the ENTIRE world.

And... it’s important for Plunge too. CLINGFILM is step one in Plunge’s major strategic endeavour to get their sitcom of the same name, commissioned and on the television.  Plunge want to be on the television because they are fame-hungry. But more importantly, fame ready. But even more importantly, a wider audience will mean that more people will be able to benefit from this accessible content. They promise to deliver something totally original – when was the last time you saw a sitcom about a Polish girl, a Turkish girl and a British girl?

Plunge are asking for £7,000 to get CLINGFILM to Edinburgh.  This will pay for:

  • Venue hire
  • Marketing 
  • Transport 
  • Props and costume
  • Living costs

In return for your support, you’ll get some excellently niche prizes and be a part of a project, which grabs the gender and ethnic inequalities of this industry by the balls,  tackling it straight on, one hilarious millennial joke at a time.

Plunge Theatre are Izabella Malewska, Tutku Barbaros & Lilly Pollard.  Unified by a keen sense of the ridiculous and a commitment to disrupting the mainstream, they have been making work together for the best part of ten years. They galloped onto the scene as Emerging Artists at the Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith in 2013. They were then residents at Theatre Delicatessen.

Their most recent short, SHALLOW got them through to the Musical Comedy Awards and the ‘Commended list’ for Funny Women Shorts Award 2017. Their short film, CLINGFILM gained them a honourable mention in the London-Worldwide Comedy Short Film Festival.

Outside of Plunge Theatre, Izabella acts (up), Tutku writes & Lilly sings. Izabella recently appeared in ITV’s Cold Feet. Tutku’s play ‘Layla & Youssef’ was developed on The Royal Court Writer’s programme, and made the Bruntwood Top 100 & Lilly’s debut track was featured on BBC Introducing.  

In tandem to their belief about accessible content, Plunge also believe that art should be in the hands of the audience, so they relish the opportunity to be funded by people hungry for this content, rather than maintain the status quo and see only the same work funded by the same big bodies. Plunge want to connect with the people who are supporting them, and that’s why their prizes allow them to interact with their audiences in some way.  They feel like they’re on the cusp of something big, and want to bring as many people with them as possible!

Please share this campaign and help spread the word about the project.  If you specifically know someone who is VERY philanthropic, or very careless with their cash, please send this their way...

"[a] lively and indignant feminist mash-up.” (The Scotsman)

"It’s lively and feisty and angry and powerful." (The Stage)

"There is cake, there is dancing, there is laughter. Above all though, there is an honest, brutal, well-crafted representation of the challenges modern women face, all wrapped up in an hour-long parcel of theatre, that will leave you feeling like part of the biggest, most brilliant team ever. I don’t think you’re ready for this jelly." (Standard Issue Magazine)

“Totally bizarre” (A confused man)

 

SHALLOW (MUSIC VIDEO)

 

CLINGFILM (SHORT FILM)

They galloped onto the scene as Emerging Artists at the Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith in 2013. They were then residents at Theatre Delicatessen.
Their most recent short, SHALLOW got them through to the Musical Comedy Awards and the ‘Commended list’ for Funny Women Shorts Award 2017. Their short film, CLINGFILM gained them a honourable mention in the London-Worldwide Comedy Short Film Festival.
Outside of Plunge Theatre, Izabella acts (up), Tutku writes & Lilly sings. Izabella recently appeared in ITV’s Cold Feet. Tutku’s play ‘Layla & Youssef’ was developed on The Royal Court Writer’s programme, and made the Bruntwood Top 100 & Lilly’s debut track was featured on BBC Introducing.  

In tandem to their belief about accessible content, Plunge also believe that art should be in the hands of the audience, so they relish the opportunity to be funded by people hungry for this content, rather than maintain the status quo and see only the same work funded by the same big bodies. Plunge want to connect with the people who are supporting them, and that’s why their prizes allow them to interact with their audiences in some way.  They feel like they’re on the cusp of something big, and want to bring as many people with them as possible!

Please share this campaign and help spread the word about the project.  If you specifically know someone who is VERY philanthropic, or very careless with their cash, please send this their way...

"[a] lively and indignant feminist mash-up.” (The Scotsman)
"It’s lively and feisty and angry and powerful." (The Stage)
"There is cake, there is dancing, there is laughter. Above all though, there is an honest, brutal, well-crafted representation of the challenges modern women face, all wrapped up in an hour-long parcel of theatre, that will leave you feeling like part of the biggest, most brilliant team ever. I don’t think you’re ready for this jelly." (Standard Issue Magazine)
“Totally bizarre” (A confused man)
 
SHALLOW (MUSIC VIDEO)

 
CLINGFILM (SHORT FILM)

story:
Our Story

From the company that brought Woody Guthrie Dreams to the stage at Theatre for the New City in Fall 2011. Written by Michael Patrick Flanagan Smith with Benjamin Forstenzer,  HISTRIONICS  is a one-person play starring Brendan Hines.

Smith and Forstenzer began writing the play in Baltimore back in 2001 during the second Bush administration, and now almost two decades later it is set to world premiere at TNC in New York City on November 30th and run for three weeks, closing December 17th, 2017.

The Impact

In the mid 1850's, when Buchanan was president, the country was a mess of internal turmoil; lines were drawn, and America was divided.  In HISTRIONICS, we look at that past, consider it in relationship to the present, and examine the ways in which actions today can have great repercussion in the future. In this technological age filled with unrest, political upheavals, and Twitter wars, a play's the thing to remind the world that history repeats itself!

What We Need & What You Get

HISTRIONICS is being produced by Executive Director Crystal Field and Theater for the New City, who have donated performance and rehearsal space - valued at tens of thousands of dollars. Plus we’ve raised $3,500 already through private donations, we now we need $8,700 to cover the rest of the costs to produce this play.  This campaign will pay for costumes, the set, as well as our lighting and sound design.  It will cover the modest stipends we are offering to our excellent design team and incredibly talented actor, Brendan Hines. This campaign will pay for our fliers and press material so we can get the word out loud and clear about what we believe is a powerful & important project.

Ways You Can Help and Why?!

Please tell your friends!  Spread the word, donate early and often! 

Along with the excitement you will feel at being a part of this world premiere production, we have some very cool perks listed for each level of giving. Nothing will give a chuckle to history nerds quite like a “Buchanan For President” bumper sticker slapped on the back of your car, and no button is gonna add flair to your Friday’s uniform like “Vote for 10c Jimmy!” Both items are designed by the incredibly talented Abby Townsend. Paper weights might sound boring, but not the beautiful blown glass pieces provided by Pacific Northwest sculpture Hope Forstenzer, elder sister of our very own Ben. Other perks include tickets to the show, backstage access and a champagne toast with Brendan. We’re pulling out all the stops for ya!

story:
Once Upon a Time...

Little Stories is being produced by Cornerstone Theatrical, which comprises of Michele Butler, Sara Fendley, Jack Herholdt, Michael Heitzler and Mickey Pantano.

In Little Stories, Grimm tales both familiar and never before dramatized come to light and life. A raucous troupe with a clown in tow use items they have collected on their travels to tell age-old tales to the audience. Using an array of performance styles including puppetry, vaudeville, clowning and music; this band of wayward entertainers subtly suggests once more that these tales are not merely of yore.

A helping hand is always needed

All funds raised are going directly to the project! Whether it be for costumes and set costs or to compensate the wonderful actors and puppet masters who will make this show the artistic and critical success everyone involved knows it can be.

Everyone who contributes gets a little piece of the experience, including personalized messages on our social media, their own copy of Grimm's Fairy Tales or a pair (2) of  tickets to a performance of their choice.

Even if we don't reach our desired goal, the show must go on. But it would go on without the costume, set and puppet aesthetics that would help make it a cut above the rest.

Fairy Tales and The World

Folklore has existed ever since there were human beings to tell stories. The selections in Little Stories are all overlooked gems from the Brothers Grimm that deserve to be seen and heard. While some stories such as “The Fisherman and His Wife” and “Mother Holle” may be known to folklore enthusiasts, other tales such as “The Bird Phoenix” have only been translated recently. All stories are faithfully adapted from the Grimm Brothers first editions and alter from the more mainstream telling. The moral lessons inherent in these specific stories and sure to linger in the minds of our audience for a long time after.

The risks of the theater

Risks are always a given in both fundraising and the theater. If we didn't take risks, life would be pretty boring. Everyone involved with Little Stories is putting their neck out. While this could be considered daunting, it's also an exciting challenge that the Cornerstone Theatrical team is meeting head on with gusto and expertise. With over 90 years of combined experience, that ranges from Broadway to the BAM Next Wave Festival, from working hand in hand with Cameron Mackintosh to Christie's Auction House, our team's abilities are far and away the best in the business.

Other ways to help

Please follow Little Stories on Twitter: @LittleStoriesNY and  visit our facebook page at www.facebook.com/LittleStoriesPlay and please make sure share our information with your friends and family. The more buzz around the show, the better off our chances are at not only having a successful run in the NY Fringe Festival  - but of a life beyond when we plan to take our show around the country.

Little Stories is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Little Stories must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
"Clouds beyond clouds above me, Wastes beyond wastes below; But nothing drear can move me; I will not, cannot go."

I incite this meeting to rebellion

Female written. Female directed. Female produced. 
Clouds is the second play by new, young writer, Laura Crow developed in collaboration with Time & Again Theatre company. 

Time & Again formed in the summer of 2017 and use history to highlight issues still relevant to the world today. With Clouds they hope to draw attention to the continuing lack of women in STEM industries. For example only 22% of the workforce in core STEM occupations is female. This percentage is even lower in areas such as engineering (12%) and IT (16%).* Lower still, only 5.18% of commerical pilots worldwide are women.**

Clouds shows characters in 1913 navigating many of the problems still experienced by women today, albeit to a more extreme level, and hopefully makes you think ‘we’re now 100 years down the line, why is there still such a low proportion of women in science and aviation, and how can we change this?’. 



Courage calls to courage everywhere

The year is 1913 and women are rising up…

Amidst the flock of pioneers fighting to rule the skies, Winifred Baxter is determined to become the first Englishwoman to enter an air race and fly right around the country!
Her instructor, Phillip, is more concerned with maintaining his own reputation as a dashing aviator - and flirting with anyone and everyone who'll listen - than teaching Freddie about the Blackburn Type D Monoplane. Her best friend, Sylvia, isn't much help either. A newly converted Suffragette, she's determined to make Freddie a poster girl for their increasingly militant Votes For Women campaign. At least she seems to know what to say to Theodore, Freddie's younger brother, who stutters badly and has no interest in anything but cloud formations and the weather. 
As the race draws ever nearer, Lady Sara observes the exploits on her husband's airfield and does all that she can to stop them ruining her summer garden party.

Clouds takes Britain's 'last glorious summer' and slowly draws to the surface the simmering tensions and stark inequality lurking just beneath the surface of repressed Edwardian respectability. 



Deeds, not words

Here is a very basic breakdown of what it will cost us to bring our show to the Fringe;
Venue - £2,400
Accommodation - £3,200
Marketing - £600
Travel - £200
Fringe Registration - £300
Insurance - £200
Monoplane Construction - £500
Total - £7,000
This is without paying our actors, director/FOH, light/sound a single penny.

Now for a few uncomfortable truths...
The arts industry - particularly opportunities for writers, directors, and producers - is still hugely male-dominated. For example, of the 73 episodes of Game of Thrones, arguably the biggest and most popular TV show of the moment, only four episodes have been written by women and only one female director has been employed.
If we want more female-led companies and plays, if we want more stories representing and focusing on the issues still faced by women all over the world, then we have to support them ourselves. We still have to fight to make our voices heard. And financial backing is (unfortunately, as money is such an ugly reality) a big part of this. 

Any support you give will make a huge difference. 

Seeing this story come to life is an incredible experience and every single person involved has given up huge amounts of time and effort to create something we're really proud of. The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is such a famous and exciting platform. It is a chance for our work to be seen by industry professionals and to reach a much wider audience. Your contributions will directly help us to achieve this and give wings to the show!

Take courage, join hands, stand beside us, fight with us.

Your donations will make all the difference. We have some super treats to tempt you with! Thank you cards in the form of a vintage pilot's licence, Suffragette wooden pins, posters of famous female aviators, and even hand stitched Votes For Women sashes! Take a look to the right to see what we have to offer and help us take to the skies!
 

Be militant each in your own way

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute but there are still many ways you can help.

  • Follow us on social media -  Twitter   Instagram   Facebook
  • Like, share and comment on our posts! Interaction is so helpful in gaining momentum.
  • Share this campaign!
  • Tell as many people as you can to check out the play at the Fringe!
  • Spread the word! In this case, words are just as helpful as deeds!


* Statistics from wisecampign.co.uk 2018 workforce statistics 
**Statistic from Air Line Pilots Association International trade union, 7th November 2018

story:
Our Story

Beautiful Soup returns to the stage this spring with a world-premiere adaptation of J.M. Barrie's THE ADVENTURES OF PETER AND WENDY, written and directed by Steven Carl McCasland. 50% of all Box Office proceeds will be donated to The Make-A-Wish Foundation.

Painting the stage completely white, the production will feature projections by Corey Stein. Using puppetry and video projections, the Darlings and Peter will take flight.

The Beautiful Soup Theater Collective was founded in the summer of 2010 by its Artistic Director, Steven Carl McCasland. Beautiful Soup uses theater to bring to light our own struggles and create a dialog. Exploring new works and classics in innovative ways, stretching a shoe-string budget to create visually enchanting minimalist productions, the Collective honors a different charitable organization with each production. Often using the themes of the piece at hand, (Crossing Brooklyn, a musical about a teacher, benefited Artists Striving to End Poverty, who visit third-world countries to teach the arts), a portion of funds raised at the box office are donated to the chosen charity.
While serving the community, the Soup strives to bring light to all types of theater, new and old. Each season, the Collective presents one Shakespearean production, a workshop of a new or forgotten musical, any two great plays. Each season will also feature a world premiere fairy tale for adults and children both.

Previous productions include: BLACK [Billy Learns About Captain Kirk] & BLUE, William Shakespeare's Hamlet, Crossing Brooklyn: a musical by Jenny Giering and Laura Harrington, The WSXR Players' Present Their June 7, 1944 Broadcast of William Shakespeare's TWELFTH NIGHT, or What You Will and Steven Carl McCasland's world premiere play, Alice Au Pays Des Merveilles (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland), Macbeth, and NORA IN REP: A Doll's House and A Doll's Life: the musical.

Theater can be for the masses if we let it. With The Beautiful Soup Theater Collective, you can return to your roots and explore the boundaries of theater while continuing to serve your community.


The Impact

Without your generous support, we cannot produce theatre. Since BSTC is a not-for-profit organization, your donations make it possible to rent a space, purchase props and costumes, hire support and technical staff and many more important things! If we can't put on the show, we can't continue to support our community!


What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we can costume our show, buy props that are necessary, paint for our walls and floors, funds to produce our video projection footage and more! We'll be offering complimentary tickets, meet-the-cast opportunities and much more to say thank you for your support!


Other Ways You Can Help

Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others'! If you can't donate at this point, share our campaign on your Facebook or Tumblr, give us a Tweet or just show us some social media love!

story:
Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company Makes Its Jacob's Pillow Debut

The beautiful and universally-loved Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, a National Historic Landmark, celebrates its 80th Anniversary this year. As The New Yorker recently proclaimed: "There's no place like Jacob's Pillow."  

In this milestone season, Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company  is excited and proud to perform on the Pillow's magnificent Inside/Out stage.  The Pillow's geography, Western Massachusetts' Berkshire mountain range, provides a stunning backdrop to the performance. Says Artistic Director and choreographer Daniel Gwirtzman, an alum of the Pillow:

As a young dancer I spent summers studying at the Pillow's famed school with legendary choreographers and teachers, and as a young professional I enjoyed summers performing in the Ted Shawn Theater, the Festival's indoor main stage.  The Pillow has a special place in my and many people's hearts, dancers and audiences alike.

The Company and its Board of Directors are reaching out for your support through an indiegogo campaign. 

The Project

Daniel says:

It has been of great interest for a long time to have the Company perform at The Pillow, a place very dear to my heart.  My formative years as a dancer and choreographer were shaped there.  My work was presented on the Inside/Out stage in 1987; so much has happened since these student days.  How terrific to have this opportunity to present the Company in some of our most celebrated dances.

The Company's robust program features a dozen dancers and a dozen dances including the sweeping Olympiad, sensuous Museum, and highlights from our acclaimed show Encore.  The exuberance of the dancers and the joyful, wholesome dances uplift and educate.  The repertory is accessible and entertaining, dances an entire audience can enjoy.  A question and answer session with the audience will immediately follow.

The Campaign

The Company launches this one-month campaign to raise the funds needed for the engagement.  It seems everywhere one looks there is a similar pitch for support.  Kickstarter and indiegogo campaigns are widespread; with the expansion of social media has come the nonstop superhighway of pleas and requests. 

We observe that companies and artists often ask for the full amount of a project. 

Dance is Expensive

We do not need all of our budget provided for by you, our potential supporters.  The Company is receiving an honorarium from The Pillow, although it is an amount that is dwarfed by our expenses. 

That's one of the things that is so confounding about dance.  Even when one receives a prestigious engagement, it is rarely enough to cover expenses.  Dance is prohibitively expensive to produce.  It takes time for people to learn choreography, even at the highest professional level, as are the Company's dancers.  Time is expensive.  Dancers cost money and space costs money.  The Company is paying what it can from our general operating budget, but it is not enough.

A week out from the performance our costs continue to escalate.

Please read our most current funding update, under the Update tab, to understand how we are using the funds, and how additional funding will support the project.  This has been updated as of July 14.

Thanks for Your Help

Without raising this money, the Company will be uncomfortably in the red.  Our ongoing and upcoming programming will be dramatically impacted, restraining the projects we provide for the general community of New York City and beyond.  We donate performances and workshops regularly.  And similarly, we receive many donated services.  From the administrative to the legal to the technical to the artistic, we are consistently buoyed by the generous contributions of professionals with pro bono work.  As a 501 c 3 organization we are thankful to be the recipients of such generosity as we fulfill our mission of serving the public.

Yet the dancers always do, and must, get paid.  The Pillow project demands we put our best, calloused and supple!, feet forward.  We are pointing and flexing these feet as hard as we can.  The free programming we offer is our way of giving to the community and sharing our love for the art of dance.  Your giving is a way to keep us going, to keep this cycle of reprocity, and to foster the magic of creating, interpreting, and watching art.

We are thankful and grateful for your support.  As appreciations of your generosity we are pleased to offer several unique rewards, as seen on the sidebar.

*Please note that payments will be accepted only through PayPal.

Pillow Talk

President Obama awarded a National Medal of Arts to this highly-acclaimed international Festival, America's longest-running, last year.  TIME magazine calls "The Pillow" a "hub and mecca of dancing" and The New York Times refers to it as "the dance center of the nation." 
 
Read the fantastic The New Yorker June 17 article HERE.

Talk Is Cheap

If you would like to contribute further, please tell your friends and family about our project.  Someone you know might be very excited to learn about the Company and the educational work for which we have gained a reputation.  We are happy to speak directly to anyone that may be interested in becoming a potential supporter.  We greatly appreciate your efforts to help us by spreading the word.

About Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company

Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company was “founded upon a philosophy that dance should celebrate human achievement through a combination of discipline and unbound optimism.” Blending virtuosic precision with pedestrian ease, the infectiously appealing dancers are renown for their charisma.  “A troupe I’d follow anywhere,” says The Village Voice. 

The recipient of a George Soros Open Society Foundation grant for the past two years, Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company, a New York-based nonprofit performing and teaching organization, has demonstrated a commitment to education since its inception in 1998.  The programming allows everyone to join in the dance.

Operating with this philosophy, the multigenerational interactive programming, known for its infectious energy and accessibility, seeks to captivate the greatest common denominator among a diverse population and share the art of dance in a meaningful way.  With a large repertory noted for its entertaining flair, musicality, and innovation DGDC consistently delivers critically-acclaimed performances.  Collaborations with a variety of organizations throughout and outside of New York City have resulted in a history of residencies and community events throughout the country and abroad.  Contracted with the Department of Education since 1999, the Company has taught dance to over 15,000 students, parents, and teachers.

Encore, an acclaimed evening-length show, premiered in 2007 at Joyce SoHo and was an official selection of the New York Musical Theater Festival in 2009. The piece continues to tour and has been licensed by other professional companies. For the Pillow, DGDC presents excerpts from the show, its greatest hits without the script. The New Yorker wrote: “Encore is both the title of Gwirtzman’s new dance suite and the response it’s likely to inspire.  The name refers to the repetitions of rehearsal, as a fictional troupe of Broadway dancers prepares to go on the road, but there’s little tedium in Gwirtzman’s choreography…Executing his tricky syncopations and intricate patterns at breakneck tempos, the dancers can’t help but smile.” With a large repertory noted for its entertaining flair, stylistic diversity, musicality, innovation and accessibility neither can the audiences. 

Visit our Company Trailer to watch a comprehensive overview of what it is we do!

"Go If You Can!"

"The Pillow is an educational experience for audiences as well; in addition to simply being exposed to dance companies and performers from around the world, visitors have the chance to hear from the artists about their motivations, inspirations, intentions, and influences. Performances on the Inside/Out stage, which are free, take place before performances in the theatres, and conclude with Q. & A.s with the creators...There is nothing like being there. Go if you can." 

The New Yorker, June 17, 2012
story_txt:
Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company Makes Its Jacob's Pillow Debut
The beautiful and universally-loved Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, a National Historic Landmark, celebrates its 80th Anniversary this year. As The New Yorker recently proclaimed: "There's no place like Jacob's Pillow."  
In this milestone season, Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company  is excited and proud to perform on the Pillow's magnificent Inside/Out stage.  The Pillow's geography, Western Massachusetts' Berkshire mountain range, provides a stunning backdrop to the performance. Says Artistic Director and choreographer Daniel Gwirtzman, an alum of the Pillow:
As a young dancer I spent summers studying at the Pillow's famed school with legendary choreographers and teachers, and as a young professional I enjoyed summers performing in the Ted Shawn Theater, the Festival's indoor main stage.  The Pillow has a special place in my and many people's hearts, dancers and audiences alike.
The Company and its Board of Directors are reaching out for your support through an indiegogo campaign. 
The Project
Daniel says:
It has been of great interest for a long time to have the Company perform at The Pillow, a place very dear to my heart.  My formative years as a dancer and choreographer were shaped there.  My work was presented on the Inside/Out stage in 1987; so much has happened since these student days.  How terrific to have this opportunity to present the Company in some of our most celebrated dances.
The Company's robust program features a dozen dancers and a dozen dances including the sweeping Olympiad, sensuous Museum, and highlights from our acclaimed show Encore.  The exuberance of the dancers and the joyful, wholesome dances uplift and educate.  The repertory is accessible and entertaining, dances an entire audience can enjoy.  A question and answer session with the audience will immediately follow.


The Campaign
The Company launches this one-month campaign to raise the funds needed for the engagement.  It seems everywhere one looks there is a similar pitch for support.  Kickstarter and indiegogo campaigns are widespread; with the expansion of social media has come the nonstop superhighway of pleas and requests. 
We observe that companies and artists often ask for the full amount of a project. 
Dance is Expensive
We do not need all of our budget provided for by you, our potential supporters.  The Company is receiving an honorarium from The Pillow, although it is an amount that is dwarfed by our expenses. 
That's one of the things that is so confounding about dance.  Even when one receives a prestigious engagement, it is rarely enough to cover expenses.  Dance is prohibitively expensive to produce.  It takes time for people to learn choreography, even at the highest professional level, as are the Company's dancers.  Time is expensive.  Dancers cost money and space costs money.  The Company is paying what it can from our general operating budget, but it is not enough.
A week out from the performance our costs continue to escalate.
Please read our most current funding update, under the Update tab, to understand how we are using the funds, and how additional funding will support the project.  This has been updated as of July 14.
Thanks for Your Help


Without raising this money, the Company will be uncomfortably in the red.  Our ongoing and upcoming programming will be dramatically impacted, restraining the projects we provide for the general community of New York City and beyond.  We donate performances and workshops regularly.  And similarly, we receive many donated services.  From the administrative to the legal to the technical to the artistic, we are consistently buoyed by the generous contributions of professionals with pro bono work.  As a 501 c 3 organization we are thankful to be the recipients of such generosity as we fulfill our mission of serving the public.
Yet the dancers always do, and must, get paid.  The Pillow project demands we put our best, calloused and supple!, feet forward.  We are pointing and flexing these feet as hard as we can.  The free programming we offer is our way of giving to the community and sharing our love for the art of dance.  Your giving is a way to keep us going, to keep this cycle of reprocity, and to foster the magic of creating, interpreting, and watching art.
We are thankful and grateful for your support.  As appreciations of your generosity we are pleased to offer several unique rewards, as seen on the sidebar.
*Please note that payments will be accepted only through PayPal.
Pillow Talk
President Obama awarded a National Medal of Arts to this highly-acclaimed international Festival, America's longest-running, last year.  TIME magazine calls "The Pillow" a "hub and mecca of dancing" and The New York Times refers to it as "the dance center of the nation." 
 
Read the fantastic The New Yorker June 17 article HERE.
Talk Is Cheap
If you would like to contribute further, please tell your friends and family about our project.  Someone you know might be very excited to learn about the Company and the educational work for which we have gained a reputation.  We are happy to speak directly to anyone that may be interested in becoming a potential supporter.  We greatly appreciate your efforts to help us by spreading the word.
About Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company
Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company was “founded upon a philosophy that dance should celebrate human achievement through a combination of discipline and unbound optimism.” Blending virtuosic precision with pedestrian ease, the infectiously appealing dancers are renown for their charisma.  “A troupe I’d follow anywhere,” says The Village Voice.

Operating with this philosophy, the multigenerational interactive programming, known for its infectious energy and accessibility, seeks to captivate the greatest common denominator among a diverse population and share the art of dance in a meaningful way.  With a large repertory noted for its entertaining flair, musicality, and innovation DGDC consistently delivers critically-acclaimed performances.  Collaborations with a variety of organizations throughout and outside of New York City have resulted in a history of residencies and community events throughout the country and abroad.  Contracted with the Department of Education since 1999, the Company has taught dance to over 15,000 students, parents, and teachers.
Encore, an acclaimed evening-length show, premiered in 2007 at Joyce SoHo and was an official selection of the New York Musical Theater Festival in 2009. The piece continues to tour and has been licensed by other professional companies. For the Pillow, DGDC presents excerpts from the show, its greatest hits without the script. The New Yorker wrote: “Encore is both the title of Gwirtzman’s new dance suite and the response it’s likely to inspire.  The name refers to the repetitions of rehearsal, as a fictional troupe of Broadway dancers prepares to go on the road, but there’s little tedium in Gwirtzman’s choreography…Executing his tricky syncopations and intricate patterns at breakneck tempos, the dancers can’t help but smile.” With a large repertory noted for its entertaining flair, stylistic diversity, musicality, innovation and accessibility neither can the audiences. 
Visit our Company Trailer to watch a comprehensive overview of what it is we do!
"Go If You Can!"
"The Pillow is an educational experience for audiences as well; in addition to simply being exposed to dance companies and performers from around the world, visitors have the chance to hear from the artists about their motivations, inspirations, intentions, and influences. Performances on the Inside/Out stage, which are free, take place before performances in the theatres, and conclude with Q. & A.s with the creators...There is nothing like being there. Go if you can."  
The New Yorker, June 17, 2012

story:
Help fund the original score for TMT's The Tempest. Your support will be music to our ears!

Cue the viola de gamba dear friends of Target Margin, we're gonna make some music.

Our 20th Anniversary production of The Tempest is gonna knock your socks off! We've got the hand painted scenery, the old-fashioned costumes, the painterly tableaux--now we just need to set the right tone with a delectable soundscape to conjure the magic for the tempest at hand. 


The Tempest is teeming with incidental music, more than any other play by Shakespeare, and we want to commit to that fact with myriad compositions and music treatments. The score of The Tempest will feature the incidental music survived from the period--songs such as "Where the Bee Sucks" and "Full Fathom Five"-- as well as new compositions, the use of Renaissance instruments (the viola de gamba!), a man/musicbox/computer collaboration for an experimental twist and a chorus of angels. Ok, maybe not the angels. But the rest is true and so close we can hear it.


We appeal to you, our community, to assist us in the realization of our dream score. (We tried to get Ariel to busk in the subway but her schedule is ethereal and really hard to manage.) Won't you help? 5 bucks would mean the world and truly honor Target Margin's 20 years of eclectic noisemaking. In addition to the myriad perks detailed here you will all be listed as "Full Fathom Funders" in our program and acknowledged for your support of the score for The Tempest.


The Tempest both connects to our earliest roots, and pushes our work in new directions: Target Margin Theater first built a reputation with muscular innovative productions of Shakespeare, including our first production Titus Andronicus in 1991, and yet we always strive to challenge and renew our own work. The Tempest is the centerpiece of our 20th Anniversary Season and runs from May 4-27, 2011 at HERE Arts Center. For more info on the production, please click here.

story:
Hi!

I'm Brooke and I am a grad student pursuing my MA in Applied Theatre at City University of New York.  I have an exciting opportunity to travel to Rwanda with CUNY's Project Rwanda: Drama and Theatre Education for Reconciliation and Development to teach the applied theatre techniques I've been learning to students at the Kigali Institute of Education.

 

What's Applied Theatre?

Good question! Applied theatre is an umbrella term used to describe theatre that has a purpose other than simple entertainment.  It can be used for...

  • Education
  • Conflict resolution
  • Community development
  • ...and more!

Applied theatre also tends to occur in locations that are not traditionally considered theatre spaces.  It can be found in...

  • Schools
  • Prisons
  • Conflict zones
  • Underserved communities
  • ...and anywhere else that theatre can bring us more than entertainment.

How Will You Be Using Applied Theatre In Rwanda?

I am passionate about using theatre for peaceful conflict resolution, and that's part of what Project Rwanda is all about.  In the wake of the Rwandan genocide, reconciliation is still needed.  Theatre unites people, and shows them that they can work together to create something.  

The project, which is in its fourth year, is "a multi-year program whereby faculty and students from the MA in Applied Theatre at the CUNY School of Professional Studies travel to Rwanda to help young Rwandan people between the ages of 11 to 25 years to develop their social, educational and cultural skills through drama and theatre."

In Project Rwanda, our applied theatre goals are "(a) to develop the use of theatre and drama strategies as educational tools to help promote unity and reconciliation among Rwandans, and (b) to create job opportunities by building applied theatre troops; first in schools and colleges, and later in the professional, cultural milieu."

 

Sweet! How Else Can I Help?

Thanks for all your help so far!  If you want to help more, the best thing you can do is spread the word!  Post the campaign to Facebook and Twitter, email it to friends who might be interested, and share it in any way you can.  I can't do this without you!

story:
You can still donate: http://www.backstromgroup.com/sogmush_donate.html


Our Story

What's more exciting than wrangling a clowder of feral felines? Or more energizing than inserting a tuning fork into a wall socket? Answer: A group of artists creating collaboratively.


Introducing

Sogmush Collective!


The Happenings at Sogmush River

Or How to Become Chic and Mysterious All at Once,


Our collaborative performance piece is a dance theater musical mystery, inspired by the works of Edward Gorey, that master of pithy rhyme and gothic imagery. Through movement, music and silent film we will explore notions of fame & infamy, love & obsession, discovery & wanderlust. In February we'll perform this newly developed piece at The Kumble Theater for the Performing Arts in downtown Brooklyn.


It's our world premiere. We want you to be part of it!


We need your support to make this performance fabulous.

  • What: Sogmush Collective's production of The Happenings at Sogmush River or How to Become Chic and Mysterious All at Once. 
  • Where: The Kumble Theater for the Performing Arts
    Buy tickets for
    Fri February 3, 2012 at 7.30pm: http://kumbletheater.tix.com/Event.asp?Event=42...
    Sat February 4, 2012 at 7.30pm: http://kumbletheater.tix.com/Event.asp?Event=42...
    Sun February 5, 2012 at 4.00pm: http://kumbletheater.tix.com/Event.asp?Event=42...

Who Are Sogmush Collective

Sogmush Collective is a group of artists committed to producing thought-provoking, socially conscious, performance-oriented works aimed at questioning the interstitialâ€”the places where the arts meet, the places where people meet, the places where ideas meet. Like other interstitial art, which falls between, not within, familiar boundaries of artistic genres, our performances aim to bring together artists of differing media, culture, race, thought and skill to explore the possibilities of the new art collaborative. Our artists hail from at least five different countries and bring various artistic traditions into the mix. Through the creative workshop and salon model we write, dance, play, develop and discover together, to learn more about our craft and to create innovative works for adventurous audiences.

Our Artists-in-Residence are performance artists, multi-media artists, writers, filmmakers, musicians, directors, visual artists, costumers and theater artists who have come together with the common goal of creating collaborative works.

We've been meeting 3-4 times a week for the past few months, developing story lines, choreography, film and music. The video above will give you a taste of our quirky esthetic. If you're a Gorey fan you'll love this performance. 

Check us out at http://sogmush.com. And keep up with our Indiegogo updates as we highlight some of our Artists-in-Residence over the next few weeks.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to make this dream (nightmare, that is) a reality. Help us bring more of New York's vibrant theater scene to Brooklyn. 


The Kumble Theatre for the Performing Arts in downtwon Brooklyn has generously donated rehearsal and performance space to us. We're eternally grateful and honored, so we want to make this performance a go-to experience for local audiences. Although The Kumble is providing the space and loads of support, they can't fund our entire project.


All your contributions will go directly into the production--to pay for lighting, to build scenes and costumes, to edit film--and to allow our Sogmush Artists-in-Residence to continue creating together. You'll also help us to find a more permanent home for our collaborative workshops. Become a partner in our collective.


Our Artists-in-Residence have dedicated themselves heart and soul to making this collaborative a success.


All you have to do is choose your contribution level and you'll become part of our production team. And you'll have our deepest thanks and undead love.


Other Ways You Can Help 

Get the word out. Tell all your dance theatre and Gorey-loving friends and family (you know who they are). Share our Indiegogo and website links. Be a Sogmush supporter.

You'll also help us to find a more permanent home for our collaborative workshops. Become a partner in our collective.

Our Artists-in-Residence have dedicated themselves heart and soul to making this collaborative a success.

All you have to do is choose your contribution level and you'll become part of our production team. And you'll have our deepest thanks and undead love.


Other Ways You Can Help 
Get the word out. Tell all your dance theatre and Gorey-loving friends and family (you know who they are). Share our Indiegogo and website links. Be a Sogmush supporter.

story:
Here Now Dance Collective 

(Michelle Fletcher, Sarah Gould, Caitlin Hafer, Michelle Kinny, Angela Mazziotta,  Kailtin Parks, Sarah Pomarico, Summer Bowie)


What: BURSTNOW - live dance performance
Where: The Garage in March and at ODC Theater in July, 2012
When: March 14-15 / July 19-22
How: with your help!


The Impact

This project is important to HNDC because we are growing our aesthetic and growing as artists, in turn we are servants of the SF community and contributing to our societies' art and culture.  The role of artists at this time are not highly valued by our country but good art frames what is happening in the world and gives life context and meaning. This project in particular enlivens the audiences and is ultimately transformative.  The piece begins with a portrait of a numb community, blocked emotionally and physically, but through relationship and awakening of self, they change into dynamic healthy beings.  If the audience leaves the theater more aware of themself, their body, and develop even just a bit more sensitivity in how they navigate through life, this dance is a success. 

What We Need 

We are asking help from our supporters - you, to help pay the dancers for their time in rehearsal and performance. Here is a mini breakdown of our budget, so you can see how your donation will support our work.


1 dancer performance pay - $50 (times that by 7 dancers and 4 performances = 1,400)

1 dancer monthly rehearsal stipend - $100 (time that by 7 dancers and 7 months = 4,900)

7 dancers costumes - $250

props - $160 (bubble machine, balloons, ironing board)

theater rental - $500

performance documentation - $300

photography and postcard flyers - $225


This is a bare bones budget. We are asking for $3000 through indieagogo, to ensure we meet our online goal, but our actual goal for this project is $8,000. For those of you who would like to donate a larger amount and have the contribution be tax-deductible (thank you!) please click this link right below and donate through our non-profit fiscal sponsor "Dancers' Group".


Tax-Deductible Donation


Other Ways You Can Help

If contributing financially to this project is not possible for you at this time (we understand), please consider being a HNDC advocate. We can use your help getting the word out about this fundraising as well as our performances. You can also "like" us on facebook. All these actions will help raise HNDC's visibility and also further the art and community conversation! Thank you!
