story:
**PLEASE NOTE**: At this point our fundraising goal is $3,500, not $1,500 as listed above.

VERTIGO PRODUCTIONS: 

Vertigo Productions at Northwestern University gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on campus that produces entirely student-written work.

ABOUT THE PLAY: 

ANIMAL STYLE is a student-written play on campus this year, giving voice to senior theater student Nick Day's beautiful story. ANIMAL STYLE is about a group of people at a crossroads, all equally ill-equipped to handle where they have found themselves and each other. The story starts as a family sits around a cheap motel room somewhere near San Luis Obispo, CA. The three individuals span three generations. One is there en route to a retirement home. Two (or maybe all three) would not be there, if given the choice. Two are there because they are trying to do the right thing. All three love each other, each in their own way. And the next 24 hours hold monumental events that will forever alter lives, and their relationships to each other. This is a play focused tightly on the intersection of four lives--and in that way, is focused tightly on us all. 

For the first time in Northwestern Student Theater, there will be engineers, film students, and animators as part of the play’s creative team. By having the back wall of the set be a screen on which we can project images, in conjunction with electronically produced soundscapes and expressionistic moving lights, we hope to do more than just bring the play’s characters to life. Theater affords young artists the rare opportunity to take risks, make bold choices, and let free their imaginations. Our goal is to give the audience an experience that pushes them to recognize aspects of themselves they often deny exist. 

We cannot reach this goal without your help. The production is entirely student produced and funded, independent of the University, so only with your financial support can we get this play successfully across the finish line. All donations, no matter how small, are greatly appreciated and are tax deductible! With your help, the possibilities for this show are endless. 

The Cast and Crew:

Cast:

  • Dan: Nick Lehmann
  • Jon: Tom DeFrancisco
  • Lindsay: Katherine Seldin
  • Nurse: Hallye Webb

The Production Team:

  • Writer: Nick Day
  • Producer: Grace Kennedy                                                                                           Assistant Producer: Natascha Buschman
  • Director: Isabella Mehiel                                                                                                  Assistant Director: Alex Wolfe
  • Stage Manager: Mallory Harrington                                                                   Assistant Stage Manager: Leigh Goldstein
  • Set Designer: Joe Entenman
  • Visual Designer: Michael Nowakowski
  • Costume Designer: Drew Tildon                                                                   Assistant Costume Designer: Lindsey Spohler
  • Sound Designers: Hannah Fisher and Michael Rogerson
  • Props Designer: Sage Ross
  • Lighting Designer: Aaron Lorenz                                                                   Assisant Lighting Designers: Geoffrey Ko & Julian Matra
  • Technical Director: Austin Appel
  • Fundraising Director: Grace Devlin
  • Publicity Directors: Aaron Simon Gross and Sara Kase
  • Graphic Designer: Sarah Sherman
  • Snack Designer: Elena Besser


Thank you so much for your support!!
story_txt:
**PLEASE NOTE**: At this point our fundraising goal is $3,500, not $1,500 as listed above.VERTIGO PRODUCTIONS: Vertigo Productions at Northwestern University gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on campus that produces entirely student-written work.ABOUT THE PLAY: ANIMAL STYLE is a student-written play on campus this year, giving voice to senior theater student Nick Day's beautiful story. ANIMAL STYLE is about a group of people at a crossroads, all equally ill-equipped to handle where they have found themselves and each other. The story starts as a family sits around a cheap motel room somewhere near San Luis Obispo, CA. The three individuals span three generations. One is there en route to a retirement home. Two (or maybe all three) would not be there, if given the choice. Two are there because they are trying to do the right thing. All three love each other, each in their own way. And the next 24 hours hold monumental events that will forever alter lives, and their relationships to each other. This is a play focused tightly on the intersection of four lives--and in that way, is focused tightly on us all. For the first time in Northwestern Student Theater, there will be engineers, film students, and animators as part of the play’s creative team. By having the back wall of the set be a screen on which we can project images, in conjunction with electronically produced soundscapes and expressionistic moving lights, we hope to do more than just bring the play’s characters to life. Theater affords young artists the rare opportunity to take risks, make bold choices, and let free their imaginations. Our goal is to give the audience an experience that pushes them to recognize aspects of themselves they often deny exist. We cannot reach this goal without your help. The production is entirely student produced and funded, independent of the University, so only with your financial support can we get this play successfully across the finish line. All donations, no matter how small, are greatly appreciated and are tax deductible! With your help, the possibilities for this show are endless. The Cast and Crew:Cast:

Jon: Tom DeFrancisco

story:
Originally I started this campaign to raise money for myself to go on this trip.  After praying, discussing, and lots of thought I decided to include my good friend Jessica Aliganga on the campaign. She has been like a sister to me during my transition to Sacramento, introduced me to so many people, and help me feel right at home.  I can't wait to take this trip with her and so I figured that one way I can show her my appreciation is to help her out on this trip as well!  Please Spread the word.



Who and where I am today:

I am Erik James Molina, 25 years old full-time student at Sacramento State majoring in Dance with a minor in Musical Theater.  Originally from San Diego, I made the transition to Nor Cal leave my family, friends, "my comfort zone" in order to find a new environment to aid my desire to grow as an individual, community member, dancer, choreographer, and artist.  Besides being a full time student, I am actively participating in the dance department preparing to perform in upcoming shows such as Sacramento Black Art of Dance's "Legacy" and the Senior Dance Concert.  Outside of school I work as a Substitute Recreational Leader through the Bridges After-School Program in the San Juan School District, as well as an instructor for the Sac Performing Arts Company in West Sacramento and Fancy Feet Dance Academy.  For fun I train, perform and compete with hip hop teams Press P.L.A.Y. and Sac Modern, where I am also an acting captain this semester.

Dance has been a intergral part of my life for years now. From my education to my spirituality, and from my social life to maintaining my health, dance has been a vital part to my holistic well being.

Any contribution to help me attend ACDFA will in many ways, big and small, change my life.  Fellow students as well as faculty have told me how much this conference has done for them in past experiences.  With the busy schedule I have, the decision to make this trip took a lot of thought and consideration.  Your support will help make this trip entirely a learning and enjoyable experience without worry of financial boundaries.

What is ACDFA?

"The American College Dance Festival Association's primary focus is to support and promote the wealth of talent and creativity that is prominent throughout college and university dance departments. ACDFA's sponsorship of regional conferences and the national dance festival provides the venue for students and faculty to engage in three days of performances, workshops, panels, and master classes taught by instructors from around the region and country. The conferences also provide the unique opportunity for students and faculty to have their dance works adjudicated by a panel of nationally recognized dance professionals in an open and constructive forum. Culminating with the presentation of pieces selected for their exemplary artistic quality, the conferences are the primary means for college and university dance programs to perform outside their own academic setting and be exposed to the diversity of the national college dance world. The American College Dance Festival Association primary focus is to support and promote the wealth of talent and creativity that is prominent throughout college and university dance departments." The regional conference will provide a venue for me to participate in three days workshops and master classes taught by instructors from around the region and country." (acdfa.org)

The cost for this trip include the following (in order of high to lowest estimated expense):

Airfare , conference registration, hotel accomadations, food, local traveling while in Tempe, Arizona, and appropriate apparel to wear during classes and workshops.

The conference is going to be held at Arizona State University from March 12-15, 2014

story:
“Theatre has proven to be a more powerful venue than advocacy for having ordinary people understand, experience and choose to be inclusive – to welcome diversity into their own lives.” 

-- Judith Snow

[A written description of the campaign video is available for blind, vision impaired and partially sighted people. Please follow this link: http://bit.ly/OLwEnm. Closed Captioning is also available.]

Presented by Selfconscious Theatre 

in partnership with Abilities Centre and The Theatre Centre

Directed by Sarah Garton Stanley

Produced by Evelyn Tauben

Performed by Michael Rubenfeld, The Book of Judith Choir, Alex Bulmer and Judith Snow

A provocative piece of transformational theatre, The Book of Judith is a musical play inspired by the real life meeting and subsequent friendship between theatre artist Michael Rubenfeld and Judith Snow, an artist and disability advocate who lives with quadriplegia. In the performance, Rubenfeld begins to see himself as a preacher and corals a fully integrated choir of singers with and without a disability to help him tell his inspirational (yet suspect) tale of Judith Snow.
 
The production takes place outdoors in a tent to compliment the “revival-style” structure of the play. The choir plays a central role in unraveling this story. Our team puts together a local choir in each community where the show is presented. After a successful Ontario tour made possible by the Trillium Foundation, The Book of Judith comes to the state-of-the-art Abilities Centre, promoting inclusive and innovative programs for people of all ages and abilities. 

Watch the inspirational report by CBC's The National of the premiere production of The Book of Judith in downtown Toronto:


JOIN OUR HEALING CRUSADE!

Help spread our message about diversity and inclusion by contributing to the upcoming production of The Book of Judith. The funds raised through this campaign offset the larger production budget including artist fees, hiring a crew, and putting up our accessible performance tent with professional staging and lighting. Our twenty-person choir makes up the largest expense in mounting The Book of Judith. Each performer is crucial to the project and receives a fee for their time and dedication. 

This campaign will cover 20% of our production budget, 65% of which is already secured through government grants and partnerships.

Excellent perks allow you to spread the “stand-up-and-shout” energy of The Book of Judith -- our choir will sing for you in a recorded video or you can get complimentary tickets to come see them live when we open at the Abilities Centre. There are also many great ways to enjoy Judith’s artwork and even an opportunity to have her speak at one of your events. 

Click here for a wonderful short video about how Judith paints.

As a partner in the production, Abilities Centre (charitable # 88981 9116 RR0001) will issue tax receipts in accordance with Canada Revenue Agency rules. If perks are waived, the full contribution amount is tax deductible (for gifts of $50 and higher). TO RECEIVE A TAX RECEIPT, ENTER "SHIPPING INFORMATION" WHEN YOU CHECK OUT.


WHO IS JUDITH SNOW?

A longtime advocate for disability rights, Judith Snow is a visual artist and Founding Director of Laser Eagles, an organization making creative activity available to artists with diverse ability via personal assistance. Her paintings have been exhibited at the Royal Ontario Museum and the Arts Etobicoke Gallery. Snow has published and presented widely on the topic of inclusion. 


WHY THIS SHOW IS IMPORTANT 

In development and performance since 2006, The Book of Judith has successfully incorporated Judith Snow’s ground-breaking philosophies that inclusive thinking adds significant societal value. The show challenges audiences to confront their assumptions about disability and difference, creating opportunity for dialogue about inclusion, accessibility and ignorance. People living with disabilities and those who are different are not only contributing members of society, they are assets. Inclusion is not a charitable practice. By working on this show, our team continues to discover how inclusion is better for all parties and creates more meaningful experiences. 


MUCH MORE THAN A PLAY!

  • Abilities Centre is also presenting an exhibition of Judith’s paintings 
  • Selfconscious Theatre and Abilities Centre are hosting a symposium on June 13, 2014 bringing artists, presenters and educators together to discuss enhancing accessibility in Canada’s performing arts community. 
  • The symposium is made possible due to a major grant from the Equity Office of the Canada Council for the Arts.

For more about The Book of Judith -- videos, tour history, meet the creative team, click here

Selfconscious Theatre                    Abilities Centre                    Theatre Centre

Be a part of getting The Book of Judith to Whitby and help step it up for inclusion in Canada.

“It is a socially minded, soul-mending public spectacle of the stand-up-and-shout variety and, at the risk of sounding more of a cheerleader than critic, I encourage you to see this and to lend to its charming crusade your own energy. You never know: miracles happen every day.” 

           Byron Laviolette, theatre critic

Thank you to our campaign team: Sascha Cole, Merik Williams, Alex Bulmer, Cathleen Edwards, Holly Hewitt, Michael Rubenfeld, Sarah Garton Stanley, Judith Snow, and Evelyn Tauben
[PHOTO ON STAGE: Jeremy Mimnagh]

story:
I am the daughter of the double-bass player Franco Marzorati and the flautist Marianne Fischer. I grew up in Venice, Italy, surrounded by a symphonic and opera environment.I lived several years abroad: in the USA in 1994-1995, in Switzerland from 2001 to 2005, and in Spain from 2005 to 2007. These experiences enriched my musical education, my foreign language knowledge, but especially my personal life experience.
I always dreamed about being part of a show that included music first of all, but also dancing, singing and acting. 

My grandfather Virgilio Marzorati was a great violinist. Besides his other musical activities, he often played the Café Concert music repertoire.

A few years ago, after I inherited his entire music Archive, I came up with the idea of a show that alternates instrumental pieces, opera arias, tableaux vivants, and performances by mimes, actors and dancers.

The beautiful city of Venice has always been a place of inspiration for many artists and composers, a fantastic stage for performances of all kinds. Its palaces are the ideal setting to host an event like this.

So I chose a first list of pieces from the Archive. Then I wrote a detailed Screenplay, recorded the Quintett playing the music, and made a brochure that presented the idea. With this material I met several event organizers, Venitian Palace's owners and Hotel directors. Basically everyone has shown interest in it, but they would like to see it.

The costumes designer Nicolao from Venice is one of my greatest supporters

By making the show for the first time, I would be able to show it to the interested persons. By filming it, I would be able to show it also in the future to other people.

What I need
€ 1000 for the catering
€ 2000 for the artists
€ 600 for the cleaning of 30 costumes (the rental is free for this first time)
€ 1000 for the prop and scene material
€ 400 for the backstage crew and transport
€ 3500 for light service, recording, filming, graphics, website and photos

What you get
Your name listed in the Venice Premiere Program
Your name on the "Thank you" page of the website
The recorded cd of the live exhibition
The dvd of the show

Plus...

Original glass candle lights used in the show!
And, if during year 2014 you come to Venice...

A typical venetian aperitif with me and some of the artists!

Free entrances to the show!

A one day special tour of Venice!


If I don't reach the entire goal, your fund will support this project in any case, but it might take longer to see it come to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute economically, there is other ways you can help me:

Share this link with your friends!

story:
You're here! Guess what?

1944 Brent Lane has been accepted into the annual Venus Theater Festival at Cabrini Repertory Theater here in this vibrant city of New York! Our goal is to make it happen-- off the page and onto the stage. This takes a ton of work and we can't do it without you. 

This money is going to the actors and artists who have been gracious enough to dedicate their time and talent to our project. We'll also be using it for the time and space to rehearse, design our set, collect props, costumes, you name it. 

We want to thank everyone in advance for your donations, support, and encouragement! 

Lots of love, 

1944 Brent Lane Team


1944 BRENT LANE by Sarah Schultz

Directed by Malachy Silva 

Starring Rick Busser, Stephanie Seward, Mackenzie Lansing, David Potters, and Kat Ross. 

Produced by Alex Riad



WHERE/WHEN?

Cabrini Repertory Theater
701 Fort Washington Ave,
New York, NY

Thursday, February 27th @ 8:45 pm. 

Saturday, March 1st @ 9 pm. 

Sunday, March 2nd @ 8 pm.


Poster design by Kayleen Wilkinson.

story:
I'm Brian Smith, an actor/writer/director based in Los Angeles.

We're talking today about the world premiere production of the award-winning play "The Gambler's Daughter", written by my long-time friend Paul North. Ever since I first read this script back in 2006, I've been looking for the ideal place to stage the premiere... and I've found it at the Eclectic Company Theatre, of which I am proud to call myself a member, and we are scheduled to open on January 4th, 2013.

"The Gambler's Daughter" is, at its heart,a play about family -- the one we're born into and the one we choose to part of. I'm a big believer in the idea of a family and this play really shows how the bonds of family can be stretched and twisted into all kinds of shapes, but seldom do they break.

All the fundamentals for a great production are in place-- we've got a great professional design team set to go, we'll have a full cast in just a few weeks but all we're missing... is YOU.

Why support live theatre?

Live theatre doesn't happen in a vacuum. Admittedly, sometimes good theatre can be hard to find in the TV/Film production vortex of the universe, not to mention in a rough economy. But the performing arts in general -- and theatre in particular -- are a vital part of a society and it's up to all of us to give artists the ability to tell stories to the people at large -- to entertain, to educate, to inspire.

How can I help?

This particular project has set a goal of $2500 because we need to ensure that this story can be told effectively. All funds raised here, whether we hit that goal or not, are going to the production itself. For example, to pay both our designers (who pour their creativity in the world they build) and our actors (who inhabit that world to tell the story). Also building the sets, assembling costumes & props and even ensuring that we can publicize the play in order to fill the theatre with eager patrons.

But don't think you'll go home empty handed, no sirree! We've got a long list of perks available for our generous donors and patrons of the arts. If you just look over there to the right hand side of the screen, you'll see the various donation levels available to you all. Those amounts are guidelines, of course... any amount is welcome. If you can't afford anything right now, please share this campaign with your fellow arts lovers using the handy tools that this fantastic site provides and encourage them to consider giving.

But Wait... There's More!

Of course there is! For everyone involved, whether you live in Los Angeles or not, if we meet our fundraising goal in time, I, Brian E. Smith, Producer and Director of the "Gambler's Daughter" do hereby solemnly swear that I will (*deep breath*) have my head shaved. In front of the audience. On opening night. Seriously. But wait... there's still more! For those of you who don't live here, if we meet the goal, we'll film the shearing and put it up on the web for all to see. Here's the before picture of me with my awesome hair:

I have never had my head shaved, nor would I ever really consider it under any other circumstances. but this is how passionate & serious I am about raising the money for this show. So take a chance and give today! You might get an extra treat out of it.

(I can NOT believe I just agreed to this...)
story_txt:
I'm Brian Smith, an actor/writer/director based in Los Angeles.
We're talking today about the world premiere production of the award-winning play "The Gambler's Daughter", written by my long-time friend Paul North. Ever since I first read this script back in 2006, I've been looking for the ideal place to stage the premiere... and I've found it at the Eclectic Company Theatre, of which I am proud to call myself a member, and we are scheduled to open on January 4th, 2013. 
"The Gambler's Daughter" is, at its heart,a play about family -- the one we're born into and the one we choose to part of. I'm a big believer in the idea of a family and this play really shows how the bonds of family can be stretched and twisted into all kinds of shapes, but seldom do they break.
All the fundamentals for a great production are in place-- we've got a great professional design team set to go, we'll have a full cast in just a few weeks but all we're missing... is YOU.
Why support live theatre?
Live theatre doesn't happen in a vacuum. Admittedly, sometimes good theatre can be hard to find in the TV/Film production vortex of the universe, not to mention in a rough economy. But the performing arts in general -- and theatre in particular -- are a vital part of a society and it's up to all of us to give artists the ability to tell stories to the people at large -- to entertain, to educate, to inspire.
How can I help?
This particular project has set a goal of $2500 because we need to ensure that this story can be told effectively. All funds raised here, whether we hit that goal or not, are going to the production itself. For example, to pay both our designers (who pour their creativity in the world they build) and our actors (who inhabit that world to tell the story). Also building the sets, assembling costumes & props and even ensuring that we can publicize the play in order to fill the theatre with eager patrons.
But don't think you'll go home empty handed, no sirree! We've got a long list of perks available for our generous donors and patrons of the arts. If you just look over there to the right hand side of the screen, you'll see the various donation levels available to you all. Those amounts are guidelines, of course... any amount is welcome. Here's the before picture of me with my awesome hair:

I have never had my head shaved, nor would I ever really consider it under any other circumstances. but this is how passionate & serious I am about raising the money for this show. So take a chance and give today! You might get an extra treat out of it.
(I can NOT believe I just agreed to this...)

story:
This festival is a response to what we perceive as a world in crisis.

 


Imagine attending an international arts festival where everything is free.

This is the fundraising goal of the fourth CrisisArt Festival. The CrisisArt Festival is an annual gathering of performing artists and arts activists at the beautiful Villa Godiola in Arezzo, Italy. 

We come together to perform, create, discuss, plan and above all share our visions of art and the future. The Festival is curated, produced and organized by the Crisis Art Collective, a group of artists, activists and scholars from all over the world who work on a volunteer basis to make this festival possible.

 Money Matters

Our fundraising goal is $15,000. We know that traveling for an international festival is
a huge expense for most companies, so we hope to eliminate all other expenses (food,
housing, etc.) for our participants. The performers are not charged a participation fee
and none of the Collective members are paid, but there are certain costs that we cannot
avoid in order to run Villa Godiola for a week.

Our costs are always in euro, so it’s tricky to approximate in dollars, but the breakdown
is basically like this:
The daily costs for one artist is 40 dollars. Of that 40 dollars, we charge 5 euro (just shy
of 7 dollars) for buffet-style meals, so the daily cost for food is approximately 20 dollars.
The other 20 dollars comes from paying our kitchen and maintenance staff a fair wage
to cook and maintain the Villa for the duration of the festival.

(40 dollars a day) x (65 artists) x (6 days of Festival fun) = $15,600

Our target fundraising goal matches the costs that our host institution, Accademia
dell’Arte, donates to the festival, since CrisisArt is a zero-profit endeavor. Everything
we fundraise will be evenly distributed for our participants. If we make even half of
our goal, everyone will eat for free!

Every donation helps, big or small. Here are some fundraising markers to consider, the perks for which are listed in our side bar:
$4 : Collective Member Status
$10 : 1 Meal (with seconds)
$20 : Feed an Artist for a Day
$40 : Adopt an Artist for a Day
$120 : Feed an Artist
$250 : Adopt an Artist
$500 : Feed a Company
$1000 : Adopt a Company

 Getting Involved

If you are unable to give, we invite you to get involved in other ways! Send our campaign to friends and colleagues who may be able to give. And help us get the word out about our festival-- and if you jive with our vibe, fill out an application for this year!

For more information, please visit our website, find us on facebook, or write to us at:
crisisart@dellarte.it

We hope to hear from you soon!

story:
CD available for download only-
ITUNES
AMAZON
RHAPSODY

This campaign is the ONLY WAY to obtain CDs of CHANCE: a Musical Play about Love, Risk and Getting It Right, by Emmy-nominated composer Richard Isen (me) from the stage show directed by Tony Award-winner Robert Kalfin. (www.chancethemusical.com.)

This CD will NOT be released for sale to the general public. 

New Musical Theater of San Francisco has brought together an exciting team of artists. I'm an Emmy nominated composer and have composed several musical scores. CHANCE will be directed by Tony Award-winner Robert Kalfin, founder of the legendary Chelsea Theater Center. The jazz inspired score will be directed and played by San Francisco jazz artist Tammy Lynne Hall and sung by our stellar cast: Richard Hefner, Ken Lear, and internationally acclaimed female impersonator Randy Roberts. 

CHANCE is not only a great show, with loads of humor and a memorable jazz inspired score, but it's an important piece of art about a psychologist so traumatized in his youth by the AIDS crisis that he never allowed himself to love. 

The recording will provide a permanent record of CHANCE.  The album will be used as an aid in future fundraising, and it will help to promote my work to a wider audience. PLUS, it's a way for our noted cast's fans, who are unable to fly to San Francisco, to experience the songs.

What I Need & What You Get

I need $3000 to record at the renowned Studio Trilogy in San Francisco. Fees include studio rental, sound engineer, musicians' fees, mailing and manufacturing costs. To show my gratitude, I'm offering a wide range of gifts and goodies - from an mp3 IPod ready song  to a video-taped Thank You Song from the cast recorded at the studio. I am even offering my culinary skills.

The Impact of Your Gift                                         

Not only will the album be a record of a great score, it will showcase this particular group of singers and actors and is the best way to ensure a continued life for the show.  There's nothing better than a great recording to get the attention of producers, festivals, other theaters and grant making organizations.  

Our music director, Tammy L. Hall, has made numerous recording with high calibre artists. As she will be overseeing the recording, we are confident it will be of the utmost quality.  

Other Ways You Can Help                               

Share this message with your family and friends - on Facebook, Twitter, and by email. It's easy - just use the Indiegogo "Share" tools above. 

Better still - come to the show!  Get tickets and more info at www.chancethemusical.com 

The Team 

Richard Isen’s (author/composer) musical theater works include: A Fine & Private Place in collaboration with Erik Haagensen, premiered Off Broadway at the York Theatre in New York City. The work, originally developed at The Eugene O’Neill Center Opera/Music Theater Conference received a full production at Goodspeed Opera House and the American Stage Company in NJ. Other musical theater works include Salford Road: A Musical Photograph, (written with Grammy Award Winning producer Stefan Rudnicki, poet Gareth Owen and winner of The Edinburgh Festival Fringe First Award), My Father’s Son with librettist Enid Futterman and awarded a CBS Development Grand, Night City Diaries, a cabaret piece based on poet Arthur Rimbaud produced by Playwright’s Horizons, and The Bluebird: A Christmas Musical, commissioned to inaugurate The Next Stage Theater in Sun Valley, Idaho and produced by The Sun Valley Repertory Company. Richard has written music for New York theater artists and companies including La Mama, Mabou Mines, The Public Theater, The Woodstock Opera House, and Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park.  Besides his work in theatre, he’s composed music for film, TV (- an Emmy nomination for original music), radio and beep-tone music for some of the very first commercial software available on Apple Computer.

Robert Kalfin (director) Founder of New York’s Chelsea Theatre Center, [winner for its work of five Tony Awards, four Tony nominations and 21 Obie Awards], Mr. Kalfin has directed more than 250 productions and workshops of new plays, musicals and the classics in venues on Broadway, Off-Broadway, in major American regional theaters, in Europe, the Middle East and as far abroad as Siberia. The book, Chelsea On The Edge, details his contribution to the American Theater.

Broadway credits include STRIDER, HAPPY END [starring Meryl Streep and Christopher Lloyd], YENTL, TRULY BLESSED [A Celebration of Mahalia Jackson]; and as Chelsea Co-Producer of Harold Prince’s production of CANDIDE. He staged RASHOMON and THE MISTRESS OF THE INN for the Roundabout Theatre Company, and directed the TV production of THE PRINCE OF HOMBURG starring Frank Langella.

Mr. Kalfin’s career includes directing such artists as F. Murray Abraham, Lucy Arnaz, Elizabeth Ashley, Theo Bikel, Marilyn Chris, Joan Copeland, Charles Durning, Alvin Epstein, Tovah Feldshuh, Paul Hecht, Jack Klugman, Frank Langella, Dan Lauria, Christopher Lloyd, Ralph Macchio, Dina Merrill, Lou Diamond Phillips, Mercedes Ruehl, Meryl Streep and Loretta Swit.

Music Director Tammy L. Hall (musical director)  

Tammy has with worked award-winning cabaret singer and actress, Connie Champagne, the Supreme Mary Wilson, chanteuse and actress Debbie De Coudreaux, The Montclair Women’s Big Band, Houston Person, the late David ‘Fathead Newman’, jazz violinist Jeremy Cohen, vocalists Kim Nalley, Denise Perrier, Pamela Rose, Linda Tillery and the Cultural Heritage Choir, Holly Near, Lynne Asher, Melba Moore, Miki Howard, Rhonda Benin, Darlene Love, Lady Mem’fis, Veronica Klaus, Diane Witherspoon, Derek Lassiter, Frankye Kelley, Nicolas Bearde, Kenny Washington, Lisa Ferraro and the late Etta Jones.

She has traveled and performed extensively in Japan, Europe and Mexico. Other venues of note include Kennedy Center (Mary Lou Williams Jazz Festival), Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall, Sala Filharmonica (Trento, ITALY), Herbst Theatre, Yoshi's Oakland and San Francisco and Kuumbwa Jazz in Santa Cruz, CA.

Richard Hefner (Gregory) studied acting, directing and music at the University of Utah. He then spent a year studying Zen Buddhism at Tassajara Zen Mountain Monastery and Green Gulch Farm in the Bay Area. Upon leaving the monastery, he gardened, taught acting and produced new theatre in Sun Valley, Idaho, co-founding The New Theatre Company with David Hemmings (Blow Up), and starring in a number of new theatre works, working with a number of Hollywood “heavy-hitters.” Five years later, he moved to Manhattan, where he began songwriting in earnest, working at La Mama and with Susan Kaessinger Improvisation troop. Following September 11, 2001, and after playing Hal in Proof in a regional production, he moved to Los Angeles, where he is a member of the Academy of New Musical Theatre. He works as an art director, actor, writer and producer. He met author Isen during The Fantastiks, where he played Harry, the Old Shakespearean actor. When Isen was writing Chance – A New Musical Play about Love, Risk and Getting it Right, he called Hefner and asked him about his monastery experience, with some those tales appearing in the play.

Randy Roberts (The Lady) has been entertaining audiences, for over 30 years. He’s been seen off-Broadway in the workshop of Chance – A New Musical Play about Love, Risk and Getting it Right (formerly called Give a Man a Mask) at the York Theatre; on TV in ABC’s “One Life To Live” He made his movie debut in the award winning indie film “Any Day Now” starring Alan Cumming. Randy is currently headlining in THE CRYSTAL ROOM CABARET at Lateda in Key West, FL. He’s been seen on the Las Vegas strip in BOY-LESQUE at the Sahara and Stardust hotels and AN EVENING AT LA CAGE at the Riviera Hotel. Randy is famous for Randy Roberts - LIVE!, a multi-media tribute to some of the world’s most loved performers. Randy’s impersonations of Cher and Bette Midler have kept him in the spotlight for the past 20 years and includes: Mae West, Joan Crawford, Carol Channing, Ann Miller, Phyllis Diller. He closes every show with a mini-lounge act, allowing him the chance to get up-close and personal with his audience. Randy’s talents is an accomplished lyricist, an adept sound technician, a talented writer, and a successful producer.

Ken Lear (Chance) is thrilled to be making his West Coast and San Francisco debut with Chance – A New Musical Play about Love, Risk and Getting it Right. He lives in NYC where he has been seen at Radio City Music Hall as a featured singer for the Rockettes (2007-2010) and off-Broadway in the international hit, Naked Boys Singing! Regional Theater: I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change (Man 2), Singin’ in the Rain (Production Tenor), and Grease (Roger) at the Palace Theatre; The Sound of Music (Rolf) at Carousel Theatre; Forever Plaid (Sparky) at NE Ohio Repertory Theatre. Bachelor of Music in Musical Theatre from Baldwin-Wallace University Conservatory. Ken studies acting with the legendary Kimberly Vaughn in New York.


Artistic Director Anne Nygren Doherty develops, directs, produces and stages original musical theater productions, many by emerging Bay Area writers and composers. She conducts monthly workshops on musical theater. Once the protegee of legendary Broadway lyricist and composer, Bob Merrill, she is the writer/composer of the long-running hit Absolutely San Francisco, which payed 140 performances at Alcove. In a wide ranging career which began as an actress, appearing as Helena in A Midsummer Night’s Dream in the first season of Shakespeare and Company in Massachusetts, she has worked as a writer, director, composer and dramaturge and has worked with luminaries such as John Belushi, William Petersen, John Malkovich, Richard Dreyfus, Tony Award winning director Frank Galati, Tony Award winner Jayne Atkinson, and Pulitzer Prize winner Milan Stitt, Her plays – including the award winning Lead Birds - have been produced in Chicago, New York and Los Angeles.

story:
CASTING FOR PATRONS

Dear Friends,

The Readers’ Theatre of Ithaca has provided sustainable theater at its bare essence since 2010. Committed to the public good, we believe good theater inspires dialogue within the community. Such an important civic resource should be affordable to all.

To help sustain our commitment to maintain low ticket prices, we are embarking on a community fundraiser. This campaign will:
  • Help pay the rent our new performance space, The Black Box Theatre at Lehman Alternative Community School, located at 111 Chestnut Street in Ithaca, NY.
  • Compensate the actors, directors, musicians, and, most importantly, artistic staff, who dedicate so much of their time to producing each season.

Our goal is to ultimately raise $25,000 annually. This year, we hope to reach $5,000. This sum will allow us to give back to those who give their time and energy to The Readers’ Theater.

Leveraging Talent

To better leverage talent, the campaign will allow us to add a Business Manager to our currently artistically-driven board. This new proposed position would help The Reader’s Theatre grow in important ways through increasing both financial and supporting sponsorship and supervising the internship program currently under development.

Contribute to Growth

Today, we are a 501(c)3 tax-exempt organization; The Readers’ Theatre filed this paperwork in part to benefit its supporters. We believe patronizing the arts should be rewarded. Your tax-deductible contribution will make reaching our campaign goals possible. 

With your help, The Readers’ Theatre will continue to work with Ithaca area actors, directors, composers, musicians, scholars, and speakers to deliver a unique performance experience.

Deepest Appreciations

“Theatre is the greatest of all art forms,” said Oscar Wilde, “the most immediate way in which a human being can share with another the sense of what it is to be a human being.” Great playwrights and great actors would be impossible, however, without great audiences.

We deeply appreciate your contribution and commitment to The Readers’ Theatre of Ithaca. For more information, or to stay up-to-date on The Readers’ Theatre news, please visit our website at www.thereaderstheatre.com, and join our e-newsletter or friend us on Facebook.

Many thanks for your support and encouragement!

Yours truly,

 

Anne Marie Cummings, Artistic Director

Eric Sterbenk, Associate Artistic Director

Tim Perry, Associate Artistic Director

Hank Roberts, Music Advisor

Dear Friends,
The Readers’ Theatre of Ithaca has provided sustainable theater at its bare essence since 2010. Committed to the public good, we believe good theater inspires dialogue within the community. Such an important civic resource should be affordable to all.
To help sustain our commitment to maintain low ticket prices, we are embarking on a community fundraiser. This campaign will:

Help pay the rent our new performance space, The Black Box Theatre at Lehman Alternative Community School, located at 111 Chestnut Street in Ithaca, NY.
Compensate the actors, directors, musicians, and, most importantly, artistic staff, who dedicate so much of their time to producing each season.
Our goal is to ultimately raise $25,000 annually. This year, we hope to reach $5,000. This sum will allow us to give back to those who give their time and energy to The Readers’ Theater.
Leveraging Talent
To better leverage talent, the campaign will allow us to add a Business Manager to our currently artistically-driven board. This new proposed position would help The Reader’s Theatre grow in important ways through increasing both financial and supporting sponsorship and supervising the internship program currently under development.
Contribute to Growth
Today, we are a 501(c)3 tax-exempt organization; The Readers’ Theatre filed this paperwork in part to benefit its supporters. We believe patronizing the arts should be rewarded. Your tax-deductible contribution will make reaching our campaign goals possible. 
With your help, The Readers’ Theatre will continue to work with Ithaca area actors, directors, composers, musicians, scholars, and speakers to deliver a unique performance experience.
Deepest Appreciations
“Theatre is the greatest of all art forms,” said Oscar Wilde, “the most immediate way in which a human being can share with another the sense of what it is to be a human being.” Great playwrights and great actors would be impossible, however, without great audiences.
We deeply appreciate your contribution and commitment to The Readers’ Theatre of Ithaca. For more information, or to stay up-to-date on The Readers’ Theatre news, please visit our website at www.thereaderstheatre.com, and join our e-newsletter or friend us on Facebook.
Many thanks for your support and encouragement!
Yours truly,
 
Anne Marie Cummings, Artistic Director
Eric Sterbenk, Associate Artistic Director
Tim Perry, Associate Artistic Director
Hank Roberts, Music Advisor

story:
The initial idea came while I was working in Hawaii for 2 weeks. The house I stayed at was next to an old bird sanctuary. I've always been fascinated with birds so I started exploring different ideas. I gravitated toward the white swan, blue bird, firebird and raven mainly because of their distinct color recognition. I touched upon a couple of ideas, looked at different angles of the stories and ultimately came back to the most common factor; the creative process. 

 

AVES (which is defined as a class of vertebrates comprising the birds) is about inspiration and how images trigger an artistic choice. As creators, we build upon ideas and emotions to create a library of visuals that express those thoughts. Using the stage and dancers as a blank canvas, We create the scenery that generates the inspiration to conceive these timeless characters.

 

We're excited to bring our vision to life. With your help, We can afford to cover costs on production (such as theater, costumes, rehearsal space, etc)

 

Performances will be May 2, 3 and 4 / 2013 @ Danspace Project in New York City

 

Choreographer:

Mike Esperanza (in collaboration with dancers)

 

Dancers:

Michael Abbatiello

Sebastian Arango

Jake Bone

Tiffanie Carson

Cat Cogliandro

Jacqui Defranca

Jessie Gonzales

Sarah Housepian

Erin Love

Evan Marsh

Katrina Muffley

Devin Oshiro

Britney Tokumoto

Ian Sherman

story:
Greetings,

My name is Ricarrdo Valentine; I am a free-lance artist living in Brooklyn, NY.  I am currently collaborating and dancing with Christal Brown/INspirit Dance Company, Dante Brown/Warehouse, Malcolm Low/FormalStructure, Paloma McGregor, and Edisa Weeks/Delirious Dance. On April 2, 2013, I was accepted into Bates Dance Festival for their professional training program held July 20- August 11, 2013 in Lewiston, Maine. As a work-study scholarship recipient, I was generously awarded $1,200.00 towards my $2,600.00 tuition. My remaining balance on my account is $1,400.00 and this is where our collective efforts come into action. Being at Bates this summer is an important and beneficial opportunity for me to continue learning about dance in all areas through classes such as Modern III, Business in Dance, Spiraldynamik, and Hip Hop. Also, Bates offers a cooperative community filled with creative artists, which will in turn provide me with rejuvenation as an artist and enrichment in art.  Your generous contribution towards achieving my goal is greatly appreciated. I believe with your support I will be able to transform as not only as an artist, but as a person that is taking another step closer to achieving my goal of being a member of a dance company while maintaining my individualism as an artist.

Thank you for your support! :)

WHAT I NEED & WHAT YOU GET

In order to achieve my goal, I need $1,400.00 for the remaining balance of my tuition for Bates Dance Festival. Bates Dance Festival tuition is due on May 28, 2013.  In return of your generosity, each person shall get a personal note sent to your home. Additional perks are available to larger contributions; these perks are displayed to the right.  If I am unable to achieve my financial goal, I will use the raised amount and continue to apply it towards my tuition.

THE IMPACT

The impact of your contribution is encouraging me to take another significant step into my dance career. I have seen how going to a professional training program can help one artist achieve their goals. For example, in 2011, I was fortunate to have attended Earl Mosely Institute of the Arts in Kent, Connecticut on a partial scholarship. Shortly after completing the intensive, my first professional opportunity was with Christal Brown /INspirit Dance Company at the Guggenheim Museum Works & Process. There I performed a piece about the life and legacy of Muhammad Ali ("The Opulence Of Integrity").  This opportunity has open up the door to work with other notable choreographers in the dance field. Attending Bates this summer will continue to open possibilities to advance as a student, artist and choreographer. I believe that Bates will keep me on track of contributing to the world through dance. 

OTHERS WAY YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to contribute, there are other ways to do so.  Please SHARE through email, Facebook and twitter. Every day is a great day to support the arts. :)

story:
Short Summary

Identity Project:  This show is a result of Olivia's exploration of Identity in all facets. Gender, has huge relevance in shaping the ideas we have about our individual identity. It places norms to follow on just about every society and if we take a further look at who we are as individuals, those norms do not seem to be a reflection of anyone’s true identity.  

This work is really a conversation between Olivia Goldberg, Lindsey Lollie & Eryka Clayton on this point.  Can we break out of the boundaries that have been put on us, release the binaries that don't fit, and see who we really are? 

 

May 17th, Doors open at 8:30 pm // Show at 9:00 pm 

Pieter Performance Space

420 W Ave 33

Ste 10
Los Angeles, CA 90031

Suggested donation at the door: $10

Donation bar!

 

What We Need & What You Get

1. We need to raise $1000 to support the entirety of the production.  

2. We will do the show whether we reach the full fundraising goal or not so your     donation keeps us from going broke. 

3. We have great perks for you no matter how much you want to donate.  Your support allows us to do what we love so we plan to get you liquored up before and after the show so you donate even more! 

 

The Impact

Both of us are dedicated to bringing live dance to local communities as much as possible.  Funding for the arts comes mainly from the community that enjoys it so you will be helping to ensure that live dance stays apart of our culture. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Everyone can contribute! 

Be a volunteer!!! We will need a few cheerful peeps with a great smile and winning attitude to help out at the door and at the bar!  

Also, please remember to share on Facebook, email, and best of course is word of mouth (text away). Help keep the arts alive!

story:
GURU KANHAIYA LAL DANCE FESTIVAL

OCTOBER 17 - 18, 2014

What is the Dance Festival about?

To commemorate its 10th anniversary, Nupur Academy LA founded by Guru Prachi Dixit, is organizing “Guru Kanhaiya Lal Dance Festival”, featuring the WORLD-PREMIERE Kathak dance-drama “The Sword & the Flute” on October 17th and 18th in Torrance, California. This annual festival marks its inaugural year by featuring India’s leading dancers and musicians like Guinness Book World Record holder Vidha Lal, known for her record of 103 perfect-Kathak spins in a minute.

The first day of the festival, October 17th, illustrates the dance-drama “The Sword & the Flute: The Story of Kali and Krishna Dark Visions of the Terrible and the Sublime in Hinduism” inspired by the work of David Kinsley. This musical highlights the mysterious connection between the two most celebrated Hindu deities - Lord Krishna and Goddess Kali.

The second day of the festival, October 18th, titled ‘Gharana Utsav’ celebrates the contribution of Guru Kanhaiya Lal - Guru and mentor of Nupur Academy LA Founder Guru Prachi DIxit. Prominent Kathak dancers from India and San Francisco will represent the three Kathak gharanas (schools).

Get a sneak peak!

About Kathak:

Kathak is derived from an ancient storytelling tradition in Northern India. (The root of Kathak, “katha”, means story.) Kathak narratives generally center on tales of Hindu Gods and Goddesses, their triumphs and defeats. Performers trained in this dance discipline work on mastering a variety of forms of physical action, including mime and facial movements.

Kathak dancers wear ankle-bells (ghungroos), that serve to accentuate the rhythmic aspects of the dance and allow complex footwork to be heard by the audience. Swift, yet graceful body movements and spins are popular Kathak movements.

Today, there are three main schools (gharanas) of Kathak - the Jaipur Gharana - the regional style emphasizing the technical mastery of pure dance, the Lucknow Gharana - emphasizing dramatic and sensuous expression and the Benares Gharana –which blends both the former styles in a unique way creating its own style.

Find out more on our website!

Goal of the Festival:

Guru Kanhaiya Lal Dance Festival is one-of-a-kind grand festival to happen in Los Angeles, and is completely devoted to showcasing the communications of the Kathak style of Indian Classical Dance. While the festival features the dance-drama “The Sword & the Flute” and showcases masters of Kathak from India and San Francisco, it profoundly nurtures the soul, the mind, and the body, all through an awakening journey of self-realization and exposure to the deep roots of dance and movement.

Speaking on the initiative, Guru Prachi Dixit says, “Our goal is to spread awareness about Kathak while preserving one of India’s traditional dance forms. The freedom of movement that Kathak affords gives a certain degree of speed. Kathak’s chakkars or spins are very popular and fast paced and it is an aspect of the dance form that audiences love. My dream is for everyone to experience and enjoy our culture, and all flavors of Kathak in its authentic form".

Why support us?

Guru Prachi Dixit is directing this festival in honor of her late dance Guru. She has collaborated efforts with dancers of her own company as well as dancers and musicians from Los Angeles, San Francisco, and India. The idea of the festival, musical compositions, choreography, and costumes are all original works of Guru Prachi Dixit.

The festival is expected to reach out to all wide areas of Los Angeles creating awareness of true arts forms and expressions of dance and culture, with the teamwork of 62 dancers and 9 musicians. 

The total cost of the production includes theater rent, light and sound manager, costumes, props, musical arrangement and recording, advertising and marketing, airfares and modest accommodations to all visiting artists and musicians. It is a vast project that will only be possible with your support!

Contributions:

All members and dancers in this festival are excited to launch this campaign in order to make Guru Kanhaiya Lal Dance Festival a great success to the Los Angeles community. The amount to be raised was decided to be $22,222 as it is a very auspicious number, especially for the start of a new project like this. You can make a donation of any chosen amount from the different levels offered. Each amount/level of contribution has a certain gift from Nupur Academy LA as a token of our deep gratitude for your kind and generous contributions. Note that all donations to Nupur Academy LA are TAX DEDUCTIBLE, and we humbly ask your help to give Guru Kanhaiya Lal Dance Festival the honorary it deserves!

Visiting Dancers:
Maulik Shah, Ishira Parikh, Abhimanyu Lal, Vidha Lal, Shambhavi Dandekar, Parimal Phadke
Visiting Musicians:
Ajeet Pathak-Tabla (Indian drums), Ranjeet Pathak-Vocal, Pankaj Mishra-Sarangi
Local Dancers & Musicians:
Marguerite Kusuhara-Sufi dancer, Saili Oak-Vocal, Ronobir Lahiri-Sitar, John Stephens-Sitar
Get your tickets here!

Risks & Challenges

Putting together a festival of this caliber can be quite the test. A challenge faced by the Director of Nupur Academy LA was how to put together the concept and idea of "The Sword & The Flute" in order to get the understanding of the co-relationship between Lord Krishna and Goddess Kali across clearly to the audience. What is more risky and challenging is the creation of music for all dance pieces, by giving it a modern twist whilst keeping the traditions of the Classical Music.

In collaboration with fabulous dancers such as Maulik Shah and Ishira Parikh, the team was able to put together their skills and expertise to create original music and choreography that is quite soul- and  mind-elevating. Challenges are what spring up the creativity and spontaneity of the dancers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please make sure you spread the word to all your family and friends, near and far about our great cause to keep the culture and tradition alive. You can share the link to the campaign on most social media using the Indiegogo share tools!

Local Dancers & Musicians:
Marguerite Kusuhara-Sufi dancer, Saili Oak-Vocal, Ronobir Lahiri-Sitar, John Stephens-Sitar


Get your tickets here!


  
Risks & Challenges
Putting together a festival of this caliber can be quite the test. A challenge faced by the Director of Nupur Academy LA was how to put together the concept and idea of "The Sword & The Flute" in order to get the understanding of the co-relationship between Lord Krishna and Goddess Kali across clearly to the audience. What is more risky and challenging is the creation of music for all dance pieces, by giving it a modern twist whilst keeping the traditions of the Classical Music.

In collaboration with fabulous dancers such as Maulik Shah and Ishira Parikh, the team was able to put together their skills and expertise to create original music and choreography that is quite soul- and  mind-elevating. Challenges are what spring up the creativity and spontaneity of the dancers.


Other Ways You Can Help



 Please make sure you spread the word to all your family and friends, near and far about our great cause to keep the culture and tradition alive. You can share the link to the campaign on most social media using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
About Marigold

Marigold Movement Center is a dance school dedicated to the study of traditional and contemporary dance traditions from around the world.

  • We will be providing classes to students of all ages, including classes specifically for children between the ages of 4-12. Students age 13 and up will be welcome to join the adult classes. We will also provide gentle movement classes specifically for seniors, and a pre-natal dance class. 
  • We have a talented group of teachers with diverse training backgrounds to provide students with classes that will prioritize cultural awareness, technical proficiency, musicality, artistry and body positivity. 
  • Our goal as a business is to provide sustainable income for dance instructors, create original performance material, and nurture our blossoming dance community. 
  • We want to provide scholarship classes to low-income students in order to make dance education accessible to those who would otherwise be prevented from attending. We believe dance provides innumerable benefits to both the individual and the community. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are a small, grass-roots family business, and we are trying to raise start up funds without having to be indebted to a bank. The space we have rented is an industrial warehouse, and so it needs some help turning into a dance studio. Funds that we raise will be used to acquire: 

  • Large mirrors for two walls of the studio $6,000
  • Marley flooring, a padded floor that is meant to be danced upon $4,000
  • LED lighting by Firefly Designs, Reno based artists $3,000 (Right now there the warehouse is lit by florescent lights, and we'd like to replace them with LED lighting that can be can be adjusted with a dimmer and require less energy).  
  • Building materials and labor for mirror supports,  $4,000
  • Building materials and furniture for dressing rooms/front desk/student lounge $3,000
  • Teaching Materials and props for classes such as mats, bolsters, chairs, stretch bands, straps, and percussion instruments.  $2,000
  • Office Suite for the front desk space including lap top, credit card scanner, and printer $2,000
  • Web design $1,000
  • Flex funds to be used for marketing, additional art installation, and performance production: $5,000
  • We will be selling advanced class cards, at a discounted rate. To view our 2015 class schedule go here: Marigold Class Schedule 2015.
  • If you do not live in Reno, or if dance classes aren't your thing, you can sponsor a class for some one else. When you select a scholarship class card, you are making it possible for a low-income student to attend class free of charge! 
    • The Impact

    By Donating to Marigold Movement Center you are helping to support diversity in dance education in the Reno, NV area. 

    • We will be offering a variety of classes on a range of dance styles including Classical Persian, Moroccan Shikhat, Lebanese Debke, Raqs Sharqi, Contempory Fusion, Modern Dance, Hoop Dance, Bhangra, and Hip Hop. We will also be providing a variety of dance conditioning classes to help dancers train and take good care of themselves. Go here for our 2015 schedule:  
    • You will be supporting a space that gives many Reno area dance artist an opportunity to grow their business. Your donation also makes it possible for us to offer work to Reno area artists who will be installing lights and assisting with construction. 
    • By purchasing a scholarship class pass you are helping a low income student access dance education.  We commit to continuing this scholarship project each year through fundraising, performances and silent auctions. 
    • We intend to host master instructors as often as possible, especially those who are connected to traditional dance forms from around the world, increasing access to art and culture for our community.
    • In October 2014 we hosted a master class with world renowned Odissi dancer and instructor Anindita Nanda. We hope to bring her back for a week long intensive in 2015.

    Other Ways You Can Help:

    • Share this campaign with everyone you know.
    • We are also accepting donations of paint, picture frames, and office supplies. Email marigoldmovementcenter@gmail.com to make a donation.

The Impact
 By Donating to Marigold Movement Center you are helping to support diversity in dance education in the Reno, NV area. 

We will be offering a variety of classes on a range of dance styles including Classical Persian, Moroccan Shikhat, Lebanese Debke, Raqs Sharqi, Contempory Fusion, Modern Dance, Hoop Dance, Bhangra, and Hip Hop. We will also be providing a variety of dance conditioning classes to help dancers train and take good care of themselves. Go here for our 2015 schedule:  
You will be supporting a space that gives many Reno area dance artist an opportunity to grow their business. Your donation also makes it possible for us to offer work to Reno area artists who will be installing lights and assisting with construction. 
By purchasing a scholarship class pass you are helping a low income student access dance education.  We commit to continuing this scholarship project each year through fundraising, performances and silent auctions.  We intend to host master instructors as often as possible, especially those who are connected to traditional dance forms from around the world, increasing access to art and culture for our community.
In October 2014 we hosted a master class with world renowned Odissi dancer and instructor Anindita Nanda. We hope to bring her back for a week long intensive in 2015.    Other Ways You Can Help:


Share this campaign with everyone you know.
We are also accepting donations of paint, picture frames, and office supplies. Email marigoldmovementcenter@gmail.com to make a donation.

story:
| UPDATE SEPTEMBER 14 |

Thanks to all our funders past and present who have helped us reach our first stretch goal and have now funded ANIMEZING this January!

Because of this, Rene will now shave his head, everybody will receive a backers button, as well as an ANIMEZING button for helping this show reach it's goal, and when our campaign ends, we will reveal details about one of two secret shows.

Our second goal will BASICALLY fund Fandom Hearts 2, in a manner that we can put on the show with the most minimum stuff we need, including minor props, sets and costumes.

If we can reach this next $400 in the next 12 hours, everybody will get a Fandom Hearts 2 button, and we will reveal details about BOTH of our two secret shows. We will also release a demo track from Fandom Hearts 2 to all backers only.

We're Fandom Musicals, and we're looking to bring you 4 new and amazing musical theater shows, both live and online.

At Fandom Musicals, we're a not for profit volunteer theatre group, performing all these shows because we love performing, and you love watching it. In the past year, we've been able to bring you three amazing shows, and now we invite you to help us bring you another four more to both a live stage,  and the whole world online.

In June 2013, you helped us raise enough money to perform "Fandom Hearts", our parody musical of Kingdom Hearts, and since then, we've put every dollar we've made into our sketch show, "Off The Top Of Our Heads", which premiered last January, and our sci-fi spoof "Star Explor”,which premiered at ConBravo! 2014. Now the time has come to do another season of shows, and we look to the support of our fans to make it happen.

Here’s some details on our upcoming season:

Frost Bite is our Canadian comedic take on a zombie pandemic, and the whole genre of horror. A rag tag group of Canadians must team up and fight their way through a zombie infested city to stop their invasion, and expose an evil plot. It's filled with parodies of your favorite zombie fandoms, and pokes fun at the stuff we love about horror movies.

Animezing is an interactive comedy sketch show with sketches and songs based around everything in Anime culture from the cosplayers, to the conventions, the voice actors, and to the fans they have. It'll include interactive improv with the audience, and a bunch of original songs.

The X Musical tells the story of your favorite gang of mutants coming together to stop a familiar magnetic villain. Just like Fandom Hearts wasn't just about Kingdom Hearts, The X Musical is all about the world of comics, super heroes, and the characters facing all the problems that come with that. It'll have a major cast and feature new original songs, and a bunch of special effects for you to sink your teeth (or adamantium claws) into.

And finally, the show our fans have been waiting for since July 2013, is Fandom Hearts 2, the follow up to our first full length production. Continuing on the ending to the last show, our clown shoed hero and his anthropomorphic friends are facing a new group of 13 villains, with some help from other Disney heroes. It's going to be up to them to discover new things about themselves, and put a stop to the darkness for good. It features brand new songs, and the continuing story our fans have been waiting to see.

Our main goal is $1,400 which will fund both our next full length shows, Frost Bite and The X Musical. The budgets for each are as follows:

FROST BITE
$600

  • $300 Soundtrack
  • $100 Props / Sets
  • $200 Costumes

The X Musical
$800

  • $400 Soundtrack
  • $200 Props / Sets
  • $200 Costumes

Because we want to be able to bring you all these shows however, we've added 3 additional stretch goals to help push the additional content that we can create from them. 

Stretch Goal #1 is $1700 which will fund Frost Bite and The X Musical (as listed above) as well as recording the soundtrack for Animezing.

Animezing

  • $300 Soundtrack

Stretch Goal #2 is $2100 which will fund Frost Bite, The X Musical, Animezing, (as listed above) and will give us the absolute BASIC budget we need for Fandom Hearts 2 as follows:

Fandom Hearts 2 (Basic)

  • $300 Soundtrack
  • $100 Props / Sets / Costumes

But if we can make it to Stretch Goal #3 which is $2700, it will fund Frost Bite, The X Musical, Animezing, (as listed above) and let us produce the best possible version of Fandom Hearts 2 for stage and online, as follows:

Fandom Hearts 2 (Full)

  • $500 Soundtrack
  • $250 Props / Sets
  • $250 Costumes

With our current catalog of shows and merch already, we can bring you amazing rewards immediately, as well as rewards following the production of these shows over the next two years. It’s like the gift that keeps on giving!

In the event that we don't succeed in the funding of our goal, we will receive any of the funding we did get, and we will continue to bring all rewards to our backers.

We'll leave you with our mission here at Fandom Musicals, which is to bring you unique shows that take the stories you know and love, and bring them to life in a new way, touching that childhood heart we all still have, while also making you laugh, cry, and remember. Remember that we are joined together for our love of these characters, these stories, and these fandoms that have defined who we are as fans. We'd like to continue to do this for as long as we can, and as long as fans over the world can support us, support live theater, and support SPREADING THE FANDOM.

story:
Breve reseña

La Teta Teatro es una compañía de teatro chilena/salvadoreña que inicia su trabajo en 2006 en Chile y lo retoma en 2012 en El Salvador. Nos planteamos trabajar con mujeres desde temáticas en dónde se reivindiquen nuestras historias, nuestras biografías, y nuestros espacios en el teatro. Así nace el proyecto Lulú.

Con el proyecto "Lulú" la Teta Teatro, se propuso fortalecer la formación profesional escénica en El Salvador, y  fortalecer la  participación de mujeres tanto en la actuación cómo en la dirección. Este proyecto lleva aproximadamente dos años, considerando la formación actoral, semiótica teatral, expresión corporal, análisis teatral y proceso de montaje culminando el proceso con la obra "Lulú" de Ana Harcha Cortés. 

Hasta el momento el proyecto ha sido autogestionado, sin embargo este año hemos sido invitadas para participar en el VIII Festival Internacional de Teatro y Danza, FINTDAZ 2015, en Iquique, Chile y queremos a través de esta campaña gestionar la Gira.

La campaña “Lulú en Chile” será difundida a través de los medios de comunicación de El Salvador y de la promoción en redes sociales, solicitando apoyo de parte de nuestros contactos tanto dentro como fuera del país. La meta a alcanzar es de USD $5,000.00 con los que planeamos costear:

Boletos de avión para las 2 actrices que participan en el proyecto "Lulú" de la Teta Teatro (El Salvador/Chile/El Salvador)

Alojamiento y alimentación en Chile 

Inversión en difusión gráfica (Bannner, afiches, camisas/poleras para el evento en Chile)

Traslado de la escenografía (El Salvador/Chile/El Salvador)

Filmación del evento (obra, tras la cámara, algunos ensayos, y comentarios de las actrices, su experiencia etc. en el festival en Chile, que es dónde damos finalización al proyecto)


Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Necesitamos 5 mil dólares, para cubrir todos los gastos mencionados anteriormente. Todo el dinero que recibamos irá a una cuenta internacional que maneja nuestra encargada de comunicaciones, de ese modo queremos lograr hacer las compras vía internet de los billetes y pagos de impuestos tanto de las pasajeras, como de la escenografía para ahorrarnos los gastos de atención que normalmente piden las aerolíneas.

Las recompensas serán para agradecer toda la confianza y apoyo hacia nuestro proyecto, por tanto ofrecemos: 

Menciones en todas nuestras redes sociales 

Postales con nuestros agradecimientos enviados de forma personal, conversaciones por skype con el equipo de nuestra compañía, 

Camisetas de nuestra participación en el festival, 

Detalles de su dinero gastado en nuestras acciones para llegar a Chile, cuándo este sea sobre 50 dólares.

Mención con agradecimientos exclusivos en los créditos  del vídeo que filmaremos en Iquique.  

Además unas eternas GRACIAS por confiar en nuestro proyecto.

Si no logramos la meta

Intentaremos considerar otras alternativas como organizar fiestas, rifas y estimular  a que nuestras amistades interesadas aporten de forma más directa. Aunque su dinero igual estará involucrado en las actividades para llevar a cabo estas acciones.

El impacto

Creemos que fortalecer espacios de mujeres en las artes o en el teatro, implica responsabilizarnos de nuestras historias, emociones, biografías etc. desde nuestras perspectivas y desde nuestras sensibilidades.  Por ello consideramos a “Lulú” como un proyecto importante porque es el punto de partida, para una gira latinoamericana de talleres en la que nos encontramos actualmente; gira que vemos como una experiencia etnográfica de trabajo con mujeres indígenas, ladinas y mujeres en general, que enriquece nuestra motivación para hacer crecer a nuestra compañía "La Teta Teatro", y que nos está brindando insumos para posteriormente poder replicar el proceso formativo que se impulsó en El Salvador, en otros países  con el proyecto "Historias de mujeres por América Latina".
Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Si no puedes ayudarnos con tu dinero, no hay problemas, hay formas de cooperar que te agradeceremos como por ejemplo compartir el link de esta campaña para que  tus amigas y amigos conozcan nuestro proyecto.

story:
Ungrateful Daughter
One Black Girl’s Story of Being Adopted into a White Family. . . that aren’t Celebrities.
written and performed by Lisa Marie Rollins
directed by W. Kamau Bell

Angelina Jolie, Tom Cruise, Nicole Kidman and Madonna have adopted black children. How could it not be good? “Ungrateful Daughter”, Lisa Marie’s riveting solo show, examines being a black girl adopted into a white family and how all that relates to these celebrity crazes, the Haitian and Ethiopian ‘orphans’ and the myth of colorblind love.

Complete show description:
http://birthproject.wordpress.com/ungrateful-da...

How /Where your money will be spent:

Production Expenses
- Light & sound for the work

- Video & image design for the work

- Graphic design for publicity and website

- Publicity

Direct support to the artist
- Application fees to foundations and local SF/ Bay Area arts organizations for funding and

- Incubation support for final stages of development.

Words:
“Ungrateful Daughter left us thinking deeply about the truths we don’t hear from adult adoptees about domestic and international adoption… Highly recommended.” Heidi Durrow and Fanshen Cox of Mixed Chicks Podcast and Mixed Roots Film and Literary Festival. mxroots.org

For more information, questions please email thirdrootproductions@gmail.com

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD on your Twitter or Facebook Page!

About the Artist:
LISA MARIE ROLLINS (Writer/ Performer) is a writer, performer and multidisciplinary theater producer. Her solo work has been featured at the Monday Night Marsh, WordsFirst, Off-Market Theater, Shelton Theater, StageWerks, SF Playhouse and others. She has been working with SF’s Solo Performance Workshop, founded by W. Kamau Bell and Bruce Pachtman, since its inception in 2005. She is the Artistic Director of Third Root Art Collective, an Art House that workshops, directs and produces solo theater, music, visual art and poetry performances. She is the Founder of AFAAD, Adopted and Fostered Adults of the African Diaspora, an organization that connects, supports, and advocates for adoptees and foster care alumni.

About the Director:
W KAMAU BELLis the Founder and Director of San Francisco’s Solo Performance Workshop. http://www.wkamaubell.com/about
