story:
>TRACK ONE: "Help Me," Joni Mitchell

Hi friends!

So, this is an IndieGoGo campaign, eh? I know you're gonna get slammed with these, given that it's festival season, so I'll try and keep this as brief and entertaining as possible. I realize I'm already defeating the brevity by explaining how brief I will be with words that are already taking up space where vital information cou--

Let me start over.

Hi friends!

I'm Nat. You probably know me. I write and direct plays. I'm presenting one of my NEWEST plays this summer in the NY International Fringe Festival!

You may remember I participated in FringeNYC last year with my noir/Dostoevsky ghost story The Eternal Husband, which was wonderfully received. This year, given the nature of the project, we here at Tin Drum Productions wanted to go a little more grassroots-y, and so we're asking you for your gracious help!

>TRACK TWO: "Who Are You," The Who

Songs of Love: A Theatrical Mixtape is a really special, unique show. It combines two of my favorite things: ridiculously warped love stories and sweet, catchy folk songs.

Basically, you've seen me do full-lengths (sometimes very full), but here is a collection of some of my twisted li'l short plays, each one having to do with romantic love.

And did I mention each short play is complemented by an original song, performed live onstage by a very handsome singer-songwriter? It's a THEATRICAL MIXTAPE, my friends, and it's been lovingly put together for you, by me, just like one of those 90-minute cassettes you know you're still hanging onto.

Tracks include: genital warts, decapitation, pornography, bagel fucking, and, of course ... love.

>TRACK THREE: "It's So Easy," Buddy Holly

Producing in the Fringe is not easy, Buddy Holly. That's the dumbest thing you've said since, "Why shouldn't the Big Bopper get to bring his snow machine onboard?" Here is just some of what we need to raise money for in order to produce this special Mixtape:

  • Paying the actors, stage manager, designers, festival volunteers, etc., for their time and skills
  • Props
  • Marketing
  • PR
  • Insurance
  • Rehearsal space
  • Drug m-- ... I mean, snacks ... for orphans ...

Believe me when I say this adds up somethin' fierce. And I am but an humble writer/director with three kids to feed (those kids are named "Rent," "SallieMae," and "Verizon"). So, whatever you can give is HUUUUGELY appreciated.

And, to make it worth your while, we've lined up a gaggle of AMAZING perks. Check them out, they're listed hereish ------>

Didja look at 'em? AMAZING!

>TRACK FOUR: "With a Little Help from My Friends," Joe Cocker

I know allllll too well how tight funds can be, so if you can't spare anything monetarily, you can still totally help out if you're so inclined. Even if you'd just be so kind as to spread the word of either this campaign, or the show itself, I will offer you the following rewards:

  • Smothering you with kisses
  • Calling your loved ones personally to let them know how and why you were smothered with kisses
  • Throwing you a KISS-themed funeral hosted by the Smothers Brothers

>TRACK FIVE: "Everybody's Talkin'," Harry Nilsson

Just in case you've never seen a Nat Cassidy production, here are some samples of what folks have said before:

Nytheatre.com People of the Year, 2011 - "Nat Cassidy is an actor, director, and playwright of surprising range and depth."

THE ETERNAL HUSBAND

"Amazing, unforgettable, absolutely electrifying ... Generates heat that is pure brilliance ... This is 75 minutes you do not want to miss!" - Joe Franklin, Bloomberg Radio

"Among the shows I've seen thus far in this year's festival, The Eternal Husband offers the most enjoyable night of theater. I can't wait for Cassidy's next creation." - Nathaniel Kressen, nytheatre.com

"Nat Cassidy's The Eternal Husband has pretty much everything. Moments of sheer terror mixed with darkly funny humour; a romantic core with a violent exterior. But my gosh does it work. ... An impressive piece of work by any standards." - Robert Walport, The Tyro Theatre Critic

I AM PROVIDENCE (winner, NY Innovative Theatre Award, Outstanding Solo Performance, 2011)

"A near-perfect horror fest ... The audience, breath held, hangs on every sound and word. This is pure storytelling." - Nita Congress, nytheatre.com

"Truly amazing ... An unexpectedly brilliant mediation on the use and function of horror, on the supernatural, on storytelling, on death, on hope ... I'm still thinking about it, days later." - Tor.com

"Successful for so many reasons ... A true treat ... Entertaining, educational and strangely unsettling. Any fan of horror in general shouldn't miss this show ... Riveting." - Weston Clay, Theatre Is Easy

"It is the most delightful thing we have ever seen anyone pull off on a stage, anywhere, ever, and if you are in New York you must go see it. You must. You REALLY MUST. Go. GO." - The Rejectionist

"Oh, God, why. WHY." - The Village Voice

ANY DAY NOW (winner, NYIT Award, Outstanding Lead Actress [Elyse Mirto], 2009; nominee, Outstanding Director [Nat Cassidy])

"The audience [is] never quite sure whether to laugh or to gasp. Cassidy packages his supernatural theme with such naturalistic aplomb that he evokes David Lynch ... Increasingly jaw-dropping ... Any Day Now is further evidence of Cassidy's talent and intelligence as playwright and director." - Martin Denton, nytheatre.com

"GENIUS. You're thrown for a loop from the moment the lights come up...and are entertained for all three acts. A great play for a myriad of reasons ... Holds the audience in the palm of its hand ... Exceptional ... This is like Sam Sheppard meets George Romero....with more emphasis on the former artist than the latter." - Dianna Martin, The Fab Marquee

"A vibrant drama heightened by a clever allegory for larger social issues ... The play's themes are compelling and clear." - Show Business Weekly

"I don't often get to cover Off-Off-Broadway, but I'm glad I came down to see this. ... Cassidy has a gift for dialogue and characterization. ... Tight, suspenseful and scary." - Richard Seff, DC Theatre Scene

THE RECKONING OF KIT & LITTLE BOOTS (winner, NYIT Award, Outstanding Full-Length Script, 2009; nominee, Outstanding Lead Actor [David Ian Lee], Outstanding Production)

"Fab and irresistible ... Cassidy nails what's universal ... One thing's certain: there's talent aplenty on display here. Cassidy is clearly a young theatre artist to watch." - Martin Denton, nytheatre.com

"Incredibly fun ... The Reckoning of Kit & Little Boots is a very inventive and funny play that gives Marlowe the Charlie Kaufman treatment." - James Comtois, Jamespeak, #6 in his "Top 10 of 2008"
story_txt:
>TRACK ONE: "Help Me," Joni Mitchell
Hi friends!
So, this is an IndieGoGo campaign, eh? I know you're gonna get slammed with these, given that it's festival season, so I'll try and keep this as brief and entertaining as possible. I realize I'm already defeating the brevity by explaining how brief I will be with words that are already taking up space where vital information cou--
Let me start over.
Hi friends!
I'm Nat. You probably know me. I write and direct plays. I'm presenting one of my NEWEST plays this summer in the NY International Fringe Festival!
You may remember I participated in FringeNYC last year with my noir/Dostoevsky ghost story The Eternal Husband, which was wonderfully received. This year, given the nature of the project, we here at Tin Drum Productions wanted to go a little more grassroots-y, and so we're asking you for your gracious help!


>TRACK TWO: "Who Are You," The Who
Songs of Love: A Theatrical Mixtape is a really special, unique show. It combines two of my favorite things: ridiculously warped love stories and sweet, catchy folk songs.
Basically, you've seen me do full-lengths (sometimes very full), but here is a collection of some of my twisted li'l short plays, each one having to do with romantic love.
And did I mention each short play is complemented by an original song, performed live onstage by a very handsome singer-songwriter? It's a THEATRICAL MIXTAPE, my friends, and it's been lovingly put together for you, by me, just like one of those 90-minute cassettes you know you're still hanging onto.
Tracks include: genital warts, decapitation, pornography, bagel fucking, and, of course ... love.

>TRACK THREE: "It's So Easy," Buddy Holly
Producing in the Fringe is not easy, Buddy Holly. That's the dumbest thing you've said since, "Why shouldn't the Big Bopper get to bring his snow machine onboard?" Here is just some of what we need to raise money for in order to produce this special Mixtape:

Paying the actors, stage manager, designers, festival volunteers, etc., for their time and skills
Props
Marketing
PR
Insurance
Rehearsal space
Drug m-- ... I mean, snacks ... for orphans ...

Believe me when I say this adds up somethin' fierce. And I am but an humble writer/director with three kids to feed (those kids are named "Rent," "SallieMae," and "Verizon"). So, whatever you can give is HUUUUGELY appreciated.
And, to make it worth your while, we've lined up a gaggle of AMAZING perks. Check them out, they're listed hereish ------>
Didja look at 'em? AMAZING!

>TRACK FOUR: "With a Little Help from My Friends," Joe Cocker


I know allllll too well how tight funds can be, so if you can't spare anything monetarily, you can still totally help out if you're so inclined. Even if you'd just be so kind as to spread the word of either this campaign, or the show itself, I will offer you the following rewards:

Smothering you with kisses
Calling your loved ones personally to let them know how and why you were smothered with kisses
Throwing you a KISS-themed funeral hosted by the Smothers Brothers


>TRACK FIVE: "Everybody's Talkin'," Harry Nilsson

Just in case you've never seen a Nat Cassidy production, here are some samples of what folks have said before:
Nytheatre.com People of the Year, 2011 - "Nat Cassidy is an actor, director, and playwright of surprising range and depth."
THE ETERNAL HUSBAND
"Amazing, unforgettable, absolutely electrifying ... Generates heat that is pure brilliance ... This is 75 minutes you do not want to miss!" - Joe Franklin, Bloomberg Radio
"Among the shows I've seen thus far in this year's festival, The Eternal Husband offers the most enjoyable night of theater. I can't wait for Cassidy's next creation." - Nathaniel Kressen, nytheatre.com
"Nat Cassidy's The Eternal Husband has pretty much everything. Moments of sheer terror mixed with darkly funny humour; a romantic core with a violent exterior. But my gosh does it work. ... An impressive piece of work by any standards." - Robert Walport, The Tyro Theatre Critic
I AM PROVIDENCE (winner, NY Innovative Theatre Award, Outstanding Solo Performance, 2011)
"A near-perfect horror fest ... The audience, breath held, hangs on every sound and word. This is pure storytelling." - Nita Congress, nytheatre.com
"Truly amazing ... An unexpectedly brilliant mediation on the use and function of horror, on the supernatural, on storytelling, on death, on hope ... I'm still thinking about it, days later." - Tor.com
"Successful for so many reasons ... A true treat ... Entertaining, educational and strangely unsettling. Any fan of horror in general shouldn't miss this show ... Riveting." - Weston Clay, Theatre Is Easy
"It is the most delightful thing we have ever seen anyone pull off on a stage, anywhere, ever, and if you are in New York you must go see it. You must. You REALLY MUST. Go. GO." - The Rejectionist
"Oh, God, why. WHY." - The Village Voice
ANY DAY NOW (winner, NYIT Award, Outstanding Lead Actress [Elyse Mirto], 2009; nominee, Outstanding Director [Nat Cassidy])
"The audience [is] never quite sure whether to laugh or to gasp. Cassidy packages his supernatural theme with such naturalistic aplomb that he evokes David Lynch ... Increasingly jaw-dropping ... Any Day Now is further evidence of Cassidy's talent and intelligence as playwright and director." - Martin Denton, nytheatre.com
"GENIUS. You're thrown for a loop from the moment the lights come up...and are entertained for all three acts. A great play for a myriad of reasons ... Holds the audience in the palm of its hand ... Exceptional ... This is like Sam Sheppard meets George Romero....with more emphasis on the former artist than the latter." - Dianna Martin, The Fab Marquee
"A vibrant drama heightened by a clever allegory for larger social issues ... The play's themes are compelling and clear." - Show Business Weekly
"I don't often get to cover Off-Off-Broadway, but I'm glad I came down to see this. ... Cassidy has a gift for dialogue and characterization. ... Tight, suspenseful and scary." - Richard Seff, DC Theatre Scene
THE RECKONING OF KIT & LITTLE BOOTS (winner, NYIT Award, Outstanding Full-Length Script, 2009; nominee, Outstanding Lead Actor [David Ian Lee], Outstanding Production)
"Fab and irresistible ... Cassidy nails what's universal ... One thing's certain: there's talent aplenty on display here. Cassidy is clearly a young theatre artist to watch." - Martin Denton, nytheatre.com
"Incredibly fun ... The Reckoning of Kit & Little Boots is a very inventive and funny play that gives Marlowe the Charlie Kaufman treatment." - James Comtois, Jamespeak, #6 in his "Top 10 of 2008"

story:
Twos and Ones is a performance collective established in January 2011 by Philip Berezney, Siena Evans, and Timothy Garlid. We are about to start work on our third collaboration and we need your help!


Since arriving in New Orleans, we have been excited to enter the newly burgeoning arts community - which is currently gaining momentum, especially in the performing arts! We hope to contribute to this positive artistic energy and in doing so help the city grow and develop.


Alteriors, our newest work, will be one half of a two-part event presented this November as a part of the New Orleans Fringe Festival at the Zeitgeist Multi-Disciplinary Arts Center - a great space that we hope will benefit from the attention brought to it from this event. In this new work, we will continue to explore the power of the trio and the fact that our work is necessarily defined by the relationships that can be implied between two men and one woman. The title references alternate spaces - located somewhere between an interior and an exterior - and relates to our collective interest in the potential for alterations to be made to one's self-identity.


The money that we raise from this site will go directly to production costs for this piece, specifically toward festival application fees and marketing costs. This will help us put all the money we eventually make in ticket sales toward future projects! Whether or not we reach our funding goal of $500, any amount you can contribute will bring us closer to completely offsetting our production costs!


For more information about Twos and Ones, and to see pictures and videos from our previous works, check us out on facebook at:

https://www.facebook.com/twosandones


We appreciate your support (loving or monetary) and look forward to sharing our new piece with you!

story:
The Abridged Synopsis:

The dance work will take the romantic ballet themes and stand them on end. A blend of the love themes of Swan Lake and the macabre of Edgar Alan Poe’s The Raven, this contemporary dance work promises to thrill audiences.  The Raven will be set in December, 2099 – cold, disengaged, sterile. ‘Prince’ Ivan is a painter who has lost faith in the goodness of mankind and relationship with his estranged wife, Lenore. His painting, The Raven, comes to life in a fantasy and shows him that there is still good in the world. The Ivan experiences a perverse conflict between desire to forget and desire to remember [his love for another man]. He begins as weak and weary, becomes regretful and grief-stricken, before passing into a frenzy and, finally, madness. A forbidden fairytale love ends his life. 


 

Mission Statement:
Between Movement is an organization committed to achieving artistic excellence within professional dance and performance art. It is our goal to continue to represent our artistic community in a positive way while still holding onto the integrity of our aesthetic.

Company Bio:
Founded in 2006, Between Movement has been striving to present cutting-edge movement art while bringing to the foreground controversial contemporary social issues. Artistic Director, Jeff Choice, developed this project as a vehicle to confront audiences with their own socioeconomic demons. BMCDC hopes to embrace the dissension among our communities by making all aware of the pain our lives can cause.


Letter from the Artistic Director

In 2011, Between Movement will continue to captivate audiences with our avante guard programming. I am writing to let you know about our December production of The Raven. A recent relocation to Hartford, CT has opened up new collaborative efforts through which this project will be made possible. The Raven will premiere December 2 & 3 at the Academy of the Arts in Hartford, Connecticut!


After years of contemplation we are finally ready to move forward with this project!  The company has reached out to artists across the country for this collaborative project. We are privileged to be working with Costume Designer Marissa Cerveris (Bethlehem, PA), Graphic Designer Rose Harris (Pittsburgh, PA), Lighting and Set  Designer Jon Haupt (Bloomsburgh, PA), and Connecticut native Bill Holden (Composer). I am very thrilled to work with these artists as we begin to bring The Raven to life! 


As exciting as this project is for Between Movement, the financial responsibility is too great for us to bear alone. Venturing into our 4th production season we face several financial challenges. A facet of pride for this company has been that our first three seasons were 100% self-funded! As you can imagine, this was not an easy task. As part of the 2011 Capital Campaign we hope to raise $30,000 to bring this new work to the stage - our largest funding campaign to date! I hope that you consider donating to help with this effort. Every member of the production team thanks you for your contribution!


Jeff Choice

Artistic Director

Between Movement Contemporary Dance Co.

story:
Our Story

We are Hugh and Larry. Two childhood friends that went to a party one time, and at that party, they had a really, really, really, good time. This party is known as a Decentralized Dance Party. As many of you have hopefully attended one of our ddp's or Tom & Gary's, we know that you share the same excitement as us. We however have a slight problem. Throwing these parties has become rather financially straining thus we come to you, our beloved fellow partiers, for support and additional party awesomeness. So if you have faith in us and yourself to make this dream a reality, help us to help you party!!


The Impact

DDP has come to be three letters synonomous with an unreal time. Many attendees have left claiming it to be one of the best nights of their life. The angles and aspects that can arise from the use of a Decentralized Sound System are limitless. March 5th we intend to throw another awesome DDP at UVIC. In order for this event to unfold, we need to get more batteries and more boomboxes. This is where we need the help of a few generous believers of the Victoria DDP crew.


What We Need & What You Get

This is what it boils down to. During the Halloween DDP we walked away with 50 less boomboxes (~$500). That brought the fleet below half of what we originally had. In the spirit of these parties being so popular we turn to you for help. We need $500 to purchase more batteries and more boomboxes to pump more party awesomeness as the crowd size for the March 5th DDP became larger than anticipated within 12 hours of posting the event. We kindly remind you this fundraiser does not include the thousands of dollars of our own money we have spent to acquire the fm transmitter, every stereo, and battery which has brought the party madness thus far. We are just two regular guys that can't keep fronting our own money, but we are however willing to do all the leg work for these massive street parties. We have had nothing but a great time throwing parties in Victoria, and hope we get the chance to continue. As for the size of Hugh and Larry's upcoming DDP, we leave it in your hands. This is an all or nothing funding system. If we do not reach our goal, your donations will be refunded and the partying will sadly not go on. Please consider the fact we are not asking for a lot. Any night at the bar or club doesn't compare to a small donation for an unreal time at a Decentralized Dance Party. Thank you to all for your support. Now, to the right you will see our party perks. They are open to interpretation and if you have anything you would like to see as a perk don't hesitate to contact us and we'll try to make it happen for you. Hugh and Larry want this to be a party by the people, for the people. Any input is greatly appreciated! Add Hugh AndLarry on Facebook or email at ddprevolution@gmail.com

THE COST BREAKDOWN:
300 D Batteries ~ $300
20 more boomboxes for the fleet ~ $200


Other Ways You Can Help

We kindly ask that if you believe in making the ddp a part of your future entertainment, you help us get the word out on funding this party platoon of awesomeness. Facebook posts, telling friends, pooling funds for the higher end perks, or anything you can think of to get this party package bigger and bolder. Let's do this Victoria!
